questions.text: An 11-month-old infant boy is brought to the office by his parents for jaundice. Parents report they introduced multiple new foods recently. The parents noticed two days ago that he looked yellow. Additionally, he has been more fussy than usual, and his activity level has decreased. The urine is dark-colored, and there is no change in stools. He has not had fever, vomiting, seizures, or hypotonia. Pregnancy, birth, medical, and surgical histories are non-contributory. The parents are originally from Bahrain. Temperature is 37° C (98.6° F), pulse is 55/min, respirations are 38/min, blood pressure is 94/52 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical exam, scleral icterus and facial jaundice are noted. There is conjunctival pallor. Cardiac exam is significant for tachycardia and a flow murmur. Pulmonary and abdominal exams are normal. Lab work is significant for unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and anemia. The peripheral blood smear is shown below. Which of the following should be performed next to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This infant who is of Middle Eastern ancestry presents with jaundice and dark urine after exposure to new foods. Lab work shows anemia and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and the peripheral smear shows bite cells and Heinz bodies. This patient likely has glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency and may have been exposed to foods like fava beans. G6PD deficiency can be confirmed with a spectrophotometric assay.    

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is an X-linked disorder that causes hemolytic anemia. It is most often found in people with Middle Eastern or Sub-Saharan African ancestry. Hemolytic anemia occurs in patients with G6PD deficiency following exposure to oxidative stressors such as certain drugs (e.g., antimalarial drugs and sulfonamides), infections, and foods (e.g. fava beans).       

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is often differentiated into hemolytic and non-hemolytic etiologies. Hemolytic causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia can be further differentiated into immune-mediated (e.g., ABO or Rhesus incompatibility) and non-immune-mediated (e.g., hemoglobinopathies, red blood cell (RBC) membranopathies, or RBC enzyme defects).  When unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is found, further laboratory tests should be ordered including blood type (in newborns), direct antiglobulin test (DAT), complete blood count (CBC), reticulocyte count, and a peripheral blood smear. Findings of an elevated reticulocyte count suggest a hemolytic process.    

Option Analysis

❌ Hemoglobin electrophoresis  :
Incorrect: Hemoglobin electrophoresis is used to diagnose various hemoglobinopathies such as sickle cell disease. However, this patient’s presentation and peripheral smear showing bite cells, and not sickle cells, are consistent with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, which would be confirmed with a G6PD spectrophotometric assay. 
❌ Abdominal ultrasound :
Incorrect: An abdominal ultrasound aids in diagnosing various causes of cholestasis causing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. However, this patient has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and the bite cells on the peripheral smear are consistent with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. A G6PD spectrophotometric assay would confirm this diagnosis 
✅ Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) spectrophotometric assay :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Uridine diphosphate glucuronosyltransferase-1A1 (UGT1A1) genetic testing :
Incorrect: Uridine diphosphate glucuronosyltransferase-1A1 genetic testing is used to diagnose Crigler-Najjar syndrome which presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. While this patient does have unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, the peripheral smear shows bite cells, which indicate glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. A G6PD spectrophotometric assay should be ordered to confirm this diagnosis. 
❌ Osmotic fragility test :
Incorrect: An osmotic fragility test is used to diagnose hereditary spherocytosis, which presents with spherocytes on peripheral smear. In contrast, this patient’s peripheral smear shows bite cells, making glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency likely, which can be confirmed by a spectrophotometric assay.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy presents to the clinic with 2 days of fatigue, malaise, arthralgias, and headache. The symptoms have progressively worsened. Ten days ago, the patient was hiking where he lives in northern Connecticut. The rash is not painful or pruritic. The patient has not had a sore throat, and there is no history of sick contacts. Past medical, family, and surgical histories are non-contributory. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 119/76 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical exam, there is a rash present on the right thigh as shown in the picture below. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. The patient has full range of motion of the neck without stiffness. There is no swelling of the joints, and the patient has full range of motion of the joints with some pain associated with movement. Which of the following laboratory tests is needed to confirm the diagnosis before starting treatment? 


Reproduced from: Wikimedia commons. Licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.5 Generic.
questions.solution:
This 12-year-old boy who lives in Connecticut and was recently hiking presents with fatigue, malaise, arthralgias, headache, and a bull's eye rash consistent with erythema migrans (EM). The presence of EM rash indicates early localized Lyme disease. Treatment should be started immediately in early localized Lyme disease as no testing is needed to confirm the diagnosis before initiating treatment.        

Patients with Lyme disease may report a tick bite or travel to a Lyme-endemic area. Erythema migrans appear with early localized Lyme disease within days to two weeks after an infected tick bite. The skin lesion begins as a red or purple-colored macule or papule and expands with enhanced central erythema. It may appear as a bull’s eye lesion, as in this case. The rash is often non-painful and non-pruritic and may be accompanied by systemic symptoms, such as fever, malaise, headache, stiff neck, myalgias, and arthralgias. Carditis with a prolonged PR interval on electrocardiography is a manifestation of early disseminated Lyme disease. The most common manifestation of late Lyme disease, which occurs weeks to months after the initial infection, is arthritis, which is typically monoarticular, and affects the large joints, particularly the knee.        

The diagnostic evaluation of children who present with fever and rash involves narrowing down the most likely etiology based on history and physical exam including rash morphology. If the characteristic erythema migrans (bull’s eye lesion) rash is seen, and the patient lives in or has been to a Lyme endemic area, and there are no signs or symptoms of early disseminated or late disease, then no further work-up is required before treatment. If the patient has signs and symptoms of early disseminated or late Lyme disease, serology testing for Borrelia burgdorferi with an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) with reflex to Western immunoblot should be performed. Positive serology confirms a diagnosis of Lyme disease. Repeat testing is recommended several weeks later if initial testing is negative due to low sensitivity of serologic testing in early disease.   

Option Analysis

✅ No testing is required:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) :
Incorrect: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is commonly used to confirm infections such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Although PCR can be used to confirm Lyme disease, this test is not recommended for numerous reasons including a high false positive rate. A presumptive diagnosis of early localized Lyme disease can be made, and treatment should be given without the need for laboratory confirmation of disease. 
❌ Skin biopsy:
Incorrect: Skin biopsy is useful in confirming various skin infections such as Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome. This patient has early localized Lyme disease which can be diagnosed clinically, and treatment should be started without the need for laboratory confirmation. 
❌ Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISA):
Incorrect: This patient has early localized Lyme disease, and confirmatory lab testing is not necessary prior to starting treatment. Typically, testing will be negative in early Lyme, and ELISA should be only performed 4-6 weeks after the appearance of an erythema migrans rash.  
❌ Throat culture :
Incorrect: A throat culture can aid in diagnosing strep throat and scarlet fever secondary to group A streptococcus. This patient has early localized Lyme disease, and no laboratory testing is needed to confirm the diagnosis before starting treatment.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the office for fever, headache, and rash. The patient returned from a camping trip in Oklahoma two weeks ago. He first developed an intermittent fever with temperatures as high as 40°C (104°F). Three days after the fevers first started, the patient developed a maculopapular erythematous rash on the ankles and wrists that subsequently spread to the trunk, palms, and soles. The patient also reports fatigue and abdominal pain. Past medical, family, and surgical histories are non-contributory. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 100/66 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical exam, a non-blanching erythematous petechial rash is seen on the chest, trunk and extremities, including the palms and soles. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Labs are shown below. Which of the following should be ordered to confirm the most likely diagnosis?  

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Serum chemistries           
 Hemoglobin      13.5  g/dL     
 Hematocrit      40 %     
 Leukocyte count      8,100 /mm3     
 Platelet count      142,000/mm3     
 Neutrophils, segmented      70%     
 Lymphocytes      20%     
 Alanine aminotransferase      60 U/L     
 Aspartate transaminase      80 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient recently returned from a camping trip in Oklahoma and presents with fever, headache, and a petechial rash that involves the palms and soles. Lab findings show mild thrombocytopenia and elevated liver enzymes. These findings are consistent with Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF) which can be confirmed with serologic testing for Rickettsia rickettsii.        

RMSF is transmitted by tick bite in endemic areas. It is commonly seen in the Southeastern and South-central United States. Patients present with fever, myalgia, headache, malaise, and rash and in severe cases may have altered mental status or meningismus. The rash is the most characteristic physical finding of RMSF and typically appears two to four days after the onset of fever. It appears initially as a blanching, erythematous maculopapular rash on the extremities, often including the palms and soles, which then spreads to the trunk and becomes petechial.        

If RMSF is suspected based on history, exposure to ticks, and physical exam findings of a petechial or purpuric rash, treatment should begin promptly because there is an elevated risk of mortality with RMSF. Patients with RMSF often have abnormal laboratory findings, such as thrombocytopenia, hyponatremia, and elevated liver enzymes. The diagnosis can be confirmed with serologic testing for Rickettsia rickettsii.    

Option Analysis

❌ Serologic testing for Rickettsia akari  :
Incorrect: Rickettsia akari is a gram-negative bacterium that causes rickettsialpox. Rickettsialpox is transmitted from mice and presents as a chickenpox-like rash that can progress to an eschar. This patient’s petechial rash includes the palms and soles, and developed after travel to Oklahoma, which is instead consistent with Rocky Mountain spotted fever; serologic testing for Rickettsia rickettsii should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Serologic testing for Borrelia burgdorferi  :
Incorrect: Borrelia burgdorferi is the gram-negative spirochete that causes Lyme disease. The classic rash of Lyme disease is erythema migrans or a bull's eye rash. This patient’s petechial rash includes the palms and soles, and developed after travel to Oklahoma, which is instead consistent with Rocky Mountain spotted fever; serologic testing for Rickettsia rickettsii should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. 
✅ Serologic testing for Rickettsia rickettsii  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blood cultures :
Incorrect: Blood cultures can diagnose infections associated with other rashes like typhoid fever and Streptococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS). Patients with typhoid fever present with vomiting, diarrhea, rose spots on the trunk or abdomen, and history of recent travel to high-risk countries. Patients with SSSS present with bullae and desquamation. This patient’s petechial rash involving the palms and soles, as well as recent travel history to Oklahoma, makes Rocky Mountain spotted fever more likely. Serologic testing for Rickettsia rickettsii should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) :
Incorrect: RPR is used to screen for syphilis. Patients with secondary syphilis can present with fever and a maculopapular rash that involves the palms and soles. This occurs after the initial chancre of primary syphilis resolves in sexually active patients. This patient’s prepubertal age and recent travel to Oklahoma makes Rocky Mountain spotted fever more likely.

questions.text: A 13-month-old infant boy is brought by his parents to the emergency department for evaluation following an episode of convulsions. His parent was putting the patient to bed when he suddenly opened his eyes, arched his back, and had stiffening of all four extremities, followed by rhythmic jerking lasting for 20 seconds. He subsequently went limp and began crying softly. He was diagnosed with left acute otitis media yesterday and was started on oral amoxicillin. He otherwise has no significant medical history and does not take daily medication. He has not been left unsupervised. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 128/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 80/45 mmHg. On exam, the patient is sleeping but arousable to touch. Mucous membranes are moist. There is no meningismus or rash. He moves all extremities spontaneously. His left tympanic membrane is erythematous. Which of the following additional historical factors is most likely to be found?

choices.text: Fever at the time of the seizure

questions.solution:
This patient presents with seizure activity for the first time. When evaluating a child presenting with a first-time seizure (after initial stabilization), it is important to inquire about the presence of fever within 24 hours, as febrile seizures are more common than epilepsy, and the work-up and treatment differ between the two conditions. Febrile seizures commonly occur during acute illness in healthy children between 6 months and 5 years of age. By definition, febrile seizures are provoked by fever, and affected children have no previous history of unprovoked seizures. These children don’t require electroencephalogram (EEG), neuroimaging, or other diagnostic workups, and treatment involves supportive care and antipyretics.

Febrile seizures occur in one in every 25 otherwise healthy and typically developing children between 6 months and 5 years of age, with a recurrence risk of 25-35% with subsequent febrile illnesses. Treatment of febrile seizures includes supportive care and antipyretic administration. The use of antiepileptics has not been shown to be helpful.

A single febrile seizure that occurs within 24 hours of fever and lasts less than 5 minutes, with generalized body involvement, is referred to as a simple febrile seizure, and the child requires no further neurodiagnostic evaluation. Complex febrile seizures refer to seizures that recur within 24 hours of the initial seizure, are focal, or are prolonged in nature. Children with complex febrile seizures should have further studies performed.

Option Analysis

✅ Fever at the time of the seizure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recent vomiting:
Incorrect: An acute electrolyte derangement or hypoglycemia from vomiting could provoke a seizure. However, this patient has no other signs of dehydration and has recently been diagnosed with otitis media. The patient's seizure activity is most likely due to a febrile seizure.
❌ Family history of medication use:
Incorrect: An accidental ingestion of medication could provoke a seizure in a toddler. However, this patient has not been unsupervised, and given the recent diagnosis of otitis media, he has more likely experienced a febrile seizure.
❌ Psychosocial stressors:
Incorrect: Stress can provoke nightmares, tantrums, and psychogenic nonepileptic seizures in older children. Given this patient’s age and the recent diagnosis of otitis media, the seizure was most likely a febrile seizure.
❌ Family history of epilepsy:
Incorrect: A first-time seizure could represent a child’s first episode of genetic epilepsy; however, febrile seizures are more common and may occur within 24 hours of a fever. It is more likely that this child, who was recently diagnosed with otitis media, had a febrile seizure.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought to the primary care office for a well-child visit. He has experienced global developmental delays, and his parents are concerned he may be regressing in gross motor skills. Yesterday, he had an episode while seated in his highchair, where he dropped his head forward, bent and then extended both of his arms and legs repeatedly for a few seconds. He then cried out before becoming completely relaxed for a few seconds, and then he returned to his baseline mental status and activity level. He has no other significant medical history and has not had any recent infections. He has been in his usual state of health. Growth parameters are at the 50<sup>th</sup> percentile. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg. On exam, he can sit but does not crawl. There is no meningismus. The neck is supple. Skin exam is normal. Reflexes are normal. Which of the following is most likely to be seen with further testing?

choices.text: Reflux of barium on an upper gastrointestinal (GI) series
Point mutation in the NF1 gene

questions.solution:
This infant presents after a first-time unprovoked seizure, as evidenced by involuntary motor activity with impaired consciousness in the absence of an obvious trigger and without signs of central nervous system infection or increased intracranial pressure. Involuntary movements, in addition to developmental delay and possible regression in an infant less than 1 year old, is consistent with infantile spasms. Infantile spasms can be diagnosed with EEG findings of hypsarrhythmia.

Infantile spasms are characterized by epileptic spasms with onset in infancy or early childhood that are usually associated with the EEG pattern of hypsarrhythmia and developmental delays or regression (i.e. West Syndrome). Tuberous sclerosis complex (TЅC) is a neurocutaneous disorder that is frequently associated with infantile spasms. Urgent treatment is required in patients with infantile spasms to prevent further developmental delays and regression.

Option Analysis

✅ Hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalography (EEG):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Abnormal esophageal pH impedance monitoring:
Incorrect: Abnormal posturing, especially around mealtimes, may suggest gastroesophageal reflux (GERD), which can demonstrate an abnormal esophageal pH impedance study. However, this child’s movements, in the setting of his developmental delays and possible regression, is more concerning for infantile spasms, which can be diagnosed with the finding of hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalography.
❌ Reflux of barium on an upper gastrointestinal (GI) series:
Incorrect: Abnormal posturing, especially around mealtimes, may suggest gastroesophageal reflux (GERD), which can demonstrate reflux of barium on an upper GI series. However, this child’s movements, in the setting of developmental delays and possible motor regression, is more concerning for infantile spasms, which can be diagnosed with the finding of hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalography.
❌ Point mutation in the NF1 gene:
Incorrect: Neurofibromatosis type 1, a neurocutaneous disorder caused by mutations in the NF1 gene, can present with developmental delays and seizures, but patients also have characteristic hyperpigmented macules. This patient’s presentation, and concern for motor regression, is more consistent with infantile spasms, which can be diagnosed with the finding of hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalography.
❌ Positive urine toxicology screen:
Incorrect: Toxic ingestion is unlikely in this nonmobile child who has not been unsupervised. This child’s movements, in the setting of developmental delays and possible motor regression, is more concerning for infantile spasms, which can be diagnosed with the finding of hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalography.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician for a well-child visit. The patient has myopia but is otherwise healthy. The patient has started puberty but has not yet had menarche. She has always been small for her age; height is currently less than 3<sup>rd</sup> percentile, weight is 8<sup>th</sup> percentile, and mid-parental height is 47<sup>th</sup> percentile. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 112/73 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing. The patient’s neck is wide, and the chest is broad. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Breasts are Tanner stage 1, and pubic hair is Tanner stage 4. There is nail dysplasia and short 4<sup>th</sup> metacarpals and metatarsals. Which of the following tests would confirm the underlying cause of this patient’s short stature?

choices.text: Insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) and insulin-like growth factor binding protein 3 (IGFBP-3)
Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and free thyroxine (T4)

questions.solution:
This 13-year-old patient assigned female at birth presents to the pediatrician for a well-visit and is found to have short stature. Physical examination identifies a webbed neck, broad chest, adrenarche without thelarche, nail dysplasia, and short 4th digits. These findings are consistent with Turner syndrome. High blood pressure during the well-child visit and a history of myopia also supports this diagnosis. Turner syndrome is diagnosed by karyotype.

The first step in evaluating a patient with short stature is to identify whether the short stature is pathologic or non-pathologic. If the height velocity is normal, and there are no signs and symptoms of an underlying condition, the patient likely has non-pathologic short stature. This is confirmed with a bone age radiograph.

Lab work is typically necessary to diagnose the various pathologic causes of short stature. When weight-for-length ratio is decreased, malnutrition, chronic illness, or celiac disease may be the cause of short stature. Celiac disease is diagnosed with anti-tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A and immunoglobulin G. Chronic illness can be difficult to diagnose, but physical examination and screening labs, such as a complete blood count, complete metabolic panel, inflammatory markers, and urinalysis, can aide in making a diagnosis.

When weight-for-length ratio is normal or increased, endocrine or genetic disorders may be the cause. Endocrine disorders should be considered, including hypothyroidism and growth hormone deficiency, which can be diagnosed with thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and free thyroxine (T4) or insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) and insulin-like growth factor binding protein 3 (IGFBP-3), respectively. Idiopathic short stature is a diagnosis of exclusion; the history, physical, and laboratory studies will all be normal.

Option Analysis

✅ Karyotype:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) and insulin-like growth factor binding protein 3 (IGFBP-3):
Incorrect: IGF-1 and IGFBP-3 are growth hormones, and low levels of these hormones signify growth hormone deficiency. This patient most likely has Turner syndrome, which can be diagnosed by karyotype. Although patients with Turner syndrome often require growth hormone, they don’t usually have a true growth hormone deficiency.
❌ Bone age radiograph:
Incorrect: A bone age radiograph is used to evaluate for constitutional growth delay, which is a non-pathological cause of short stature. This patient’s physical examination findings, including a webbed neck, wide chest, and nail dysplasia, are consistent with Turner syndrome. This genetic cause of short stature can be diagnosed by karyotype.
❌ Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and free thyroxine (T4) :
Incorrect: TSH and free T4 are used to evaluate for abnormal thyroid function. Although hypothyroidism can cause short stature, this patient’s physical examination findings, including a webbed neck, wide chest, and nail dysplasia, are more consistent with Turner syndrome, which can be diagnosed by karyotype.
❌ Pelvic ultrasound :
Incorrect: This patient’s physical examination, including short stature, delay in thelarche, webbed neck, wide chest, and nail dysplasia, is concerning for Turner syndrome. In patients with Turner syndrome, a pelvic ultrasound may diagnose streak ovaries, which are associated with Turner syndrome. However, a karyotype provides definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by friends due to confusion and weakness for the past few hours. The patient was diagnosed with type 1 diabetes at the age of ten. The patient is treated with insulin through a pump. Friends report they were at the mall that afternoon and then went to see a movie. The patient has not experienced vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, trauma, or seizures. She is followed by endocrinology, and the diabetes mellitus is well-controlled. The patient’s most recent hemoglobin A1c was 6.5%. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 118/min, respiration is 20/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient is alert but disoriented. The cardiopulmonary exam reveals only tachycardia, and the abdominal exam is unremarkable. The neurological exam reveals generalized weakness with intact reflexes. Bedside blood glucose level is 25 mg/dL, and a basic metabolic panel is pending. Intravenous access is obtained. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with confusion and weakness, and she is found to have hypoglycemia with a bedside check. The patient’s diabetes is typically well-controlled by an insulin pump. Hypoglycemia is most likely due to an accidental overdose of insulin by the pump for which the patient requires immediate intravenous dextrose administration.

Hypoglycemia refers to a plasma glucose concentration less than the lower limit of normal for age, (typically less than 60 mg/dL for infants and children). Children with hypoglycemia may present with irritability, drowsiness, or confusion. Prolonged severe hypoglycemia can lead to seizures and permanent brain injury. Physical exam may be significant for diaphoresis, tachycardia, weakness, or confusion. Medication-induced hypoglycemia from insulin can occur in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus being managed with insulin. Sulfonylureas, beta-blockers, and alcohol can also cause hypoglycemia.

In the setting of a patient presenting with signs of hypoglycemia, an Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure (ABCDE) assessment should be performed. If the patient is unstable, the first step is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. Bedside glucose should be obtained followed by confirmation with a venous sample. If plasma glucose is less than 60 mg/dL in infants or children who are over 48 hours of age, hypoglycemia is confirmed. If the patient is conscious and cooperative, oral glucose can be administered; in patients with critical signs of hypoglycemia or altered consciousness, intravenous dextrose should be given immediately. Once the patient is stabilized, the focus should be on determining the cause of hypoglycemia. Monitoring neurological status is essential, as is continuous vital sign monitoring.

Option Analysis

✅ Administer intravenous dextrose:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Check serum insulin level:
Incorrect: This patient is likely hypoglycemic from an accidental insulin overdose, and serum insulin level should be checked; however, the hypoglycemia should be treated with IV dextrose before further investigations are performed.
❌ Consult pediatric endocrinology :
Incorrect: Although pediatric endocrinology may be consulted during this patient’s visit due to the accidental insulin overdose, the best next step in managing this patient’s hypoglycemia is the administration of dextrose.
❌ Check urine toxicology:
Incorrect: While urine toxicology might rule out drug use in a confused patient, this patient's current state of confusion is most likely due to hypoglycemia which should be emergently managed with intravenous dextrose.
❌ Start insulin infusion:
Incorrect: An insulin infusion is required in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). This patient has a history and findings consistent with hypoglycemia which should be treated with the administration of dextrose.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of academic difficulties. His parent notes that he has always struggled to maintain good grades, but his performance has declined significantly this year. The parent reports that he is easily distracted, unable to complete his homework on time, frequently fails to listen, and often loses personal items. Teachers have observed him fidgeting in class and inappropriately blurting out answers. When asked about his behavior, the boy says he has noticed difficulty controlling his actions. He was born prematurely at 35 weeks’ gestation but has otherwise been healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits, and the physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following additional criteria must be met for a diagnosis?

choices.text: ≥ 3 symptoms of hyperactivity and ≥ 1 symptom of inattention or impulsivity

questions.solution:
This 10-year-old boy presents with multiple symptoms of hyperactivity/impulsivity and inattention, which are strongly suggestive of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). The diagnosis of ADHD is based upon the presence of ≥ 6 symptoms from either the hyperactivity/impulsivity or impulsivity domains, with these symptoms persisting for ≥ 6 months in ≥ 2 settings. In addition, the symptoms must start before the age of 12 and be severe enough to impair academic, social, or adaptive functioning.

ADHD is a common neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by a history of excessive levels of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. As a result, children with ADHD often experience impaired social, emotional, and academic functioning, and many exhibit poor impulse control. The diagnostic criteria, as outlined in the DSM-5, are detailed above.

Option Analysis

✅ Symptoms present ≥ 6 months in ≥ 2 settings:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Symptoms present > 12 months in > 2 settings:
Incorrect: To diagnose attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), symptoms must be present for at least six months in two or more settings.
❌ ≥ 3 symptoms of hyperactivity/impulsivity or inattention:
Incorrect: At least six symptoms of hyperactivity/impulsivity and/or inattention must be present to make a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).
❌ ≥ 3 symptoms of hyperactivity and ≥ 1 symptom of inattention or impulsivity:
Incorrect: At least six symptoms of hyperactivity/impulsivity and/or inattention must be present to make a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).
❌ Symptoms present > 24 months in > 4 settings:
Incorrect: To diagnose attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), symptoms must be present for at least six months in two or more settings.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents with fever and cough for 4 days. She has a past medical history significant for recurrent episodes of pneumonia requiring several hospitalizations. Her parents report progressively worsening orthopnea requiring three pillows to sleep, along with dyspnea and cough over the past few months. They also report multiple falls over the last 6 months, and she now requires assistance with walking. She does not have associated diarrhea, vomiting, or skin rash. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 119/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 110/66 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 86% on room air. Physical examination reveals moist mucous membranes and no dysmorphic facial features or rashes. Bilateral weakness of the hip flexors is noted, and the patient is unable to walk without support. She has poor respiratory effort with decreased air entry in the right lower lobe. Cardiac and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

 Serum Chemistries
 Laboratory value Result
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 217 U/L
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 511 U/L
 Creatine kinase (CK) 750 U/L
 pH 7.36
 pCO2 50 mmHg
 pO2 58 mmHg
 HCO3 30 mEq/L
 Blood glucose 95 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This 6-year-old girl’s presentation is consistent with late-onset Pompe disease, as evidenced by her progressive muscle weakness, dyspnea, orthopnea, recurrent respiratory infections, and elevated creatine kinase (CK) and liver enzymes. The combination of her poor respiratory effort on examination, low oxygen saturation, and respiratory acidosis suggests significant respiratory muscle weakness. As a result, emergent intubation and mechanical ventilation are required to stabilize her airway and breathing.

Late-onset Pompe disease is a glycogen storage disorder (GSD) caused by a deficiency of acid alpha-glucosidase, resulting in the accumulation of glycogen primarily in muscle tissue. It typically presents after one year of age, and sometimes during adolescence, with progressive muscle weakness in a limb-girdle distribution (e.g. hip flexors), delayed gross motor development, and respiratory compromise due to diaphragmatic weakness. Laboratory studies commonly show elevations in CK and liver enzymes along with a deficiency of acid alpha glucosidase. This presentation contrasts with the more severe form of Pompe disease (the “classic infantile onset” form) which, as the name suggests, presents within the first 3 months of life and includes hypertrophic cardiomyopathy in its phenotype.

In a patient presenting with an inborn error of metabolism like Pompe disease, an ABCDE assessment should be performed. If the patient is unstable, the first step is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. In patients with signs of poor respiratory effort and low oxygen saturation, emergent intubation and mechanical ventilation is needed to maintain the airway and prevent respiratory failure. Once the patient is stabilized, continuous vital sign monitoring, supportive measures, and enzyme replacement therapy can be initiated.

Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous dextrose bolus:
Incorrect: This patient has late-onset Pompe disease and is unstable with poor respiratory effort and low oxygen saturation. Their glucose level is normal, so a dextrose bolus will not be beneficial. The immediate priority is stabilization with emergency intubation and mechanical ventilation.
✅ Emergency intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Genetics consultation:
Incorrect: Although genetic testing can aid in confirming late-onset Pompe disease, this patient is unstable with poor respiratory effort and low oxygen saturation. The immediate priority is stabilization of their airway and breathing before proceeding with any consultations.
❌ Urgent echocardiography:
Incorrect: An echocardiogram can help diagnose hypertrophic cardiomyopathy seen in classic infantile-onset Pompe disease. However, given this patient's presentation of poor respiratory effort, muscle weakness, and laboratory findings suggestive of late-onset Pompe disease, the immediate priority is stabilization of their airway and breathing.
❌ Plasma exchange:
Incorrect: Plasma exchange is a treatment option for Guillain-Barré syndrome, which classically presents with rapidly progressive muscle weakness, paresthesias, and respiratory compromise after a respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. However, this patient's more protracted course — characterized by progressively worsening weakness, dyspnea, and orthopnea, as well as elevated CK and liver enzymes — is more consistent with late-onset Pompe disease. Additionally, this patient’s respiratory compromise makes stabilization of the airway and breathing the immediate priority.

questions.text:
A 16-month-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents with global developmental delays. She was born at full term to nonconsanguineous parents and has no significant family history. Her past medical history includes bilateral conductive hearing loss and recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 99/56 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, notable facial dysmorphisms include frontal bossing, a broad-based nose, a large protruding tongue, and coarse facial features. She has a short neck with no skin rash. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. The abdomen is distended, and the liver is palpated at 2 cm below the costal margin. Both patient’s eyes have the findings seen in the image below. Which of the following best describes the fundoscopic examination findings expected in this patient?
 
Image Courtesy of Openi
questions.solution:
This 16-month-old infant has Hurler syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type I, or MPS I). She presents with developmental delay with physical examination findings of coarse facial features, hepatomegaly, and corneal clouding. Fundoscopic examination in patients with Hurler syndrome is expected to reveal retinal degeneration.

Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive glycosaminoglycan lysosomal storage disorder. It is caused by a deficiency of the alpha-L-iduronidase enzyme, which results in glycosaminoglycan accumulation in the brain, eyes, tongue, liver, spleen, heart, spine, and lungs. Symptoms usually begin between 6 and 24 months of age and include progressive intellectual disability, skeletal abnormalities, and joint stiffness.

These patients often have recurrent respiratory infections, and some develop combined conductive and sensorineural hearing loss. Physical examination reveals coarse facial features such as macroglossia and macrocephaly, with prominent frontal bones, a large protruding tongue, and depressed nasal bridge. Ocular manifestations include corneal clouding, which can lead to blindness. Retinal degeneration and optic nerve compression can occur within the first year of life.

The diagnosis of Hurler syndrome is based on clinical examination and measurement of an alpha-L-iduronidase enzyme assay. A deficiency of this enzyme confirms the diagnosis.
Corneal clouding. Image courtesy of Openi 

Option Analysis

❌ Ectopia lentis:
Incorrect: Ectopia lentis is seen in patients with homocystinuria, which presents with intellectual disability, thromboembolism, and a Marfanoid appearance on exam. The findings in this patient are more consistent with Hurler syndrome, which is associated with retinal degeneration.
❌ Optic atrophy:
Incorrect: Optic atrophy is seen in patients with Krabbe disease, which presents with feeding difficulties and seizures accompanied by rigidity, spasticity, and peripheral neuropathy on exam. The findings in this patient are more consistent with Hurler syndrome, which is associated with retinal degeneration.
✅ Retinal degeneration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Retinal cherry-red spot:
Incorrect: A retinal cherry-red spot is seen in patients with Tay-Sachs disease, which presents with a gradual loss of milestones within the first months of life, an exaggerated startle response, macrocephaly, and hypotonia. The findings in this patient are more consistent with Hurler syndrome, which is associated with retinal degeneration.
❌ Cataracts:
Incorrect: Cataracts may be seen in patients with congenital infections like rubella, which presents with microcephaly, a blueberry muffin rash, sensorineural hearing loss, and a patent ductus arteriosus. The findings in this patient are more consistent with Hurler syndrome, which is associated with retinal degeneration.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic due to feeding difficulties. His parents also report he is unable to support his head. There is no recent illness, fever, or skin rash. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 40/min, blood pressure is 94/46 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. His weight has fallen from the 25th to the 3rd percentile for age. No coarse facial features are seen on physical examination. Abdominal examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly, generalized lymphadenopathy, and spasticity. Cardiopulmonary and ophthalmologic exams are unremarkable. Laboratory studies show decreased acid sphingomyelinase activity in peripheral blood leukocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 4-month-old infant presents with feeding difficulties, failure to thrive, and developmental delay. Physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly, and laboratory studies demonstrate decreased acid sphingomyelinase activity, which confirms the diagnosis of Niemann-Pick disease.

In a patient presenting with a suspected inborn error of metabolism, the evaluation should include an assessment for progressive neurological deterioration. If present, the next step is to evaluate self-mutilating behavior and unusual odors. If both are absent, examine for organomegaly. Hepatosplenomegaly without coarse facial features, along with loss of early motor function, suggests Neimann-Pick disease. In contrast, the presence of both hepatosplenomegaly and coarse facial features, particularly when accompanied by corneal clouding, is more consistent with Hurler syndrome, whereas Hunter syndrome is not associated with corneal clouding.

Niemann-Pick disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of acid sphingomyelinase. This leads to the accumulation of sphingolipids throughout the body, resulting in tissue damage and organ dysfunction. Affected patients often present with feeding difficulties, failure to thrive, and developmental delay. Regression of developmental milestones becomes noticeable by the age of one year. Physical examination typically reveals lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and spasticity or rigidity. Laboratory investigations can include a peripheral smear and lipid profile. Confirmation of the diagnosis is achieved by measuring acid sphingomyelinase activity in leukocytes and performing genetic analysis. A decreased acid sphingomyelinase level confirms the diagnosis of Niemann-Pick disease, type A.

Option Analysis

❌ Hunter syndrome:
Incorrect: Patients with Hunter syndrome typically present with hepatosplenomegaly, coarse facial features, and a lack of corneal clouding (as compared to Hurler syndrome, which does have corneal clouding). In contrast, this patient presents with feeding difficulties, hepatosplenomegaly without coarse facial features, and decreased acid sphingomyelinase activity, making Niemann-Pick disease the most likely diagnosis.
❌ Gaucher disease:
Incorrect: Patients with Gaucher disease present with fatigue, bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, bruising, and short stature. This patient presents with hepatosplenomegaly and labs showing decreased acid sphingomyelinase activity, making Niemann-Pick disease the most likely diagnosis.
✅ Niemann-Pick disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hurler syndrome:
Incorrect: Patients with Hurler syndrome typically present with hepatosplenomegaly, coarse facial features, and corneal clouding (as compared to Hunter syndrome, which does NOT have corneal clouding). This patient, however, presents with feeding difficulties, hepatosplenomegaly without coarse facial features, and decreased acid sphingomyelinase activity, making Niemann-Pick disease the most likely diagnosis.
❌ Late-onset Pompe disease:
Incorrect: Patients with late-onset Pompe disease present after one year of age with progressive muscle weakness and delayed gross motor development. However, they do not typically have hepatosplenomegaly, making Pompe disease unlikely in this patient.

questions.text: A 13-month-old infant is rushed to the emergency department by his parents due to sudden, abnormal shaking. The parents describe these episodes as brief, symmetric contractions of the upper and lower extremities. There is no history of fever, recent illness, or neck rigidity. The patient’s older brother has autism. The patient's temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 90/46 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Skin examination with a Wood’s lamp reveals hypopigmented macules on the patient’s back. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. During the examination, the infant experiences a brief episode of jerking followed by relaxation. Laboratory studies are unremarkable. An electroencephalogram (EEG) shows hypsarrhythmia. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on ocular examination?
questions.solution:
This 13-month-old infant presents with infantile spasms, a positive family history of autism, and ash-leaf spots on skin examination; these findings are consistent with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC). Retinal hamartomas may be seen on ocular exam in patients with tuberous sclerosis.       

TSC is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder resulting from mutations in the TSC1 and TSC2 genes. Although cases of TSC can be due to de novo mutations, a positive family history can be present. Affected children often have intellectual disabilities or autism spectrum disorder (ASD), and many infants with TSC present with intractable seizures and infantile spasms.         

Patients with neurocutaneous syndromes should be evaluated based on the morphology of their skin lesions. TSC is diagnosed in a patient who exhibits characteristic ash-leaf spots (hypomelanotic macules best visualized under a Wood’s lamp) and Shagreen patches (raised lesions with an orange-peel texture, typically seen in the lumbosacral region). Some children develop facial angiofibromas on the nose and cheeks and periungual fibromas (small skin nodules under the nails). Other classic skin findings in neurocutaneous syndromes include the cafe-au-lait spots (hyperpigmented macules) seen in neurofibromatosis and the port-wine stains seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome.        

To help differentiate the etiology of neurocutaneous syndromes, both neurological and ophthalmological examinations should be performed. If retinal hamartomas are identified, a diagnosis of TSC is likely. When physical examination findings are highly suggestive of TSC, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain, along with cardiac and renal ultrasounds, should be ordered to evaluate for non-cutaneous manifestations of TSC.   


Ash-leaf spots (hypomelanotic lesions). Image courtesy of Openi. 



Shagreen patches. Image courtesy of Openi. 

Option Analysis

❌ Glaucoma  :
Incorrect: Glaucoma may be seen in patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome, which presents with a port-wine stain typically located on the upper eyelid and forehead. The skin findings described in this case are most likely ash-leaf spots, which are associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC). Retinal hamartomas are expected on ophthalmological exam with TSC. 
❌ Lisch nodules  :
Incorrect: Lisch nodules are commonly seen in patients with neurofibromatosis type I, which is characterized by multiple café-au-lait spots and axillary freckling. The skin findings described in this case are most likely ash-leaf spots, which are associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC). Retinal hamartomas are expected on ophthalmological exam with TSC. 
❌ Optic gliomas :
Incorrect: Optic gliomas can be seen in patients with neurofibromatosis type I, which is characterized by multiple café-au-lait spots and axillary freckling. The skin findings described in this case are most likely ash-leaf spots, which are associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC). Retinal hamartomas are expected on ophthalmological exam with TSC. 
❌ Oculomotor apraxia :
Incorrect: Oculomotor apraxia is seen in ataxia telangiectasis, which presents with oculocutaneous telangiectasias and telangiectasias of the nasal bridge and ears. The skin findings described in this case are most likely ash-leaf spots, which are associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC). Retinal hamartomas are expected on ophthalmological exam with TSC. 
✅ Retinal hamartomas  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after being found drowsy and unresponsive at home. Her parents noticed an empty pill bottle of her grandmother’s medication nearby. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 50/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 72/40 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. She is lethargic but arousable. Pupils are 3 mm and reactive. Breath sounds are clear, the abdomen is soft and non-tender, and there is no evidence of diaphoresis. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows sinus bradycardia with a first-degree atrioventricular (AV) block. Which of the following tests would help determine the etiology of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
This 4-year-old child presents with bradycardia, hypotension, and lethargy without signs of respiratory depression, miosis, or abdominal tenderness; this presentation raises concern for ingestion of a cardioactive medication, particularly a beta-blocker or calcium channel blocker (CCB). Since both drug classes can cause similar cardiovascular effects, measuring a serum glucose level is critical to differentiate between them. Beta-blocker toxicity often results in hypoglycemia, especially in children, due to inhibition of gluconeogenesis. Calcium channel blocker toxicity typically causes hyperglycemia, as these drugs impair insulin release from pancreatic beta cells.        

The diagnostic workup for a child with suspected medication exposure begins with a focused history and physical examination, followed by targeted laboratory and imaging studies. Initial tests should include an ECG, serum glucose, metabolic panel (CMP), venous blood gas (VBG), and toxicology screening (e.g., urine drug screen, acetaminophen, and salicylate levels). An ECG may demonstrate findings such as a widened QRS complex (seen in tricyclic antidepressant toxicity), QT prolongation (seen in selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor toxicity), and atrioventricular (AV) block (seen in beta-blocker and calcium channel blocker toxicity).        

To differentiate between tachycardia- and bradycardia-inducing ingestions, certain diagnostic markers are useful. Tachycardia with hyperpnea and tinnitus suggests salicylate toxicity, while bradycardia with hypoglycemia is more consistent with beta-blocker ingestion, and bradycardia with hyperglycemia points to calcium channel blocker toxicity.    


Option Analysis

❌ Serum lactate:
Incorrect: While an elevated lactate can indicate poor perfusion or metabolic acidosis and can be present in severe poisoning, it does not help differentiate between beta-blocker and calcium channel blocker toxicity. 
✅ Serum glucose level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Urine drug screen:
Incorrect: Routine urine drug screens do not detect beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers, making this test unhelpful in identifying the cause of this patient’s condition. 
❌ Echocardiogram:
Incorrect: An echocardiogram can show decreased cardiac function in severe beta-blocker or calcium channel blocker toxicity but does not differentiate between these agents.  
❌ Liver function testing:
Incorrect: Elevated liver enzymes are seen with hepatotoxic ingestions (e.g. acetaminophen), but they are not helpful for differentiating beta-blocker and calcium channel blocker toxicity.

questions.text: A 4-day-old girl is seen in the pediatrician’s office for poor feeding and abnormal movements over the past two days. The parents report she has been irritable with poor feeding. They have witnessed several episodes of jerky movements of the arms and legs lasting about 30 seconds and then resolving spontaneously. She was born at 38 weeks gestation via vaginal delivery. The mother reports she had vesicles in the vaginal area three weeks prior to delivery but did not receive treatment. Delivery was uncomplicated. Family and surgical histories are non-contributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 134/min, respirations are 37/min, blood pressure is 74/45 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Length is at the 25<sup>th</sup> percentile, weight is at the 30<sup>th</sup> percentile, and head circumference is at the 34<sup>th</sup> percentile. Physical exam reveals an irritable infant with a vesicular rash on the arms and the head. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are normal. During the exam, generalized tonic clonic seizures are witnessed that resolve without intervention after about 20-30 seconds. The patient is admitted to the hospital. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) shows edema and encephalitis. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This newborn with poor feeding, tonic clonic seizures, a vesicular rash on physical examination, and brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showing encephalitis likely has congenital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. The patient's mother reports having vaginal vesicles a few weeks prior to the delivery. If left untreated, neonatal HSV infection has high morbidity and mortality. Urgent treatment with intravenous acyclovir is necessary when the disease is suspected.

Neonates most often acquire HSV infection while passing through an infected vaginal canal during birth or from the virus ascending after rupture of membranes in mothers with a history of active genital lesions. Infants with congenital HSV infection typically present in the first 6 weeks after birth. Early signs may include irritability, poor feeding, lethargy, vesicular rash, fever, temperature instability, and seizures. The manifestations of neonatal herpes can be classified based on the primary involvement:
  •   Primarily skin, eyes, and mucosal involvement (SEM disease)
  •   Primarily CNS disease
  •   Disseminated disease with multiple organ involvement including the liver, lungs, and encephalitis. 

In infants with suspected congenital infections, an ABCDE assessment should be performed. If the patient is unstable, the first step is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. Once the patient is stabilized, continuous vital sign monitoring and oxygen as needed are the next steps in management. In patients with signs of congenital HSV infection, as in this patient, the diagnosis can be confirmed by ordering HSV polymerase chain reaction (PCR) on the blood and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Swab specimens should be collected from the conjunctivae, mouth, nasopharynx, rectum, and skin lesions. Brain MRI may demonstrate edema and parenchymal changes consistent with encephalitis.

Treatment with intravenous acyclovir can be started if congenital HSV is suspected while results are pending as it improves mortality for all infants with neonatal herpes and neurologic development in those who have SEM and disseminated disease.
   
Edema in the frontal lobe white matter due to acute HSV-2 by Moore et al. Image reused with permission. Reproduced from: Statdx 

Option Analysis

❌ Intubation:
Incorrect: Intubation is required in unstable infants with tachypnea, respiratory distress, and low oxygen saturation, which are not noted in this infant.
❌ Echocardiogram:
Incorrect: Echocardiogram can help confirm the diagnosis of congenital rubella infection when a heart murmur, cataracts, sensorineural hearing loss, and diffuse, non-blanching, purplish-blue macules or papules (also referred to as “blueberry muffin” rash) are present. The findings in this patient are consistent with congenital herpes infection, and echocardiogram is not necessary at this time.
✅ Intravenous acyclovir:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intravenous penicillin:
Incorrect: Intravenous penicillin is the appropriate treatment for congenital syphilis, which presents with a desquamative maculopapular rash on the palms and soles. The findings in this patient are consistent with congenital herpes infection, and acyclovir is the appropriate treatment.
❌ Antiepileptic medication:
Incorrect: While this infant is experiencing seizures, these are secondary to herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis. Antiepileptic drugs would control the seizures temporarily but would not treat the underlying viral infection, which requires urgent antiviral therapy with intravenous acyclovir to prevent further neurological damage.

questions.text: A male infant delivered at 39 weeks via vaginal delivery is evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) for microcephaly and a rash. The pregnancy was uncomplicated. There was no use of recreational substances by the mother and no exposure to pets. Membranes ruptured spontaneously 6 hours prior to delivery, and delivery was uncomplicated. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at one and five minutes, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 32/min, blood pressure is 67/38 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Weight is at the 5<sup>th</sup> percentile, body length is at the 10<sup>th</sup> percentile, and head circumference is at the 3<sup>rd</sup> percentile. On physical examination, there is a generalized blueish petechial rash on the face and extremities. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are normal. Fundoscopic exam reveals chorioretinitis. Brain imaging shows periventricular calcifications and ventriculomegaly. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Nucleic acid amplification (NAAT) for Zika virus
Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) of the blood

questions.solution:
This newborn is small for gestational age and presents with microcephaly, a purplish-blue rash (“blueberry muffin rash”), and chorioretinitis. Brain imaging shows periventricular calcifications and ventriculomegaly. Congenital cytomegalovirus infection (CMV) is the most likely diagnosis. Positive urine or salivary polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for CMV is diagnostic for congenital CMV.

Congenital CMV is the most common congenital infection. It can be acquired through vertical transmission in utero, but infection can also be acquired at the time of birth. Maternal history may reveal a mild flu-like illness during pregnancy, and the neonatal history often reveals that the infant is premature or small for gestational age, as in this case. Newborns are usually asymptomatic at birth, though they may develop seizures and developmental delay later. Physical exam findings may reveal a purplish-blue (“blueberry muffin”) rash and microcephaly, and fundoscopy may show chorioretinitis and retinal hemorrhage. Sensorineural hearing loss is commonly detected on hearing screens.

A complete blood count, urine or salivary PCR, and possible viral cultures from blood or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) should be obtained when congenital CMV is suspected. Typical laboratory abnormalities include elevated liver transaminase levels, direct hyperbilirubinemia, and thrombocytopenia. Positive PCR testing or cultures with brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) findings of periventricular calcifications or cysts and ventriculomegaly will confirm the diagnosis of congenital CMV infection.
   
Head ultrasound parenchymal calcifications with congenital CMV infections. Reproduced from: Statdx

Option Analysis

✅ Cytomegalovirus (CMV) urine polymerase chase reaction (PCR):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nucleic acid amplification (NAAT) for Zika virus:
Incorrect: Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) is used to confirm congenital Zika virus infections, which typically present in newborns with microcephaly, hypertonia, clubfoot, and macular scarring or chorioretinal atrophy on fundoscopic exam. However, the findings in this patient are more consistent with congenital CMV infection.
❌ Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) of the blood:
Incorrect: RPR is used to diagnose syphilis, which can cause a desquamating rash on the palms and soles, hepatomegaly, and skeletal abnormalities in congenital cases. However, this infant's findings of microcephaly, chorioretinitis, and periventricular calcifications on brain imaging are more consistent with congenital CMV infection.
❌ Rubella IgM titer:
Incorrect: Rubella IgM titer can confirm the diagnosis of congenital rubella infection, which typically presents in newborns with a heart murmur, rash, and cataracts. This patient’s presentation is instead consistent with congenital CMV infection, which can be confirmed by urine PCR.
❌ Viral culture of the mouth:
Incorrect: Viral culture of the mouth is commonly used to confirm congenital herpes simplex virus infection. This patient’s presentation is consistent with congenital CMV infection, which can be confirmed with urine PCR.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy with a recent diagnosis of a craniopharyngioma is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to altered mental status. The parents report that he has had increased urination and excessive thirst for the past six days. He has had no vomiting or diarrhea. On arrival, his temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears confused, does not know his age, and does not recognize his parents. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals a regular heart rate with no murmurs or gallops. Capillary refill is 3 seconds, and mucous membranes are moist. Lungs are clear bilaterally. The abdomen is soft and non-tender with no organomegaly. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to determine the cause of hyponatremia in this patient?  

 Laboratory value Results
 Sodium 126 mEq/L
 Potassium 3.2 mEq/L
 Glucose 95 mg/dL
 BUN 10 mg/dL
 Creatinine 0.4 mg/dL
 Urine protein Negative
 Urine glucose Negative
 Plasma osmolality 272 mOsm/kg
questions.solution:
This patient has a craniopharyngioma and presents with confusion, polyuria, and polydipsia. This history, along with the euvolemic volume status and labs showing hyponatremia and plasma osmolality <280 mOsm/kg, make syndrome of inappropriate ADH (SIADH) the most likely cause of hyponatremia. The best next step to confirm the diagnosis is to obtain urine sodium and osmolality.  

In patients with hyponatremia and plasma osmolality <280 mOSm/kg, the next step is to evaluate the volume status. In patients with euvolemic hyponatremia, the physical exam usually reveals a normal heart rate with no orthostatic drop in blood pressure. Mucous membranes will be moist with normal skin turgor, and there will be no signs of hypervolemia, such as ascites and lower extremity edema. Euvolemic hyponatremia can be seen in hypothyroidism, glucocorticoid deficiency, SIADH secretion, and water toxicity.

To help differentiate the causes of euvolemic hyponatremia, urine sodium and random urine osmolality should be checked. If urine sodium is >20 mmol/L and random urine osmolality is >100 mOsm/kg, then TSH, free T4, morning cortisol, and an adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) stimulation test should be checked to determine the etiology. If the TSH is elevated and the free T4 is low, hypothyroidism can be diagnosed. If the morning cortisol is low and the ACTH stimulation test demonstrates a decreased or absent cortisol response, this suggests glucocorticoid deficiency. If the TSH, free T4, cortisol, and ACTH stimulation tests are all normal, a diagnosis of SIADH can be made. SIADH can occur in patients with certain tumors and with lung or central nervous system (CNS) infections or due to chemotherapy medications. In contrast, if urine sodium is <20 mmol/L and random urine osmolality is <100 mOsm/kg, consider excessive free water intake.

Option Analysis

❌ Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) stimulation test:
Incorrect: Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) stimulation testing can confirm glucocorticoid deficiency, which presents with hyponatremia and decreased or absent cortisol response to ACTH stimulation. This patient has euvolemic hyponatremia; the best next step is obtaining urine sodium and osmolality prior to an ACTH stimulation test to help rule out water intoxication.
❌ Serum and urine protein levels:
Incorrect: Proteinuria, along with hypoalbuminemia, can confirm the diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome, which can lead to hypervolemic hyponatremia. However, this patient does not have hypertension, orthopnea, edema, or proteinuria, making nephrotic syndrome a less likely cause of hyponatremia.
❌ Serum triglycerides levels:
Incorrect: Elevated serum triglycerides can confirm the diagnosis of pseudohyponatremia, which presents with hyponatremia and plasma osmolality >280 mOsm/kg. The findings of craniopharyngioma, polyuria, and polydipsia with hyponatremia and plasma osmolality of <280 mOsm/kg are more consistent with euvolemic hyponatremia secondary to syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH).
❌ Thyroid profile:
Incorrect: Elevated thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and low free T4 can confirm hypothyroidism. However, this patient has euvolemic hyponatremia; the best next step is obtaining urine sodium and osmolality before thyroid profile.
✅ Urine sodium and osmolality:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department with fevers, diarrhea, vomiting, and decreased oral intake for three days. He has been less playful and has had fewer wet diapers than usual. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 133/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 88/52 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient looks sick with sunken eyes. Mucous membranes are dry, and capillary refill is 4 seconds. The patient is tachycardic but has no murmur or gallops. Chest and abdominal exams are normal. Initial lab work is shown below. Which of the following additional lab results would confirm the most likely cause of hyponatremia in this patient?

 Laboratory value Results
 pH 7.27
 pCO2 45 mmHg
 HCO3- 17 mEq/L
 Base deficit -5
 Serum sodium 126 mEq/L
 Random blood glucose 92 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient is brought to the emergency department for vomiting and diarrhea. Physical exam is significant for tachycardia, hypotension, sunken eyes, dry mucous membranes, and delayed capillary refill. These findings, along with laboratory results showing metabolic acidosis and hyponatremia, are consistent with hypovolemic hyponatremia. Urinary sodium can help determine the cause of hypovolemic hyponatremia. Urine sodium levels <20 mmol/L suggest an extra-renal cause of hyponatremia, such as viral gastroenteritis in this case.  

Hypovolemic hyponatremia is usually caused by a combination of sodium loss and water retention to compensate for the volume depletion. Physical exam findings often include tachycardia and an orthostatic drop in blood pressure, sunken eyes, dry mucous membranes, and decreased skin turgor.

When evaluating hyponatremia in a patient, it is important to order a plasma osmolality. If it is >280 mOsm/kg, consider pseudohyponatremia or hyperosmolality; but if it is <280 mOsm/kg, diagnose hyponatremia and assess volume status to determine if the patient is hypovolemic, euvolemic, or hypervolemic. In the setting of hypovolemic hyponatremia, the history and urine sodium will help determine the etiology.

Urine sodium level <20 mmol/L suggests extrarenal causes of sodium loss. If the patient has a history of vomiting and diarrhea, such as in this case, the underlying cause of hyponatremia is likely gastrointestinal loss of sodium. Extensive burns or excessive sweating increases insensible fluid losses and can also cause hypovolemic hyponatremia. Also, children with cystic fibrosis are susceptible to hyponatremia due to sodium loss through sweat. Pancreatitis, small bowel obstruction, or a severe allergic reaction may lead to accumulation of extracellular fluid within extravascular spaces, resulting in hypovolemic hyponatremia. Inappropriately high urine sodium >20 mmol/L suggests a renal cause of hypovolemic hyponatremia, such as salt-wasting, which can be seen in renal dysplasia, proximal tubule dysfunction, or diuretic use.

Option Analysis

❌ Serum potassium of 5.4 mEq/L:
Incorrect: Hyperkalemia is seen in patients with mineralocorticoid deficiency, which presents with hypotension, hyponatremia, and urine sodium >20 mmol/L. The patient’s presentation of vomiting, diarrhea with tachycardia, sunken eyes, and dry mucous membranes is more consistent with hypovolemic hyponatremia secondary to viral gastroenteritis.
❌ Serum osmolality of 350 mOsm/kg:
Incorrect: Serum osmolality >295 mOsm/kg suggests hyponatremia secondary to hyperglycemia. The patient in this case has vomiting, diarrhea, decreased oral intake, and decreased urine output with a normal blood glucose level, making hyperglycemia unlikely.
✅ Urine sodium of 10 mEq/L:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Urine osmolality of 500 mOsm/kg:
Incorrect: Urine osmolality helps determine the etiology of euvolemic hyponatremia. Urine osmolality >200 mOsm/kg indicates hypothyroidism, glucocorticoid deficiency, or syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion. However, this patient’s presentation of vomiting, diarrhea, tachycardia, sunken eyes, and dry mucous membranes is more consistent with hypovolemic hyponatremia. Low urine sodium would be consistent with extrarenal losses of sodium that can be seen with vomiting and diarrhea from gastroenteritis.
❌ Urine sodium of 27 mmol/L:
Incorrect: Urine sodium >20 mmol/L suggests renal causes of hypovolemic hyponatremia, such as diuretics use, renal tubular acidosis, and obstructive uropathy. This patient's history and physical examination are more consistent with gastroenteritis as the cause of hyponatremia, and therefore, urine sodium would be expected to be less than 20 mmol/L.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of a “lazy eye.” Teachers have noticed the patient squinting at the blackboard for several weeks, and the child’s caregiver notes that the left eye now appears to be “looking inward” over the past several days. The patient is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals the finding shown in the image below. The patient’s red reflexes are intact bilaterally. Visual acuity is 20/20 OD (right eye) and 20/40 OS (left eye). Corneal light reflection and a cover-uncover test demonstrate persistent ocular misalignment, and there is persistent deviation regardless of gaze direction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia (CC by 3.0)
questions.solution:
This 6-year-old patient presents with findings concerning for amblyopia. Examination reveals eye deviation on gross examination with persistent ocular misalignment on corneal light reflection and cover-uncover tests. Additionally, there is consistent deviation regardless of gaze direction, which is consistent with a comitant tropia. The inward deviation of the eye indicates esotropia.        

Patients with true strabismic amblyopia have visible eye deviation on gross examination, whereas deprivation and refractive amblyopia do not. A complete eye examination with fundoscopy can identify a significant refractive error (refractive amblyopia) or reveal a visual obstruction (deprivation amblyopia).       

When strabismic amblyopia is suspected, corneal light reflection and cover-uncover testing should be performed. Ocular misalignment confirms true strabismus and warrants assessment of its consistency. If the deviation remains the same in all gaze directions, it is a comitant tropia and is classified by the direction of the deviation: inward deviation indicates esotropia, while outward deviation indicates exotropia. If the deviation varies with gaze direction, it indicates noncomitant tropia, for which the differential diagnosis includes CN III, CN IV, or CN VI palsy, which are distinguished by their characteristic patterns in gaze deviation.    

Option Analysis

❌ Pseudostrabismus:
Incorrect: Pseudostrabismus produces a false appearance of eye misalignment because of certain anatomic facial features. Both the corneal light reflection and cover-uncover tests would be normal.  
✅ Esotropia :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Exotropia :
Incorrect: Exotropia refers to an outward deviation of the eye rather than the inward deviation seen here.  
❌ Cranial nerve (CN) VI palsy:
Incorrect: Abducens nerve (CN VI) palsy can result in the appearance of esotropia; however, the ocular deviation associated with a pure CN VI palsy will vary with gaze direction.  
❌ Cranial nerve (CN) IV palsy:
Incorrect: Trochlear nerve (CN IV) palsy produces a vertical, upward ocular misalignment (hypertropia) that will vary with gaze direction.

questions.text:
A 4-hour-old infant, delivered by vaginal delivery at 37 weeks’ gestation, is evaluated in the newborn nursery for atypical genitalia. The pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. There is no family history of consanguinity. The mother did not show signs of virilization prenatally and took only regular prenatal vitamins during the pregnancy. Family and surgical history are non-contributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 150/min, respirations are 30/min, blood pressure is 64/36 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical exam, there is a right-sided inguinal hernia, and the genitalia appear as shown below. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are unremarkable. 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP) is elevated before and after the adrenocorticotrophin (ACTH) stimulation test. Laboratory results one week after birth are shown below. A karyotype is confirmed as 46,XX. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

 Laboratory value      Results     
 Sodium      133 mEq/L    
 Potassium      6.5 mEq/L     
 Chloride      103 mEq/L     
 Bicarbonate      17 mEq/L    
 Glucose      50 mg/dL    


“Ambiguous genitalia” by Tantbirojn et al. Licensed under CC BY 2.0.  Reproduced from Wikimedia
questions.solution:
This newborn has atypical genitalia and a right-sided inguinal hernia. Labs show elevated 17- hydroxyprogesterone (OHP), hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia, along with a 46,XX karyotype. These findings are consistent with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH).         

Atypical genitalia refers to external genitalia that are not phenotypically male or female. Examples include cryptorchidism, hypospadias with micropenis, or bifid scrotum in karyotypic males or clitoromegaly, posterior labial fusion, single genitourinary opening, or inguinal hernia in karyotypic females. The appearance of the external genitalia is not diagnostic of a particular disorder and often does not distinguish among the various disorders of sex development (DSD).        

A karyotype should be ordered during the initial diagnostic workup. The most common cause of 46,XX DSD is CAH. This is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by impaired steroidogenesis in the adrenal glands, leading to androgen excess. 21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common cause. Classic CAH typically presents with virilization of female external genitalia at birth and normal genitalia in karyotypic males. Elevated 17-OHP and a positive ACTH stimulation test are suggestive of CAH. Additional lab findings that support a diagnosis of classic CAH include elevated plasma renin activity, hyperkalemia, and hyponatremia. An abdominal ultrasound may reveal enlarged adrenal glands.   

Option Analysis

✅ Congenital adrenal hyperplasia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Gonadal dysgenesis  :
Incorrect: Patients with gonadal dysgenesis can present with atypical genitalia, a 46,XY karyotype, elevated gonadotropins, and low testosterone levels. However, this patient has a 46,XX karyotype, elevated gonadotropins, elevated testosterone, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia, which are more consistent with congenital adrenal hyperplasia.  
❌ Maternal androgen-producing tumor  :
Incorrect: Karyotypic females born to mothers with androgen-producing tumors, such as luteomas, may have atypical genitalia, and the mothers usually develop virilization. However, maternal virilization was not present in this vignette. This patient has a 46,XX karyotype, elevated gonadotropins, elevated testosterone, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia, making congenital adrenal hyperplasia the most likely diagnosis.
❌ Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome  :
Incorrect: Patients with partial androgen insensitivity syndrome may have atypical genitalia with a 46,XY karyotype, along with normal gonadotropins and testosterone. This patient has a 46,XX karyotype, elevated gonadotropins, elevated testosterone, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia, making congenital adrenal hyperplasia the most likely diagnosis. 
❌ Placental aromatase deficiency  :
Incorrect: Karyotypic females with placental aromatase deficiency are born with atypical genitalia, and the mothers usually develop virilization. In this case, maternal virilization is not present. This patient has a 46,XX karyotype, elevated gonadotropins, elevated testosterone, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia, making congenital adrenal hyperplasia the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy presents to the clinic for evaluation of a newly noted squint. There is no history of pet exposure, fever, rash, seizures, trauma, or recent illness. The child was born at term, and prenatal history is unremarkable. Past medical and surgical histories are non-contributory. Family history is notable for osteosarcoma in the father. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 132/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 90/46 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. Physical examination is notable for strabismus.
