No dysmorphic features are seen. Direct ophthalmoscopy reveals a white pupil on the right and a normal red reflex on the left. A whitish-gray retinal mass is seen on fundoscopic exam. Which of the following would confirm this patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This infant with strabismus, unilateral leukocoria, an intraocular mass on examination, no history of pet exposure, and a family history of osteosarcoma most likely has retinoblastoma. Orbital magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can confirm the diagnosis.

In a pediatric patient presenting with leukocoria, the first step is to determine whether an intraocular mass is present. If so, inquire about exposure to cat or dog feces and a history of geophagia (eating dirt), since these factors increase the risk of toxocariasis and ocular larva migrans. When those risk factors are absent, retinoblastoma should be strongly considered.

Retinoblastoma is the most common ocular tumor in children and typically presents with leukocoria in a child under three years of age. History may reveal strabismus or visual changes. A family history of retinoblastoma or related tumors such as osteosarcoma reflects a germline RB1 gene mutation. Clinical findings may include one or more creamy or whitish-gray retinal masses, orbital inflammation, blood in the anterior chamber (hyphema), retinal detachment, or vitreous inflammation. Once suspected, orbital ultrasound or MRI confirms the diagnosis by demonstrating an intraocular mass with calcifications and assessing for optic nerve involvement or extraocular spread.

Option Analysis

❌ Slit-lamp examination  :
Incorrect: A slit-lamp evaluates anterior eye structures, including the cornea and lens, and is commonly used to diagnose cataracts, keratitis, and uveitis. Without specialized lenses, it is less effective for assessing the posterior segment. In suspected retinoblastoma, cross-sectional imaging (e.g. MRI) provides a more reliable evaluation.
❌ ELISA test for Toxocara canis:
Incorrect: Toxocara canis causes ocular larva migrans (OLM), which can present with an intraocular mass in patients with exposure to dog feces. In this case, however, an intraocular mass coupled with a positive family history and no pet exposure makes retinoblastoma far more likely. Orbital MRI is recommended to confirm the diagnosis.
❌ Karyotype:
Incorrect: Standard karyotyping can identify chromosomal aneuploidies (e.g., trisomy 21, trisomy 18), which can be associated with cataracts. However, an intraocular mass coupled with a family history of osteosarcoma are concerning for retinoblastoma. Potential point mutations or small deletions in the RB1 gene would not be detected on karyotyping.
✅ Orbital magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rubella IgG antibodies:
Incorrect: Congenital rubella infection can lead to cataracts, which are lens opacities rather than an intraocular mass. The history and findings in this case are more consistent with retinoblastoma, which is best evaluated by orbital MRI.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a 4-week history of intermittent abdominal pain localized to the epigastric region. The pain is described as a burning sensation that worsens at night and is partially relieved by eating. The parents note that the child has been less active recently and has occasionally experienced nausea but without vomiting or weight loss. The parents also mention that the child has experienced growing pains over the past several months. Vitals are within normal limits. On examination, the patient appears pale, and abdominal palpation reveals mild tenderness in the epigastric region without rebound or guarding. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Considering the most likely diagnosis, which of the following additional features is most likely to be present in this patient’s history?

choices.text: Frequent antibiotic use for recurrent ear infections

questions.solution:
This child’s symptoms are consistent with peptic ulcer disease (PUD), including epigastric pain that worsens at night and improves with food. This patient also has ongoing growing pains. Frequent use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) is a common cause of gastric mucosal injury and PUD.

In a pediatric patient with PUD, the history often includes chronic or intermittent epigastric pain described as burning, gnawing, or cramping in nature, worsening at night or between meals and relief after eating. Nausea, early satiety, bloating, or less commonly, vomiting, may also be reported. A history of gastrointestinal bleeding, such as hematemesis (vomiting blood) or melena (black, tarry stools), indicates a more severe presentation. Risk factors include regular use of NSAIDs or corticosteroids, severe physiologic stress (e.g., burns, severe trauma), a family history of PUD, or Helicobacter pylori infection. On physical examination, findings may include epigastric tenderness without rebound or guarding and pallor if there is significant anemia due to blood loss.

Option Analysis

❌ Frequent antibiotic use for recurrent ear infections:
Incorrect: While frequent antibiotic use may lead to gastrointestinal disturbances such as diarrhea, it is not associated with the development of peptic ulcer disease (PUD).
✅ Daily nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recent streptococcal throat infection:
Incorrect: Streptococcal infections do not contribute to the development of peptic ulcer disease (PUD). This history would be relevant if the patient presented with symptoms of acute rheumatic fever or post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.
❌ Consumption of a high-fat diet:
Incorrect: A high-fat diet may exacerbate symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) but does not cause peptic ulcer disease (PUD). This history would be pertinent in a child with regurgitation or heartburn suggestive of GERD.
❌ History of food allergies:
Incorrect: Food allergies typically cause acute or recurrent symptoms like vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain associated with specific dietary triggers, not chronic epigastric pain. This history would be relevant in a child with suspected eosinophilic esophagitis, food protein-induced enterocolitis syndrome, or an IgE-mediated food allergy.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right lower leg pain. The patient was pole-vaulting and fell awkwardly on the right leg. The patient heard a “pop” and experienced immediate, severe pain. Parents report that the child is otherwise healthy and does not take any daily medication. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 120/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient appears to be in severe pain. Examination of the right lower extremity reveals an obvious deformity with bone protruding through the anterior shin. Dorsalis pedis pulse is 2+, sensation is intact, and the child can move all toes. Intravenous access is established, and fentanyl is administered for pain. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Radiographs of the tibia and fibula

questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents with a complete open fracture, likely of the tibia and fibula. Open fractures require immediate administration of intravenous antibiotics, copious wound irrigation, appropriate analgesia, and emergent orthopedic consultation to reduce the risk of infection and ensure timely surgical management.       

Pediatric musculoskeletal injuries encompass a wide range of conditions involving bones, joints, connective tissue, and muscles. While most injuries are related to low-energy trauma like falls or sports, severe injuries can result from high-energy trauma like motor vehicle accidents. Common pediatric musculoskeletal injuries include fractures, sprains, joint dislocations or subluxations, and overuse injuries.         

Initial management should include an Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure (ABCDE) assessment, along with evaluation of joint stability and neurovascular status. Although most pediatric musculoskeletal injury patients are stable, certain injuries (e.g., pelvic, hip, and proximal femur fractures) can cause significant hemorrhage, requiring urgent surgical intervention. Other orthopedic emergencies include open fractures and injuries associated with nerve or vascular compromise.    

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous cefazolin:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Radiographs of the tibia and fibula:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of an open fracture of the lower extremity. While a radiograph is indicated to confirm the underlying diagnosis, antibiotic administration should not be delayed, as early antibiotics reduce the risk of infection.  
❌ Traction splint:
Incorrect: A traction splint is often utilized for femur fractures but is not appropriate for tibial or fibular fractures. Since this patient has an open fracture, initial management should focus on infection prevention. 
❌ Short leg splint:
Incorrect: A short leg splint is an appropriate method of immobilization for tibial fractures. However, before reduction and splint placement, the patient requires copious wound irrigation and intravenous antibiotic administration. 
❌ Bedside reduction of the fracture:
Incorrect: This patient has an open fracture that requires operative reduction in a controlled, sterile environment such as an operating room. Copious wound irrigation and intravenous antibiotic administration should be performed prior to further management.

questions.text: A 36-hour-old infant delivered at 38 weeks' gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery is evaluated in the nursery for poor feeding, lethargy, and non-bloody, non-bilious emesis. Pregnancy and delivery were uneventful. The mother is group B Streptococcus negative. The infant is formula-fed. There is no temperature instability or rash. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 41/min, blood pressure is 70/42 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination reveals lethargy, jaundice, and hepatomegaly. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. A complete blood count and urinalysis are normal, but transaminases are elevated. Bedside serum glucose level is 36 mg/dL. Blood and urine cultures and an ammonia level are pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This early onset of symptoms in a newborn without clear signs of infection, such as risk factors or temperature instability, raises suspicion for an inborn error of metabolism (IEM). Hypoglycemia, a common complication of IEMs, should be treated with intravenous dextrose.

Inborn errors of metabolism (IEMs) can cause lethargy, poor feeding, vomiting, and neurological decline in neonates. Affected infants often appear septic but lack fever, signs of infection, trauma, or congenital anomalies. History may reveal a positive newborn screen, a sibling with similar symptoms or unexplained death, or a family history of metabolic disease. Exam findings may include altered mental status, apnea or tachypnea, and hepatosplenomegaly.

Initial evaluation begins with an ABCDE assessment to determine clinical stability. Airway, breathing, and circulation should be stabilized first. Intravenous (IV) access should be obtained, and IV fluids initiated, if needed. Continuous vital sign monitoring and supplemental oxygen may be necessary. Because IEMs can mimic sepsis, empiric antibiotics should be considered. Prompt correction of hypoglycemia is essential.

Once stabilized, further evaluation includes a focused history and physical, arterial blood gas, complete blood count, metabolic panel, and urinalysis. Based on initial findings, additional tests such as serum ammonia and lactate can help identify specific metabolic disorders, including urea cycle or glycogen storage diseases.

Option Analysis

❌ Intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Incorrect: This newborn presents with signs suggestive of an inborn error of metabolism. There is no evidence of respiratory distress or failure requiring intubation. However, the patient is hypoglycemic and requires supplemental glucose.
❌ Abdominal ultrasonography:
Incorrect: Abdominal ultrasonography is used to evaluate bilious emesis or signs of obstruction. This newborn presents with non-bilious emesis and symptoms suggestive of an inborn error of metabolism. The patient’s glucose is 36 mg/dL and supplemental glucose is necessary.
✅ Intravenous dextrose:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intravenous saline bolus:
Incorrect: A saline bolus is indicated for hypotension or shock; however, this patient's blood pressure is within the normal range for age. The findings in this case are suggestive of an inborn error of metabolism, and the patient’s hypoglycemia requires treatment.
❌ Intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin:
Incorrect: Intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin are given to infants less than one month old when there is concern for sepsis or meningitis. This infant is afebrile and with a flat fontanelle. The findings in this case are most consistent with an inborn error of metabolism, and the patient’s hypoglycemia requires treatment.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status. Caregivers report that the child underwent a tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy yesterday. Postoperatively, there has been vomiting and minimal oral intake. There have been four minimally wet diapers and no stools in the past 24 hours. The child has a history of gross developmental delay, hypotonia, and poor weight gain. Height is at the 9th percentile and weight is at the 3rd percentile. Blood pressure is 88/42 mmHg, pulse is 140/min, respiratory rate is 38/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On examination, the child appears lethargic and is moaning while lying in a caregiver’s arms. Mucous membranes are dry, and capillary refill is 3 seconds. The posterior pharynx shows recent cauterization without active bleeding. No cardiac murmur is appreciated. The abdomen is soft and mildly tender to palpation, without rebound or guarding. Bowel sounds are diminished. Glasgow coma scale (GCS) score is 12. The child opens his eyes to verbal stimuli and withdraws to touch. Laboratory evaluation reveals an ammonia level of 100 µg/dL. Which of the following is most likely to be found on further questioning?
questions.solution:
This 2-year-old boy presents with altered mental status following repeated vomiting and decreased oral intake after a recent surgery. Medical history includes developmental delay, hypotonia, and poor weight gain. Physical examination is notable for tachycardia, tachypnea, lethargy, and a GCS score of 12. Laboratory testing reveals hyperammonemia. Taken together, these findings are consistent with an inborn error of metabolism (IEM), and a history of an abnormal newborn screen would be expected.       

The differential diagnosis for altered mental status in the pediatric population is broad and includes toxic ingestion, head trauma or intracranial lesion, infections, seizures, and metabolic disturbances. Because pediatric patients are often unable to provide a reliable history, input from caregivers is essential in establishing the history of present illness. Symptoms of altered mental status may include changes in consciousness, confusion, altered mood or behavior, or inconsolability. More severe cases can present with lethargy or coma.        

When evaluating a child with altered mental status, it is important to ask about potential exposures to medications, recreational substances, or household toxins. Head trauma should be considered, and associated signs such as periorbital ecchymosis or hemotympanum should be assessed. Fever, headache, photophobia, neck stiffness, and positive Kernig or Brudzinski signs raise concern for central nervous system infection. A postictal state or Todd paresis suggests recent seizure activity. In a patient with a suspected IEM, an abnormal newborn screen would be expected. Metabolic crises in these disorders are often triggered by physiologic stressors such as surgery or infection.       

Option Analysis

✅ History of abnormal newborn screen:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Fever:
Incorrect: Fever is a common finding in patients with an infectious process. However, this patient’s altered mental status in the setting of growth and developmental delays, poor oral intake, and elevated ammonia is most consistent with an inborn error of metabolism. 
❌ Recent head injury:
Incorrect: Head injuries can cause intracranial trauma and subsequent altered mental status. However, this patient’s altered mental status in the setting of growth and developmental delays, poor oral intake, and elevated ammonia is most consistent with an inborn error of metabolism. 
❌ Family member with gastroenteritis:
Incorrect: While gastroenteritis may lead to vomiting and dehydration, it would not explain this child's chronic hypotonia, growth delay, and elevated ammonia. These findings point to a likely inborn error of metabolism. 
❌ Unilateral weakness:
Incorrect: There are numerous causes of unilateral weakness, including Todd paresis following a seizure. However, this patient presents with hypotonia, growth and developmental delays, and an elevated ammonia level suggestive of an inborn error of metabolism (IEM). Although seizures and Todd paresis can occur in patients with an IEM, it is more likely that this patient had an abnormal newborn screen.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status in the setting of persistent non-bloody, nonbilious emesis for 48 hours. A caregiver reports the child has not been able to keep any food down and is only tolerating tiny amounts of water. The child has urinated once in the last 10 hours. There have been a few episodes of non-bloody diarrhea. There is no recent travel or known sick contacts. Weight is at the 15th percentile, and height is at the 30th percentile. Temperature is 101°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 96/57 mmHg, pulse is 135/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the child appears lethargic and is unable to answer questions appropriately. She is disoriented to place. Mucous membranes are dry, and capillary refill is 3 seconds. A soft flow murmur is noted. The abdomen is soft and mildly tender to palpation without rebound or guarding. Glasgow coma scale (GCS) is 12. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 7-year-old girl presents with lethargy and confusion following 48 hours of persistent vomiting. The patient appears dehydrated with an abnormal GCS score. The clinical picture is most consistent with viral gastroenteritis, and the most appropriate next step in management is obtaining a bedside glucose level, as hypoglycemia is a common and readily reversible cause of altered mental status.        

After initial stabilization, the first diagnostic priority in evaluating altered mental status is always to check a bedside glucose level to assess for hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia. If glucose is normal, possible ingestion of medications or toxins should be considered. In such cases, urine and serum toxicology screening may be warranted. If there is concern for an intracranial process, computed tomography (CT) of the head is the preferred initial imaging modality.       

Infectious etiologies, including central nervous system or systemic infections, should also be considered. Evaluation may include a chest radiograph and urine, blood, and cerebrospinal fluid studies and cultures. Further testing may include arterial blood gas analysis, electroencephalogram (EEG), or serum ammonia and a comprehensive metabolic panel, depending on the suspected cause, such as hypoxemia, hypoventilation, seizures, or a metabolic disorder.   

Option Analysis

✅ Glucose level:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen:
Incorrect: Abdominal CT may help evaluate intra-abdominal pathology such as obstruction or appendicitis but is not the initial priority in a child with altered mental status. Given this presentation, a bedside glucose check should be performed first to assess for hypoglycemia, a common and reversible cause of lethargy and confusion. 
❌ Neurology consult:
Incorrect: Neurology consultation may prove useful when patients present with altered mental status due to a neurological condition, such as seizure disorder or an intracranial lesion. However, this patient’s fever, vomiting, and diarrhea are consistent with viral gastroenteritis. A bedside glucose level should be performed to assess for hypoglycemia. 
❌ Urine toxicology:
Incorrect: Ingestion of medications, recreational drugs, or household products can cause altered mental status. However, this child’s symptoms and limited oral intake place them at risk for hypoglycemia, which should be evaluated first with a bedside glucose check. 
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Central nervous system infection remains in the differential, but altered mental status with a history of vomiting and decreased oral intake warrants immediate evaluation for hypoglycemia. A bedside glucose test is essential before pursuing more invasive diagnostics such as lumbar puncture.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents to clinic with her parents for follow-up of a four-month history of burning chest pain and sour-tasting regurgitation. Symptoms begin mostly after meals and worsen when lying down or at night. The patient reports nausea but has not had vomiting, dysphagia, weight loss, or hematemesis. There is no history of chronic medical conditions. Over-the-counter antacids have provided temporary relief. After a prior visit, the patient began avoiding acidic foods and caffeine and now sleeps in the left lateral decubitus position with pillows elevating the head. These changes have not alleviated the symptoms. Growth parameters are at the 50<sup>th</sup> percentile, and BMI is 22 kg/m² (85<sup>th</sup> percentile). Vital signs are normal. Physical examination is unremarkable, with no abdominal tenderness, organomegaly, or lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosing this patient?

choices.text: Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy for 4-8 weeks

questions.solution:
This 12-year-old patient presents with classic symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), including indigestion, regurgitation, and symptoms that worsen when lying down. These symptoms have not improved with lifestyle modifications. There are no warning signs such as weight loss, dysphagia, hematemesis, or systemic illness. The best next step, which may be both diagnostic and therapeutic, is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) trial.

In older children and adolescents with typical GERD symptoms and no alarm features, initial management includes lifestyle modifications. These may involve weight reduction if appropriate and avoidance of caffeine and acidic foods. If relevant, alcohol and smoking cessation should be encouraged. Head-of-bed elevation and sleeping in the left lateral decubitus position may also help reduce symptoms.

If symptoms improve with lifestyle changes, this approach can be continued. If symptoms persist, an empiric trial of a PPI (e.g., omeprazole, lansoprazole) for 4 to 8 weeks is appropriate. A positive response supports the diagnosis of GERD. If symptoms continue despite PPI therapy, further evaluation (e.g., esophageal pH monitoring or esophagogastroduodenoscopy) should be pursued, with referral to a pediatric gastroenterologist as indicated.

Option Analysis

❌ Upper gastrointestinal (GI) series:
Incorrect: An upper GI series is useful for evaluating structural abnormalities, such as malrotation or strictures, but has limited utility in diagnosing gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). It is not indicated in patients with typical GERD symptoms unless alarm features are present.
✅ Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy for 4-8 weeks:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 24-hour esophageal pH monitoring:
Incorrect: Esophageal pH monitoring is typically reserved for cases with persistent or atypical symptoms despite an adequate trial of PPI therapy, or when the diagnosis remains uncertain.
❌ Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) with biopsy:
Incorrect: EGD is indicated when alarm symptoms such as dysphagia, weight loss, hematemesis, or anemia are present, or when symptoms persist despite PPI treatment. It is not routinely recommended for initial evaluation of typical gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) symptoms.
❌ Abdominal ultrasonography:
Incorrect: While an abdominal ultrasound may be used in older children for other abdominal concerns such as suspected appendicitis or biliary disease, it is not appropriate in a patient with isolated, classic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) symptoms without alarm features.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy presents to the emergency department along with his parents for evaluation of altered mental status and decreased urine output for the past 12 hours. The parents report tea-colored urine and swelling around the eyes that gradually progressed to involve the entire face. There has been no fever, rash, or recent viral illness. The child has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) diagnosed 4 years ago, with no follow-up for the past 6 months due to relocation. Family and surgical histories are noncontributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The child appears sleepy and is oriented to self but not to time or place. Periorbital and lower extremity edema are noted. Initial laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the immediate next step in management?  

 Serum chemistry    
 Hemoglobin      10.9 g/dL    
 White blood cells     7,600 / mm3    
 Platelets       95,000 / mm3    
 Serum creatinine     1.9 mg/dL    
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)     35 mg/dL    
 Potassium      4.9 mEq/L    
 Urine     
 Erythrocytes     60/hpf    
 Leukocytes     2/hpf    
 Urine specific gravity     1.010    
 Protein       +3    
 Red blood cell casts     Positive
questions.solution:
This child presents with hematuria, oliguria, altered mental status, hypertension, and edema consistent with nephritic syndrome secondary to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The best next step in management is to obtain intravenous access and initiate continuous vital sign monitoring.       

Nephritic syndrome is characterized by hematuria, hypertension, oliguria, and edema resulting from glomerular inflammation. Common causes include postinfectious and infection-associated acute proliferative glomerulonephritis, as well as proliferative lupus nephritis. Urinalysis typically reveals red blood cell casts, hematuria, variable proteinuria, and the presence of white blood cells. In active lupus nephritis, complement levels (C3 and C4) are often low, and anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies are usually positive. Serum creatinine may be normal or elevated depending on the degree of renal involvement.       

An ABCDE approach should be used when evaluating any patient with suspected nephritic syndrome. If the patient is unstable, priority should be given to stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation. Once stabilized, intravenous access should be secured, continuous vital sign monitoring initiated, and supplemental oxygen provided as needed. In stable patients, supportive management includes antihypertensive therapy to control blood pressure, with preference for angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors or angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs), especially in SLE. For patients with SLE and evidence of acute kidney injury, induction therapy with corticosteroids is indicated, often in combination with immunosuppressive agents such as cyclophosphamide or mycophenolate mofetil. Close monitoring of urine output is essential to monitoring renal function and fluid status.   

Option Analysis

❌ Hydralazine:
Incorrect: Hydralazine is used to manage severe hypertension or hypertensive emergencies. While this blood pressure is elevated for age, there is no indication for immediate pharmacologic treatment. Additionally, angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors or angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) are preferred agents in lupus nephritis when antihypertensive therapy is indicated. 
✅ Continuous vital sign monitoring:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Intravenous normal saline bolus:
Incorrect: This patient has peripheral edema and evidence of fluid retention due to active lupus nephritis. Administration of intravenous fluids may worsen volume overload and is not appropriate without signs of intravascular depletion or shock. 
❌ Hemodialysis:
Incorrect: While this patient has an acute kidney injury and mild altered mental status, there are no current indications for emergent dialysis, such as life-threatening hyperkalemia, severe metabolic acidosis, refractory volume overload, or uremic complications. 
❌ Methylprednisolone:
Incorrect: High-dose corticosteroids are indicated in suspected lupus nephritis; however, initial management should include establishing intravenous access and continuous monitoring, especially in a patient with altered mental status, volume overload, and the potential for rapid clinical deterioration.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of cough, decreased oral intake, and high fever (up to 40°C) unresponsive to antipyretics. There is no history of vomiting, seizures, or rhinorrhea. The infant has a history of recurrent ear infections and persistent diarrhea for one month. Birth and family histories are noncontributory. Temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 198/min, respirations are 54/min, blood pressure is 75/40 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals a white film over the tongue and buccal mucosa, as well as a flaky, dandruff-like rash over the scalp and face. Capillary refill is 2 seconds, and mucous membranes are moist. Cardiopulmonary exam shows tachycardia and tachypnea. Abdominal and neurologic exams are normal. Laboratory findings include a decreased lymphocyte count. A chest radiograph reveals an absent thymic shadow. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This infant has severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) and presents with signs of sepsis. The history of chronic diarrhea, recurrent infections, oral thrush, and a flaky rash suggestive of Omenn syndrome, along with laboratory findings of lymphopenia and an absent thymic shadow on chest radiograph, support the diagnosis. Although further evaluation for immunodeficiency is warranted, the best next step in management is initiation of empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics to stabilize the patient.        

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is a life-threatening primary immunodeficiency caused by genetic mutations that result in profound T- and B-cell dysfunction. It typically presents in infants younger than 6 months with features such as failure to thrive, chronic diarrhea, oral thrush, and recurrent infections. Physical examination may reveal mucocutaneous candidiasis, oral ulcers, and decreased or absent lymphoid tissue. Some patients exhibit signs of Omenn syndrome, including scaly erythematous skin, alopecia, and peripheral edema (see image below). Laboratory findings often show decreased lymphocyte counts and low immunoglobulin levels, with impaired T- and B-cell numbers or function. Chest radiographs commonly demonstrate a small or absent thymus.        

An ABCDE assessment should be performed for any patient presenting with suspected primary immunodeficiency. The initial priority is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation in unstable patients. Once stabilized, continuous vital sign monitoring and supplemental oxygen as needed should follow. Emergent initiation of empiric antibiotics is a cornerstone of acute management, and immunoglobulin therapy should be considered. Long-term treatment includes hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, avoidance of live vaccines, antimicrobial prophylaxis, and protective isolation.   


A 5-month-old female infant with Omenn syndrome. Reproduced from Wikipedia. Licensed under CC BY 2.0. 

Option Analysis

❌ Outpatient immunology referral :
Incorrect: Referral to immunology on an outpatient basis is inappropriate for an infant with suspected severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) and signs of systemic infection. Prompt inpatient evaluation and empiric treatment are critical. 
❌ Intravenous vasopressors :
Incorrect: Although the patient meets criteria for sepsis, the blood pressure is within the normal range for age, and perfusion appears adequate. Vasopressors are not indicated before initiating fluid resuscitation and empiric antibiotic therapy. 
✅ Intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Flow cytometry  :
Incorrect: Flow cytometry is an important diagnostic tool for evaluating suspected severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). However, in a patient presenting with sepsis, empiric antibiotic therapy takes priority over diagnostic testing. 
❌ Bone marrow biopsy :
Incorrect: Bone marrow biopsy may be used to support the diagnosis of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) and guide preparation for hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. However, it is not part of the initial workup, and initiating empiric antibiotics is the priority in a patient presenting with signs of sepsis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents to clinic with concerns regarding irregular menstrual cycles and excessive hair growth over her face and abdomen. Menarche occurred at age 12, but only 4 to 5 periods have occurred per year since then. She has had unintentional weight gain over the past two years and progressively worsening acne despite over-the-counter treatments. She has not had any headaches, visual changes, or galactorrhea. Family history is notable for type 2 diabetes and obesity in multiple relatives. Body mass index (BMI) is at the 96<sup>th</sup> percentile for age and sex. Coarse hair is present on the upper lip and lower abdomen. There is mild inflammatory acne and acanthosis nigricans over the neck. Which of the following is the best next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Serum prolactin and brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
Serum androgen levels and pelvic ultrasound

questions.solution:
This adolescent meets the diagnostic criteria for obesity. However, the presence of irregular menses, hirsutism, and acne suggests an underlying diagnosis of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), an obesity-associated endocrine disorder that warrants further evaluation. The next best step is to measure serum androgen levels, such as total testosterone and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEA-S), and perform a pelvic ultrasound if indicated.

The diagnostic evaluation for pediatric obesity in children 2 years of age and older begins with calculating body mass index (BMI). A BMI between the 85th and 94th percentiles indicate overweight, while a BMI at or above the 95th percentile confirms obesity.

Once obesity is identified, further assessment includes screening for common comorbidities with a fasting lipid panel (to assess for dyslipidemia), hemoglobin A1c or glucose testing (for diabetes), liver function tests (to evaluate for non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)), and blood pressure measurement (for hypertension). Additional testing for hypothyroidism, Cushing syndrome, or genetic conditions such as Prader-Willi syndrome may be warranted if clinical findings suggest an alternative etiology, including features such as short stature, rapid-onset weight gain, or dysmorphic features.

Option Analysis

❌ Serum prolactin and brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
Incorrect: Hyperprolactinemia can lead to menstrual irregularities but typically presents with galactorrhea and may be associated with headaches or visual field changes, which are not present in this patient.
✅ Serum androgen levels and pelvic ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thyroid function tests:
Incorrect: Thyroid dysfunction may contribute to menstrual irregularities but does not account for the hyperandrogenic features present in this case (e.g., hirsutism, acne). Additionally, signs commonly seen with hypothyroidism (e.g., cold intolerance, constipation, bradycardia) are absent.
❌ Liver function testing:
Incorrect: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) may coexist with obesity and insulin resistance but would not explain this patient’s clinical features of hyperandrogenism and menstrual irregularity. Liver function testing is not useful in establishing this patient’s diagnosis.
❌ Oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT):
Incorrect: An OGTT is appropriate for assessing metabolic risk in individuals with suspected polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), but it is not used to confirm the diagnosis. Evaluation should begin with an assessment of hyperandrogenism.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for a well child visit. The patient was born at full term, and immunizations are up to date. Maternal history includes seizures (controlled with medication), alcohol intake, and cigarette smoking. The parent reports the child has always been healthy, though a bit small for age. Compared to siblings, development is mildly delayed, and the patient has a poor attention span. Weight and height are at the 5th and 10th percentiles for age, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 97/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 95/51 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, short palpebral fissures, a thin vermilion border, and a smooth philtrum are noted. A loud, harsh, holosystolic murmur is heard at the lower left sternal border. Prenatal exposure to which of the following best explains the findings?
questions.solution:
This 3-year-old patient presents with developmental delays, growth restriction, and characteristic facial features; this constellation of findings is consistent with fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD). FASD refers to a range of physical, behavioral, and neurodevelopmental effects resulting from prenatal alcohol exposure.        

When a pediatric patient presents with concerns suggesting prenatal teratogen exposure, it is essential to obtain a focused history and physical examination. If there are no signs of opioid withdrawal, a history of medical conditions associated with teratogenicity, or prenatal exposure to medications, alcohol exposure should be considered.        

Alcohol use during pregnancy, in any amount, can have significant adverse effects on the developing fetus, including restricted growth, cardiac defects (e.g., atrial, or ventricular septal defects), renal anomalies (e.g., hypoplastic or horseshoe kidneys), skeletal defects (e.g., pectus carinatum, radioulnar synostosis), and eye or ear anomalies. Older children often demonstrate cognitive delays, poor attention span, and behavioral problems. Characteristic facial features, such as short palpebral fissures, a thin vermilion border, and a smooth philtrum, are commonly observed. Epicanthal folds, midface hypoplasia, hypoplastic nails, and “railroad track” ears (which refers to an underdeveloped upper ear that appears in parallel to a crease below) can also be seen with FASD.   

Option Analysis

✅ Alcohol :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Phenytoin  :
Incorrect: Prenatal exposure to phenytoin is associated with abnormal bleeding, impaired development, and characteristic craniofacial abnormalities (e.g., wide anterior fontanelle, short nose, bowed upper lip, cleft lip, or palate). The features noted in this case, including the short palpebral fissures, thin vermilion border, and smooth philtrum, are more consistent with fetal alcohol syndrome.  
❌ Tetracycline  :
Incorrect: Prenatal exposure to tetracycline can result in brown or yellow-stained teeth. It does not cause the characteristic facial features of short palpebral fissures, thin vermilion border, and smooth philtrum, which are more indicative of fetal alcohol syndrome. 
❌ Tobacco   :
Incorrect: Prenatal exposure to tobacco is associated with low birth weight and developmental delays, without characteristic facial features. The observed short palpebral fissures, thin vermilion border, and smooth philtrum are more consistent with fetal alcohol syndrome.  
❌ Valproate :
Incorrect: Prenatal exposure to valproate leads to club feet, wide skull, high forehead, midface hypoplasia, and a broad, low nasal bridge. The features of short palpebral fissures, a thin vermilion border, and a smooth philtrum, in this case, are more consistent with fetal alcohol syndrome.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of a 2-week history of diarrhea. The diarrhea is watery, occasionally mixed with blood, and associated with abdominal cramping and fever. He has also been fatigued, and his appetite has decreased. A 10-day course of amoxicillin was completed for otitis media 3 weeks ago. The child is not currently enrolled in daycare. No recent travel is reported. The child is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), heart rate is 140/min, respiratory rate is 28/min, and blood pressure is 82/46 mm Hg. The child appears lethargic but is arousable to verbal stimuli. Mucous membranes appear dry, and capillary refill is 4 seconds. Abdominal exam reveals diffuse tenderness without guarding or rebound. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Oral rehydration therapy and discharge on oral antibiotics
Abdominal computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This 4-year-old boy presents with a subacute history of diarrhea (>14 days). This clinical picture raises concern for antibiotic-associated diarrhea, with Clostridioides difficile infection being a possible etiology due to recent amoxicillin use and the absence of a travel history. Stabilization with intravenous fluids (e.g. normal saline) is the priority for this patient, given the signs of severe dehydration and hypovolemic shock.       

The first step when a pediatric patient presents with subacute diarrhea is to perform an ABCDE assessment to identify signs of respiratory distress or hemodynamic instability. If the patient is unstable, stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation takes priority. Immediate interventions may include obtaining intravenous access, initiating isotonic fluid resuscitation (e.g., normal saline or lactated Ringer’s), and placing the patient on continuous vital sign monitoring. Supplemental oxygen should be provided if necessary, and antibiotics, such as oral vancomycin for suspected C. difficile, may be considered. Once stabilized, further history, examination, and diagnostics can be pursued to determine the underlying cause.   

Option Analysis

❌ Oral rehydration therapy and discharge on oral antibiotics :
Incorrect: Although oral rehydration is appropriate for mild dehydration, this child shows signs of severe dehydration and hemodynamic instability, which require intravenous fluids. Discharging the child without addressing the unstable condition would be inappropriate.
✅ Intravenous (IV) normal saline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stool ova and parasite studies:
Incorrect: Parasitic infections are less likely in this patient’s case due to the absence of travel history or other risk factors (e.g., daycare attendance, exposure to contaminated water). This patient’s diarrhea may be due to C. difficile, especially given the recent antibiotic use. Even so, stool studies are not the priority in an unstable patient. 
❌ Abdominal computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: Imaging is unnecessary for patients with gastroenteritis unless there is suspicion of complicating conditions such as toxic megacolon or peritoneal signs. This patient should be stabilized before pursuing further testing. 
❌ Loperamide:
Incorrect: Antidiarrheal agents like loperamide are typically contraindicated in suspected infectious diarrhea, as they slow colonic transit and can increase the risk of toxin retention.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to clinic for evaluation of a 3-week history of diarrhea. The stools are described as greasy, foul-smelling, and pale, occurring 4–5 times daily. He has also had bloating, abdominal cramping, and increased flatulence. The parents report a decreased appetite and weight loss. There has been no fever, vomiting, or blood in the stools. The family recently returned from a camping trip. Vital signs are within normal limits. The child appears well. Mucous membranes appear tacky, and capillary refill is <2 seconds. Abdominal examination reveals mild diffuse tenderness without guarding or rebound tenderness. Laboratory stool studies are ordered. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on stool microscopy?

choices.text: Oval-shaped eggs with a terminal spine

questions.solution:
This child presents with a 3-week history of greasy, foul-smelling diarrhea, abdominal bloating, and weight loss, hallmark features of giardiasis caused by Giardia lamblia. The recent camping trip and possible ingestion of contaminated water strongly support this diagnosis. Stool microscopy would likely reveal trophozoites with a pear-shaped appearance and four pairs of flagella, which are often described as resembling a "smiling face."       

The diagnostic workup for pediatric subacute infectious gastroenteritis includes a thorough history, physical examination, and targeted stool studies to identify the underlying pathogen. Stool cultures are essential for detecting bacterial causes, such as enteroaggregative Escherichia coli (EAEC) or Clostridioides difficile, with additional tests like toxin assays or nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT) to detect specific bacterial toxins. Parasitic infections, including Giardia lamblia and Cryptosporidium, require stool ova and parasite (O&P) examination, antigen testing, or special stains for visualization.    

Option Analysis

❌ Oocysts with sporozoites :
Incorrect: This description matches Cryptosporidium, which causes watery diarrhea and is associated with recreational water exposure, such as public pools or lakes, or in immunocompromised individuals. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with giardiasis.
✅ Trophozoites with a pear-shaped appearance:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oval-shaped eggs with a terminal spine:
Incorrect: These findings are characteristic of Schistosoma species, which cause symptoms like hematuria or dysentery and are typically found in freshwater snail habitats in specific regions. These symptoms do not match the presentation of diarrhea, bloating, and malabsorption in this case. Instead, this patient’s presentation is consistent with giardiasis. 
❌ Round cysts with multiple nuclei:
Incorrect: This finding describes Entamoeba histolytica, which causes bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. The absence of blood and the presence of greasy stools make this diagnosis unlikely in this case. Instead, this patient’s presentation is consistent with giardiasis. 
❌ Gram-positive rods with flagella:
Incorrect: This finding describes Clostridium difficile, which causes antibiotic-associated diarrhea, which is often watery and accompanied by fever or cramping. The greasy stools and weight loss described here are not typical of C. difficile infection. Instead, this patient’s presentation is consistent with giardiasis.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of recurrent vomiting. The child was found vomiting in the laundry room while playing with laundry detergent packets. The patient was last seen in his usual state of health 2 hours ago. The patient has no past medical history and does not take any daily medications. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate is 150/min, blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg, respiratory rate is 40/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears ill, with noted respiratory distress, drooling, and stridor. Intravenous (IV) access is established, supplemental oxygen is applied, a normal saline bolus is administered, and the patient is connected to telemetry. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents following ingestion of a laundry detergent capsule, raising concern for caustic ingestion. Caustic substances can cause liquefactive necrosis of the esophagus and upper airway, leading to stridor and drooling. Given the risk for airway instability, the best next step in management is securing the airway via fiberoptic endotracheal intubation. This approach allows clear visualization of the upper airway and esophagus, minimizing further injury.

Many pediatric patients with caustic injury may initially present without symptoms but can quickly decompensate, making clinical suspicion crucial in suspected cases. In these situations, patients should undergo gastroenterology consultation for endoscopy and surgical consultation if perforation is suspected. Additionally, a local poison center should be contacted for further guidance on management and disposition.

All patients with suspected exposure to household substances should be evaluated using the ABCDE approach to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. Caustic substances, carbon monoxide, organophosphates, and toxic alcohols can cause acute, life-threatening symptoms. Patients with airway instability should have their airway secured, with particular attention to preventing aspiration or further damage to surrounding structures. Breathing should be supported with supplemental oxygen, and circulation should be stabilized with intravenous fluids if signs of dehydration or hemodynamic instability, such as hypotension, are present.   

Option Analysis

❌ Laryngeal mask airway (LMA) placement:
Incorrect: Blind placement of upper airway adjuncts such as laryngeal mask airways (LMAs) are strictly contraindicated in patients with suspected caustic ingestion. Blind placement may worsen esophageal injury.
✅ Fiberoptic endotracheal intubation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Activated charcoal:
Incorrect: This patient is at high risk of respiratory decompensation given the concern for caustic ingestion. There is no role for activated charcoal in the management of caustic agents. Charcoal may obscure visualization during endoscopy or intubation and can cause vomiting, which could re-expose the upper gastrointestinal tissues to the caustic agent.
❌ Syrup of ipecac:
Incorrect: Syrup of ipecac is no longer recommended following ingestion of household substances. It was previously used to induce vomiting, but studies show that vomiting alone does not reliably remove poisons from the stomach. Moreover, it risks re-exposing the upper gastrointestinal tissues to the caustic agent.
❌ Bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP):
Incorrect: Application of bilevel positive airway pressure could increase the risk of aspiration and worsen respiratory distress by interfering with swallowing and breathing coordination. It may also cause gastric distention, which can further compromise respiratory status.

questions.text: A 14-month-old girl presents to the pediatrician’s office with diarrhea for the past 2 days. The parent reports that the patient has been drinking less than usual but continues to tolerate oral intake. The parent notes low-grade fevers but no sustained true fever. The patient continues to make wet diapers and tears while crying. The child is otherwise healthy, has met all developmental milestones, and has not had any other medical history since birth. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 35/min, blood pressure is 95/55 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. Physical examination reveals an infant crawling on the gurney. The patient appears alert and in no acute distress. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable aside from increased bowel sounds. During the examination, the patient has an episode of watery diarrhea. The patient has slightly reduced skin turgor. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: 20 mL/kg bolus of intravenous normal saline

questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents with signs of mild dehydration secondary to a diarrheal illness. Mild dehydration is characterized by volume losses of approximately 3-5%, normal vital signs, slightly reduced skin turgor, normal urine output, and normal tear production. Treatment for mild dehydration involves oral rehydration therapy (ORT) without the need for additional diagnostic testing or intravenous fluids.   

Dehydration refers to excessive loss of body water, which may result from conditions such as gastrointestinal illnesses, third-spacing, burns, or polyuria. Pediatric dehydration exists on a spectrum, from mild to severe, with distinct clinical features depending on the severity. Accurate assessment of dehydration severity is essential for determining the appropriate treatment.        

Mild dehydration should be treated with ORT. Moderate and severe dehydration require fluid resuscitation with isotonic crystalloid fluids, such as a bolus of normal saline. In severe dehydration, additional boluses may be necessary if signs of shock persist. Additional fluids should be based on calculating the patient’s remaining fluid deficit and replacing the fluid over 24 hours with ORT (for moderate dehydration in patients who can tolerate oral intake) or intravenous isotonic fluids (for severe dehydration or patients who cannot tolerate oral intake). Electrolyte derangements should be identified with a basic metabolic panel.    

Option Analysis

✅ Oral rehydration therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ 20 mL/kg bolus of intravenous normal saline:
Incorrect: A bolus of normal saline is indicated for patients with moderate to severe dehydration or those who cannot tolerate oral intake. This patient has mild dehydration and is able to tolerate oral fluids. 
❌ Basic metabolic panel :
Incorrect: A basic metabolic panel is typically used for patients with moderate to severe dehydration or when there is concern for electrolyte abnormalities. This patient shows signs of mild dehydration and is otherwise stable. 
❌ Point-of-care glucose:
Incorrect: Point-of-care glucose is appropriate for patients with signs of hypoglycemia (e.g., lethargy, seizures) or for those with moderate to severe dehydration who are unable to feed. This patient shows no signs of hypoglycemia and is tolerating oral intake. 
❌ Oral ondansetron :
Incorrect: Oral ondansetron is used for patients who cannot tolerate oral intake due to vomiting. This patient is able to tolerate oral fluids and is not vomiting, so ondansetron is unnecessary.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of 12 hours of vomiting and diarrhea. She has had three episodes of non-bilious, non-bloody vomiting and six watery stools. The child has been unable to tolerate fluids and has not urinated for 8 hours. She recently attended a birthday party a few days ago, and several children have since developed similar symptoms. Medical history is unremarkable, and the patient takes no medication. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), blood pressure is 78/40 mmHg, heart rate is 140 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The child appears uncomfortable. Mucous membranes are dry, capillary refill time is 3 seconds, and skin turgor is reduced. Abdominal examination reveals mild diffuse tenderness without rebound or guarding. Stool is watery without visible blood or mucus. Laboratory results are shown in the table below. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory Test     Result    
 Serum sodium     134 mEq/L   
 Serum potassium     3.2 mEq/L   
 Serum bicarbonate     17 mEq/L   
 Blood urea nitrogen     22 mg/dL   
 Creatinine     0.8 mg/dL   
 Glucose     90 mg/dL

choices.text: Intravenous (IV) antiemetic and oral rehydration therapy

questions.solution:
This 4-year-old girl presents with vomiting and diarrhea following exposure to ill contacts, suggesting viral gastroenteritis. Clinical signs, including lethargy, tachycardia, hypotension, delayed capillary refill, dry mucous membranes, anuria, and reduced skin turgor, indicate severe dehydration and hypovolemic shock. Immediate management should focus on restoring intravascular volume and correcting electrolyte imbalances via intravenous (IV) fluid administration. Isotonic fluids, such as normal saline or lactated Ringer's solution, should be given as an initial bolus (e.g., 20 mL/kg), followed by additional fluids based on the clinical response.       

For pediatric patients presenting with vomiting, an ABCDE assessment should be performed to assess clinical stability. In unstable patients, measures should be performed to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. IV access should be established, and IV isotonic fluids initiated to address life-threatening volume depletion. The patient may need to remain nil per os (NPO) and have a nasogastric tube inserted if indicated. Continuous vital sign monitoring, supplemental oxygen, and antibiotics may also be necessary, depending on the patient's condition and potential etiologies.       

Additionally, a focused history and physical examination should be conducted to assess for life-threatening causes of vomiting, such as diabetic ketoacidosis, appendicitis, intussusception, or an incarcerated hernia leading to an acute abdomen. Key investigations include a blood glucose test, blood gas, metabolic panel, and abdominal exam to evaluate for tenderness, rebound, guarding, or rigidity.   



Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous (IV) antiemetic and oral rehydration therapy:
Incorrect: Oral rehydration therapy is effective for mild dehydration. This patient has signs of severe dehydration, making IV fluid administration the appropriate initial management. Antiemetics can be considered after stabilization but are not the priority. 
✅ Intravenous (IV) normal saline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rapid stool antigen test:
Incorrect: A stool antigen test could identify a viral pathogen (e.g., rotavirus or norovirus), but it would not change the initial management, which focuses on correcting this patient’s severe dehydration. 
❌ Nasogastric tube placement:
Incorrect: Nasogastric hydration is an option for children with mild to moderate dehydration who cannot tolerate oral rehydration. However, this patient’s signs of severe dehydration warrant IV hydration instead. 
❌ Stool culture and intravenous antibiotics:
Incorrect: Stool cultures are typically indicated when invasive bacterial diarrhea is suspected (e.g., bloody stools, high fever, or significant abdominal tenderness). This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a viral etiology. Antibiotics are not indicated for viral gastroenteritis and would not take priority over appropriate fluid resuscitation.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after falling from a tree. The child landed on his back and briefly lost consciousness but is now awake and alert. There is no past medical history and no medications. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate is 110/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 104/64 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The primary survey is unremarkable. During the secondary survey, the child reports a headache and neck pain. Examination reveals midline cervical spine tenderness and mild bruising across the upper chest. The musculoskeletal examination is normal, with full range of motion and no swelling, tenderness, or deformities in any extremity. The abdomen is nontender, and distal pulses are intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate next diagnostic step to evaluate this patient’s injuries?

choices.text: Cervical spine X-ray and computed tomography (CT) of the head
Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) examination
X-rays of upper and lower extremities
Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This 7-year-old patient has clinical signs of head trauma (brief loss of consciousness, headache) and cervical spine trauma (midline cervical tenderness), both of which warrant immediate imaging. A non-contrast head CT is indicated to evaluate for intracranial hemorrhage or other brain injury. Cervical spine X-rays are appropriate to quickly assess for vertebral fracture, dislocation, or spinal cord injury, even if further imaging such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is ultimately needed.

The diagnostic evaluation of a pediatric trauma patient follows stabilization during the primary survey and is guided by findings from the secondary survey. Head CT is warranted when there is loss of consciousness, altered mental status, focal neurologic deficits, or signs of skull fracture (e.g., skull irregularity, facial lacerations) or ocular injury (e.g., displacement of the globe, enophthalmos). Midline cervical tenderness or neurologic symptoms raise concern for cervical spine injury, which is initially assessed with cervical spine X-ray or, in some settings, CT. Thoracic trauma, suggested by chest pain, bruising, or abnormal breath sounds, is evaluated with chest imaging. Pelvic or genitourinary injury is indicated by pelvic tenderness, hematuria, or urethral bleeding and may require pelvic X-ray or CT. Musculoskeletal trauma is identified by swelling, tenderness, or deformity and evaluated with targeted extremity X-rays.   

Option Analysis

❌ Pelvic X-ray:
Incorrect: There are no pelvic tenderness, bruising, or signs of genitourinary injury to suggest a pelvic fracture or indicate the need for imaging. However, the mechanism of injury, loss of consciousness, headache, and cervical spine tenderness are concerning and warrant urgent imaging.
✅ Cervical spine X-ray and computed tomography (CT) of the head:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) examination:
Incorrect: The FAST exam is used to assess for intra-abdominal bleeding. This patient has no abdominal tenderness or hemodynamic instability to suggest such an injury. However, the mechanism of injury, loss of consciousness, headache, and cervical spine tenderness are concerning and warrant urgent imaging.
❌ X-rays of upper and lower extremities:
Incorrect: There is no reported pain, deformity, swelling, or bruising in the upper or lower extremities to suggest the need for imaging. However, the mechanism of injury, loss of consciousness, headache, and cervical spine tenderness are concerning and warrant urgent imaging.
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: Abdominal CT is not indicated in a stable patient without signs of abdominal trauma such as tenderness, distention, or ecchymosis. However, the mechanism of injury, loss of consciousness, headache, and cervical spine tenderness are concerning and warrant urgent imaging.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents to his pediatrician with nasal congestion, fever, and throat pain complaints. His parent reports the patient had an upper respiratory tract infection last week, which seemed to improve, but his symptoms worsened over the past three days. The patient's current vital signs are temperature is 38.9 C° (102 F°), respirations are 16/minute,  pulse is 90/minute, and blood pressure is 105/70 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates purulent rhinorrhea. A flexible nasal endoscope is inserted, which confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following correctly describes the anatomic structure implicated in this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
The tonsils consist of a group of lymphatic tissues in the posterior pharynx/oropharynx and include pharyngeal, palatine, tubal, and lingual. When the pharyngeal tonsils, or adenoids, become inflamed, the condition is called adenoiditis.

The pharyngeal tonsils typically regress by early puberty; therefore, the majority of patients that present with adenoiditis are prepubescent. A typical history includes a child with a recent viral upper respiratory infection that progresses to fevers, purulent rhinorrhea, nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, and halitosis. Diagnosis is primarily clinical, and direct visualization of the inflamed pharyngeal tonsils can be achieved via a laryngeal mirror or nasal endoscope.

Commonly implicated pathogens include those responsible for other upper respiratory tract infections, including Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Streptococcus pyogenes, and Staphylococcus aureus. In addition, environmental allergens and caustic irritation secondary to gastric reflux are known to precipitate adenoiditis.

Option Analysis

✅ Pharyngeal tonsils:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Palatine tonsils:
Incorrect: The palatine tonsils are tonsils located on the left and right sides at the back of the throat, which can often be seen as flesh-colored, pinkish lumps. The palatine tonsils are not the lymphatic tissue associated with acute adenoiditis.  
❌ Thyroid gland:
Incorrect: The thyroid gland lies inferior and anterior to the pharyngeal tonsils--at the level below the cricoid cartilage. The thyroid gland may become enlarged and inflamed for various reasons; however, it is not implicated in cases of acute adenoiditis.  
❌ Tubal tonsils:
Incorrect: The tubal tonsil is located posterior to the Eustachian tube's opening on the nasopharynx's lateral wall. This tonsil may become implicated in cases of eustachian tube dysfunction.  
❌ Parotid gland:
Incorrect: The parotid gland serves as the largest salivary gland and lies on the lateral aspects of the face. The parotid glands cannot be visualized with nasal endoscopy.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the clinic for evaluation of acne. He has had acne for several years but noticed it has worsened in the past few months. He has tried an over-the-counter benzoyl peroxide wash and topical retinoid cream without improvement. He has multiple bright red pustules and acneiform papules on the forehead and cheeks on physical examination. He was prescribed doxycycline for three months, which leads to symptomatic improvement. However, after six months, the patient’s symptoms worsened. What is the mechanism by which bacteria develop resistance to this class of antibiotics?

choices.text: Amino acid modification of D-Ala D-Ala

questions.solution:
Doxycycline and other tetracyclines are bacteriostatic antibiotics that inhibit the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome, thereby preventing attachment of aminoacyl-tRNA. Doxycycline is commonly used in the treatment of acne vulgaris.

Bacteria can develop resistance to tetracyclines primarily by forming plasmid-encoded transport pumps that decrease the uptake or increase the efflux of tetracyclines out of the cell. Other proposed resistance mechanisms include ribosomal protection and bacterial modification of tetracycline molecules, reducing the drug’s effectiveness.  

Option Analysis

✅ Plasmid-encoded transport pumps  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bacterial transferase enzymes:
Incorrect: This is how bacteria develop resistance to aminoglycoside antibiotics (e.g., gentamicin, neomycin, amikacin, tobramycin, streptomycin). These enzymes inactive the drugs through adenylation, phosphorylation, or acetylation.  
❌ Carbapenemases:
Incorrect: This is how bacteria develop resistance to carbapenems (e.g., doripenem, imipenem, meropenem, ertapenem). These antibiotics are not used in the routine treatment of acne vulgaris.  
❌ Amino acid modification of D-Ala D-Ala:
Incorrect: This is the mechanism by which bacteria develop resistance to vancomycin. D-Ala D-Ala is converted to D-Ala D-Lac, preventing vancomycin from binding to the bacterial cell wall.  
❌ Methylation of 23S rRNA-binding site:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes how bacteria develop resistance to macrolide antibiotics. Methylation of the site prevents the binding of drug molecules to the ribosome.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a bee-sting at the park across the street. The patient appears uncomfortable and is able to speak in only short phrases. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 85% on room air. Physical examination shows a diffuse erythematous rash on the chest wall. Pulmonary auscultation demonstrates bilateral wheezing throughout all lung fields. Which of the following appropriately describes the mechanism of action of the first-line medication used to treat this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Epinephrine is the most potent sympathomimetic medication available and is the first-line treatment for anaphylaxis and/or anaphylactic shock.  

Option Analysis

✅ α1, α2, ß1, ß2, and ß3 agonism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ α1, α2, ß1, and ß3 agonism:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of norepinephrine. Unlike epinephrine, norepinephrine lacks ß2 agonist effects, making it an inappropriate choice for the management of anaphylactic shock.  
❌ D1, α1, α2, ß1, and ß3 agonism:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of dopamine, which carries similar properties to norepinephrine but also agonizes the D1 receptor. Activation of this receptor relaxes renal vascular smooth muscle and activates the direct pathway of striatum in the brain. It is rarely used in clinical practice due to its propensity towards fatal cardiac arrhythmias.  
❌ α1, α2 agonism:
Incorrect: α1, and α2 agonists include medications such as phenylephrine. While this medication may aid in increasing systemic vascular resistance, epinephrine carries ß2 agonistic properties, making it an ideal agent for the treatment of anaphylactic shock.  
❌ ß2 agonism:
Incorrect: Medications such as albuterol or salmeterol are pure ß2 agonists. While they may have some effect in assisting with this patient’s bronchoconstriction, associated effects of epinephrine make it a preferred agent for the treatment of anaphylactic shock.

questions.text: A 5 year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of fever and irritability for two days. Her parent reports that the patient has had foul-smelling, dark urine. The patient has been given acetaminophen for fever control. She has a past medical history of an uncomplicated appendectomy at 4 months of age and was treated for otitis media two months ago with amoxicillin. She has a history of moderate developmental delay, and she is not yet toilet-trained. Temperature is 39°C (102°F), pulse is 124/min, respiratory rate is 28/min, blood pressure is 99/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is crying. Mucous membranes appear moist. Cardiopulmonary and HEENT examinations are within normal limits. Suprapubic tenderness is present. Genitourinary examination shows normal-appearing female genitalia. Urinalysis is positive for leukocyte esterase. Which of the following is most likely to lead to misdiagnosis?

choices.text: Obtaining urine via a perineal bag

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of irritability, fever, and foul-smelling urine which is concerning for a urinary tract infection (UTI). In non-toilet-trained children, a urine specimen for culture should ideally be obtained via straight catheterization, as other methods of collection in this patient population such as obtaining urine via a perineal bag can lead to a contaminated specimen and misdiagnosis.

Evaluation of pediatric patients who present with a suspected UTI varies depending on the patient’s age and whether or not they are toilet-trained. Analysis of a urine sample is a cornerstone of diagnostic evaluation. A urine sample can be obtained via clean catch, straight catheterization, perineal bag, or suprapubic needle aspiration. When a urine culture is needed in addition to urinalysis, a clean sample is typically obtained via straight catheterization in non-toilet trained patients, as urine collected via bag specimen is often contaminated by skin flora and can thus only be used for urinalysis. Suprapubic needle aspiration is another option for obtaining a urine sample for culture, but this is a painful procedure that is not commonly used. A clean-catch sample can be obtained in toilet-trained children.

In addition to urinalysis and urine culture, the workup for infants less than 2 months of age who present with a fever and signs suggestive of a UTI (e.g., foul-smelling urine, poor oral intake or vomiting, suprapubic tenderness) should also include a complete blood count (CBC), c-reactive protein, and procalcitonin. Blood cultures and cerebrospinal fluid analysis and culture may also be included as part of a neonatal sepsis evaluation.

On urinalysis, the presence of leukocyte esterase, white blood cells, nitrites, or bacteria suggests a UTI. The quantitative threshold for bacterial counts in the urine culture that is used to diagnose a UTI varies depending on the method of collection and ranges from over 10,000 colony-forming units per milliliter to over 100,000 CFU/mL depending on the source of the sample.  Consideration should be given to renal and bladder imaging, in young children especially, to identify abnormalities of the genitourinary tract or post-infectious sequelae such as renal scarring. Additional workup in children of any age may include laboratory studies such as a CBC and basic metabolic panel, with blood cultures if signs of urosepsis are present.  

Option Analysis

✅ Obtaining urine via a perineal bag:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obtaining urine via straight catheterization:
Incorrect: Obtaining urine via straight catheterization is the preferred method, particularly in very young or non-toilet trained patients who are unable to provide a clean urine sample.  
❌ Recent antibiotic use:
Incorrect: Recent antibiotic use can potentially confound the results of a urine culture; however, it is less likely to be a factor in this patient given that she was treated with antibiotics two months prior.  
❌ History of appendicitis:
Incorrect: Appendicitis can result in sterile pyuria (the presence of white blood cells in urine and a negative urine culture). However, this patient’s history of appendicitis is remote, making this a less likely confounding factor.  
❌ Acetaminophen use:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen use is unlikely to be a confounding factor in the diagnosis of pediatric urinary tract infections as it does not affect the results of urinalysis and culture.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of difficulty breathing. The patient has had rapid and noisy breathing for the past few hours. Symptoms have progressively worsened. The patient has not received any vaccinations since birth due to parental preference. Temperature is 39.7°C (103.4°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is leaning forward and makes a loud harsh sound during every inspiration. A lateral neck x-ray is obtained and shown below. The patient is admitted to the hospital and blood cultures are obtained. After securing the airway, which of the following medications should be administered in combination with vancomycin?
 
Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a high-grade fever and respiratory distress. Imaging reveals the “thumbprint sign” caused by a swollen epiglottis. In combination, these findings are suggestive of acute epiglottitis, which is most often caused by the Gram-negative coccobacilli Haemophilus influenzae. The condition is empirically treated with vancomycin and a third-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone, cefotaxime).

The third-generation cephalosporins include cefotaxime, ceftazidime, ceftriaxone, cefdinir, cefixime, and cefpodoxime. These are broad-spectrum antibiotics with improved Gram-negative activity at the cost of decreased efficiency against Gram-positive bacteria. Moreover, third-generation cephalosporins can cross the blood-brain barrier.

They are the first-line treatment against infections caused by Haemophilus influenzae, Pneumococci, Meningococci, and Neisseria species. They are also the antibiotic of choice against penicillin-resistant Neisseria gonorrhoeae. In addition, ceftazidime is effective in treating infection caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa whereas ceftriaxone is effective in treating Borrelia burgdorferi, which causes Lyme disease.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Glucocorticoid:
Incorrect: Glucocorticoids are not recommended in the initial management of epiglottitis as direct evidence of benefit is lacking. Glucocorticoids do not reduce the length of stay or duration of intubation.  
✅ Third-generation cephalosporin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tetracyclines:
Incorrect: Tetracyclines inhibit bacterial protein synthesis and can be used in the management of Borrelia, Mycoplasma, Rickettsia, or Chlamydia infections. However, it is not effective against  Haemophilus influenzae, which is the most common cause of acute epiglottitis.  
❌ Chloramphenicol:
Incorrect: Chloramphenicol has been historically used in the management of meningitis caused by Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Streptococcus pneumoniae. It is rarely used in the United States nowadays due to its toxicity profile, in particular its ability to cause dose-dependent aplastic anemia.  
❌ Fluoroquinolones:
Incorrect: Fluoroquinolones are effective against Gram-negative rods infecting the urinary and gastrointestinal tract. However, they would not be effective in this patient with epiglottitis, which is most often caused by the Gram-negative coccobacilli Haemophilus influenzae.

questions.text:
A 2-week-old neonate is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of fever, feeding intolerance, and abdominal distention. He was born at 37 weeks to a healthy, 34-year-old woman, G3P2, via uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery. He had been doing well until 2 days ago. A full sepsis and meningitis work-up is initiated and is unrevealing. The neonate has an episode of hematochezia 8 hours after initial evaluation. Vital signs are notable for a temperature of 38.3 °C (101 °F), heart rate of 140/min, respiratory rate of 42/min, and blood pressure of 65/40 mmHg. Lab results can be seen below. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis?  

White blood cells (WBC)
15.5 x 103/µL
Absolute neutrophil count (ANC)
< 1500/µL
Hemoglobin (Hgb)
14.5 g/dL
Hematocrit (Hct)
52%
Platelets (PLT)
125,000/µL

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) Abdomen/Pelvis with IV contrast
No testing is necessary, a clinical diagnosis can be made

questions.solution:
