The Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporters are located in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, which is impermeable to water.       

Epithelial cells along the thick ascending limb have Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporters on the apical surface, which actively reabsorb sodium down its concentration gradient. This movement of sodium powers the movement of one potassium and two chlorides into the cell as well. These changes also cause paracellular reabsorption of Ca2+ and Mg2+ (secondary to the positive lumen potential established by K+ backleak).        

On the basolateral surface of the tubule cell, a Na+/K+ ATPase uses ATP to pump three sodium ions into the interstitial fluid in exchange for letting two potassium ions into the cell. The Na+/K+ ATPase pump helps maintain the low sodium concentration inside the cell. Finally, both chloride and potassium move passively through their own channels down their concentration gradient from the cell into the interstitial fluid as well.       

The thick ascending loop of Henle is impermeable to water, and thus, is known as the diluting segment. This segment is responsible for approximately 10-20% of the Na+ reabsorbed from the nephron.   



Option Analysis

❌ Most concentrated segment of the nephron:
Incorrect: The descending limb of the loop of Henle is permeable to water but not to solutes. Water moves down its concentration gradient in this segment of the nephron from the lumen to the highly osmotic medulla. Tubular fluid will be most concentrated at the bottom of the loop of Henle. 
✅  Impermeability to water:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Site of action of ADH:
Incorrect: Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) binds to V2 receptors on the collecting tubules, thereby increasing their permeability to water. In contrast, the Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporters are located in the ascending loop of Henle. 
❌  Isotonic tubular fluid:
Incorrect: The tubular fluid in the proximal convoluted tubule remains isotonic as the water is reabsorbed along with the electrolytes. In contrast, the Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporters are located in the ascending loop of Henle. 
❌ Controlled by aldosterone:
Incorrect: The collecting duct is the final segment of the nephron. Sodium reabsorption at this site is controlled by aldosterone. In contrast, the Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporters are located in the ascending loop of Henle.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset severe left testicular pain that started three hours ago while he was asleep. He reports associated nausea and vomiting following the start of the pain. He does not have dysuria. Temperature is 37ºC (98.6°F), heart rate is 106/min, blood pressure is 135/90 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 20/min. The patient is in distress due to pain. The left testicle is high-riding with a transverse lie. There is marked scrotal erythema and swelling. Cremasteric reflex is absent on the left. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe antibiotics, analgesia, and schedule follow-up in one week
Apply ice packs, scrotal support, and reassess in 24 hours
Obtain emergent urology consultation and perform manual detorsion
Advise bed rest and observe for spontaneous resolution of symptoms

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe acute scrotal pain associated with nausea and vomiting and is found to have a high riding testicle with vertical lie, swelling, erythema, and an absent cremasteric reflex. These are classic signs and symptoms of acute testicular torsion, which is considered a urological emergency. Obtaining emergent urology consultation and performing manual detorsion is the appropriate treatment.

Immediate intervention is required for testicular torsion in order to attempt to salvage the testicle. Manual detorsion serves as a temporizing measure that can restore blood flow before definitive surgical intervention. This procedure involves rotating the testicle in a medial-to-lateral direction, akin to the motion of "opening a book.” When testicular torsion is suspected, emergent urology consultation is critical for definitive management, typically involving surgical exploration and detorsion with possible orchiopexy to prevent recurrence.    

Option Analysis

❌ Prescribe antibiotics, analgesia, and schedule follow-up in one week :
Incorrect: Immediate surgical treatment is necessary for testicular torsion; delay in treatment puts patients at risk for permanent testicular damage or loss due to prolonged ischemia. 
❌ Apply ice packs, scrotal support, and reassess in 24 hours:
Incorrect: Immediate surgical treatment is necessary for testicular torsion; delay in treatment puts patients at risk for permanent testicular damage or loss due to prolonged ischemia. 
✅ Obtain emergent urology consultation and perform manual detorsion:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Order Doppler ultrasonography:
Incorrect: Many cases of testicular torsion, such as this one, do not require imaging to confirm the diagnosis if the history and physical examination are pathognomonic. For equivocal cases, color Doppler ultrasonography should be obtained urgently. 
❌ Advise bed rest and observe for spontaneous resolution of symptoms:
Incorrect: Immediate surgical treatment is necessary for testicular torsion; delay in treatment puts patients at risk for permanent testicular damage or loss due to prolonged ischemia.

questions.text:
A 1-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her parents for a well-child visit. She eats three solid food meals per day and breastfed five times a day (equivalent to 25 oz/day). Parents report that she is a picky eater. They offer fruits, vegetables, and protein, but she prefers carbohydrates. They often forget to give her multivitamins daily. She drinks water from a sippy cup. Length is 43rd percentile, weight is 35th percentile, and head circumference is 52nd percentile. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 30/min, blood pressure is 90/55 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Faint pallor is appreciated on skin and conjunctival examination. The tongue appears smooth and glossy. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals tachycardia, but no murmur is appreciated. Routine blood work is obtained, and results are shown below. In addition to oral iron supplementation, which of the following interventions is recommended?
 
 Laboratory value     Result   
 Hemoglobin     9.3 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     27.4%    
 Leukocyte count     10.6/mm3    
 Platelet count     257/mm3    
 Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)     66 fL    
 Serum Ferritin (SF)     6 ng/mL    
 Transferrin Saturation (TSAT)     188 mg/dL    
 Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)     420 mcg/dL

choices.text: Having citrus foods with supplemental iron

questions.solution:
This patient has a limited diet, with findings on exam of pallor, tachycardia, and atrophic glossitis suggestive of iron deficiency anemia. Diagnosis is confirmed by the laboratory findings of low hemoglobin, mean corpuscular volume, ferritin, and transferrin saturation, and elevated total iron binding capacity. This patient can be diagnosed with mild iron deficiency anemia which can be treated with oral ferrous sulfate and be taken with citrus foods for better absorption. 

Treatment of iron deficiency with and without anemia in children involves treating the underlying cause, whether it is from chronic disease or poor intake of iron-rich foods. Oral supplementation with ferrous sulfate is recommended, and length of treatment depends on the severity of the anemia. Oral supplementation is recommended to be taken with acidic foods for better absorption and should not be taken with milk, eggs, or soy, which are foods that limit absorption. If the patient cannot tolerate oral supplementation or has a hemoglobin below 7 or 8 g/dL or ongoing blood loss, parenteral iron therapy should be considered. If the patient has severe symptomatic anemia (hemoglobin < 5 g/dL), a red blood cell transfusion should be considered.

Iron deficiency with and without anemia is common in toddlers due to their diet. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that all children be screened for anemia between 9 and 12 months and again between 1 and 5 years of age if they are at high risk. To prevent iron deficiency, iron is added to formula and babies who are breastfed should start iron supplementation at four months and continue it until iron-containing solid foods are introduced. All preterm infants should be on iron supplementation for the first year of life.   

Option Analysis

✅ Having citrus foods with supplemental iron:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Red blood cell transfusion:
Incorrect: Red blood cell transfusion should be given to patients with severe anemia (defined as hemoglobin < 5 g/dL). This patient has mild anemia which can be treated with oral supplementation and does not warrant a red blood cell transfusion. 
❌ Discontinue breastfeeding:
Incorrect: Although there is limited iron in breastmilk, iron deficiency anemia is not an indication to discontinue breastfeeding. This patient has iron deficiency anemia and iron supplementation taken with citrus foods can be recommended. 
❌ Switch to a vegetarian diet:
Incorrect: Vegetarian diets are low in iron. This patient has iron deficiency anemia, so a vegetarian diet would not be helpful. 
❌ Introduce cow’s milk:
Incorrect: Cow’s milk interferes with the absorption of iron and would exacerbate this patient's iron deficiency. There is no need to add cow’s milk at one year of age if the patient is breastfeeding.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old boy presents to the pediatrician for new-onset fatigue and pallor. He was diagnosed with pneumonia two weeks ago and seemed to recover after completing a course of antibiotics. The patient is napping more and seems tired despite increased napping and sleeping 12-13 hours at night. The patient was born full-term and had been healthy until the recent pneumonia diagnosis. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 162/min, respirations are 38/min and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is alert and sitting quietly in the parent’s lap. There is no increased work of breathing. There is scleral icterus and mild jaundice is noted. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally and no cardiac murmurs are appreciated. Lab work is obtained, and results are shown below. Based on the likely underlying diagnosis, which of the following is contraindicated for this patient? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Hemoglobin     8.1 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     23.8 %    
 Leukocyte count     10,600/mm3    
 Platelet count     320,000/mm3    
 Mean corpuscular volume     78 fL    
 Reticulocyte count     5.6%    
 Peripheral smear     Heinz bodies
questions.solution:
This patient presents with new-onset fatigue and pallor after a recent course of antibiotics prescribed for pneumonia. Physical examination, vitals, and lab work are consistent with hemolytic anemia. Heinz bodies and bite cells are present on peripheral smear and are consistent with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Hemolytic anemia secondary to G6PD deficiency is triggered by certain illnesses, drugs, chemicals, and food. Ingestion of fava beans is the most common trigger of hemolytic anemia in these patients, and they should be avoided. 

The first step in assessing newborns or infants with anemia is to perform an Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure (ABCDE) assessment. Depending on the severity of anemia, patients may require intravenous access, so fluids and packed red blood cells can be administered. If a patient with anemia is unstable, it is important to evaluate for signs of active bleeding such as hematochezia, melena, and hematuria. When anemia is secondary to blood loss, the source of blood loss should be identified and addressed. 

Subsequent management of patients depends on the underlying cause of anemia. Hemolytic anemias are often triggered by certain exposures such as cold temperatures and infections in patients with sickle cell disease. Patients with G6PD deficiency should be instructed to avoid fava beans, henna, fluoroquinolones, sulfonylureas, and several other medications.   

Option Analysis

✅ Fava beans:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Penicillin:
Incorrect: This patient has glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Although many medications are contraindicated in G6PD deficiency, penicillin is not contraindicated. 
❌ Vitamin C:
Incorrect: This patient has glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Vitamin C is not contraindicated. 
❌ Blood donations:
Incorrect: This patient has glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. There is no contraindication to donating blood if the patient is not anemic at the time. 
❌ Vegan diet :
Incorrect: This patient has glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Although it may be difficult for patients with G6PD deficiency to keep a vegan diet due to food restrictions, it is possible and is not contraindicated.

questions.text:
A woman who is pregnant with a fetus with unknown gestational age presents to the emergency department in labor. There was limited prenatal care. This is her second pregnancy. Maternal labs are obtained, and results are shown below. The baby is delivered vaginally without any complications. Apgar scores are 8 and 9, and Ballard score confirms that the baby is full-term. At 6 hours of life, the infant is re-examined by the pediatrician. Temperature is 37.1 °C (98.8 °F), pulse is 156/min, respirations are 35/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the infant is in no acute distress and has scleral icterus and jaundice of the face. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. In addition to a bilirubin level, which of the following tests should be ordered next to help make the diagnosis? 

 Laboratory value     Result   
 Maternal blood type     A-    
 Group B Streptococcus     Negative    
 Human immunodeficiency virus      Negative    
 Hepatitis B     Negative    
 Hepatitis C     Negative    
 Rubella     Immune    
 Neisseria gonorrhoeae     Negative    
 Chlamydia trachomatis     Negative
questions.solution:
This baby is born to a mother with A- blood type and limited prenatal care. Given that this is a second pregnancy and there was limited prenatal care, the mother likely did not receive RhoGAM (Rho(D) immune globulin). This puts the baby at risk for hemolytic disease of the newborn from Rhesus (Rh) incompatibility. Jaundice and hyperbilirubinemia at 6 hours of life is concerning for hemolytic disease of the newborn. A Coombs test should be obtained to confirm the presence of antibodies and hemolytic disease of the newborn.

In the setting of anemia in newborns and infants, it is important to assess whether the anemia is secondary to red blood cell (RBC) underproduction, blood loss, or RBC destruction. In patients with anemia secondary to RBC underproduction, reticulocyte count will be low, while in patients with anemia secondary to blood loss or RBC destruction, the reticulocyte count will be elevated. Once anemia secondary to blood loss or RBC destruction is confirmed, lab work should be obtained to determine the cause including Coombs test, unconjugated bilirubin, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), haptoglobin, urinalysis, and peripheral blood smear.

With anemia secondary to RBC destruction, patients will have elevated unconjugated bilirubin and LDH levels and decreased haptoglobin levels. Coombs test will be positive in hemolytic disease of the newborn where anti-D antibodies lead to the destruction of red blood cells due to blood group incompatibility, primarily involving Rh or ABO blood types. Coombs testing will be negative in other causes of RBC destruction like sickle cell disease. In cases of RBC destruction that are Coombs negative, subsequent testing should include genetic testing, spectrophotometric assay, or osmotic fragility testing depending on the results of the peripheral smear.   

Option Analysis

✅ Coombs test :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Peripheral smear:
Incorrect: This child has jaundice likely secondary to Rhesus (Rh) incompatibility. In patients with Rh incompatibility, a blood smear will show nucleated erythrocytes and polychromasia. However, a Coombs test should be ordered first to confirm the diagnosis of hemolytic disease in the newborn. 
❌ Transaminases:
Incorrect: Although liver disease can cause jaundice, Rhesus (Rh) incompatibility is the probable cause of this patient’s jaundice given the patient’s age, maternal blood type of A-, and limited prenatal care (mother had a previous pregnancy and likely did not receive Rho(D) immune globulin during this pregnancy). 
❌ Newborn screen:
Incorrect: A newborn screen is collected on all infants between 24 and 48 hours of life. It is not needed to diagnose a patient with Rhesus (Rh) incompatibility, and a Coombs test would be more appropriate to obtain now to confirm hemolytic disease of the newborn. 
❌ Crossmatch:
Incorrect: A crossmatch is performed with blood transfusions to make sure the donor and recipient blood types are compatible. This patient does not need a blood transfusion and a crossmatch is not necessary. A Coombs test should be performed to confirm hemolytic disease of the newborn.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for a two-week history of fatigue and pallor. She was born full-term, and parents report she has been healthy and developing normally and meeting all expected milestones. Temperature is 37.3 °C (99.1 °F), pulse is 150/min, respirations are 32/min, blood pressure is 88/45 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is pale and sleeping on her parent’s chest. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally and there is no increased work of breathing. No murmur, hepatosplenomegaly, or rashes are noted. Lab work is obtained, and results are shown below. Which of the following tests should be performed to confirm the most likely underlying diagnosis? 

 Laboratory value     Result   
 Hemoglobin     9.8 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     28.8%    
 Leukocyte count     10,600/mm3    
 Platelet count     235,000/mm3    
 Mean corpuscular volume     78 fL    
 Reticulocyte count     4.2%    
 Lactate dehydrogenase     335 U/L    
 Haptoglobin     18 mg/dL    
 Peripheral smear     Spherocytes
questions.solution:
This child presents with fatigue and pallor and is found to have anemia with elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), low haptoglobin, and elevated reticulocyte count consistent with hemolytic anemia. The peripheral smear shows spherocytes, making hereditary spherocytosis the most likely diagnosis. This diagnosis should be confirmed by performing an osmotic fragility test.

In the setting of anemia in the newborn or infant, it is important to assess whether anemia is secondary to red blood cell (RBC) underproduction, blood loss, or RBC destruction. In anemia secondary to RBC underproduction, patients will have a low reticulocyte count, while in patients with anemia secondary to blood loss or destruction an elevated reticulocyte count will be seen.

Patients with anemia due to blood loss will have normal bilirubin, LDH, and haptoglobin levels, and a normal peripheral smear. It is often a clinical diagnosis (e.g., hematochezia, history of excessive peripartum blood loss). When there is anemia with an elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), low haptoglobin, and elevated reticulocyte count, hemolytic anemia can be diagnosed. Coombs testing can identify alloimmune hemolytic diseases in the newborn. The peripheral smear will help narrow down the remaining causes of anemia secondary to RBC destruction. Sickle cell disease is often identified on newborn screening and confirmed with hemoglobin electrophoresis. Although hemoglobin electrophoresis can identify thalassemia, genetic testing typically confirms the diagnosis. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency requires a spectrophotometric assay to confirm diagnosis, and hereditary spherocytosis requires an osmotic fragility test for confirmation.   

Option Analysis

✅ Osmotic fragility test:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hemoglobin electrophoresis:
Incorrect: Hemoglobin electrophoresis evaluates for hemoglobinopathies such as sickle cell disease and beta-thalassemia. This patient has spherocytes on peripheral smear and hereditary spherocytosis can be diagnosed by an osmotic fragility test. 
❌ Spectrophotometric assay:
Incorrect: Spectrophotometric assay can be used to diagnose glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency. This patient has spherocytes on peripheral smear and hereditary spherocytosis can be diagnosed by an osmotic fragility test. 
❌ Genetic testing:
Incorrect: Genetic testing is one method of diagnosing thalassemia. This patient has spherocytes on peripheral smear and hereditary spherocytosis can be diagnosed by an osmotic fragility test. 
❌ Coombs test :
Incorrect: Coombs test evaluates for antibodies against red blood cells and confirms hemolytic disease of the newborn. This patient likely has hereditary spherocytosis, which is a Coombs-negative disease and is confirmed by an osmotic fragility test.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for vomiting, diarrhea and decreased oral intake for 3 days. His younger brother who is in daycare has similar symptoms. The patient was diagnosed with type I diabetes mellitus (DM) at 4 years of age and is on insulin therapy. The parents did not give him insulin today because he has not been eating. The patient sees an endocrinologist every 3 months and attends regular well-checks with his pediatrician. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/66 mm Hg. On physical examination, the child appears tired. He is dressed appropriately for the season and caregivers are attentive to him. Dry mucous membranes are noted, and capillary refill is > 3 seconds. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. The patient is admitted to the hospital and stabilized. Initial labs are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Blood glucose      230 mg/dL    
 Serum sodium     144 mEq/L     
 Serum potassium      3.5 mEq/L    
 PH     7.35    
 PCo2     32 mmHg    
 Serum bicarbonate      20 mEq/L    
 Urine ketones      negative
questions.solution:
This patient with type I diabetes mellitus (DM) is presenting with signs and symptoms of gastroenteritis and mild dehydration. He has had vomiting, diarrhea, and decreased oral intake. Significant changes in daily oral intake require careful adjustment of insulin administration in patients with type I DM. Patients and caregivers should be provided with education and resources on how to adjust insulin to meet changing needs during acute illnesses.        

Patients with type I DM require daily subcutaneous insulin therapy. Blood glucose targets depend on several factors, including the patient’s age, activity level, and oral intake. Factors that may require adjustment of insulin doses include puberty, insulin sensitivity, acute illness, and exercise. Insulin requirements may be increased or decreased during an illness; therefore, close monitoring is required. For children unable to tolerate oral intake, it may be necessary to reduce the insulin dose to avoid hypoglycemia. To maintain endogenous glucose metabolism, insulin should be reduced rather than stopped, even if the child is not eating.    

Diabetes education and support are essential in managing DM. Education should be provided on how to administer insulin, monitor and interpret blood glucose levels, and manage hypo- and hyperglycemia. Dieticians can help parents and patients learn how to count carbs, determine pre-meal insulin dosing, and adjust insulin doses for changes in routine, such as illness and exercise. A mental health specialist can help regarding the psychological burden of living with a chronic disease.    

Option Analysis

✅ Education on insulin dose adjustments  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Social services consultation :
Incorrect: Social services can help families and children with the psychological burden of diabetes mellitus, especially with a new diagnosis, and should also be involved in cases of suspected neglect. This patient appears well cared for and follows up regularly with his doctors; there does not appear to be an obvious need for social services.  
❌ Genetic testing  :
Incorrect: Genetic testing can confirm maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY). This patient is known to have type I DM and is on insulin therapy; therefore, he does not require genetic testing.  
❌ Oral metformin  :
Incorrect: Metformin is an oral hypoglycemic agent used in addition to lifestyle modifications in the treatment of type II DM. Patients with type I DM lack insulin and require supplemental insulin for treatment.  
❌ Education on dietary and lifestyle modifications :
Incorrect: Dietary and lifestyle modifications are an essential part of management of type II DM to maintain normal blood glucose levels by balancing food intake with activity and medications. However, in this case of type I DM, education on adjustment of insulin doses during illness is more appropriate.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 24-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department for new-onset fever over the last 24 hours. Parents report that the prior evening the patient was experiencing poor feeding and lethargy. He normally wakes every 3 hours to feed, but last night he slept for a 7-hour interval. The patient has a 2-year-old brother who is in daycare. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 180/min, respirations are 38/min, blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the infant appears fussy but consolable. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Laboratory results are shown below. The culture results are pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Complete blood count (CBC)    
 Hemoglobin     13.9 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     40.9%    
 Leukocyte count     21,200/mm3    
 Platelet count     370,000/mm3    
 Neutrophils     45%    
 Eosinophils     3%    
 Basophils     0%    
 Lymphocytes     46%    
 Monocytes     7%    
 Urinalysis         
 Leukocyte esterase     Negative    
 Nitrite     Negative    
 pH     6.8        
 Protein     Negative    
 Blood     Negative    
 Specific gravity     1.010    
 Ketones     Negative    
 Glucose     Negative    
 Bilirubin     Negative    
 Inflammatory markers    
 C-reactive protein (CRP)     7 mg/dL    
 Procalcitonin (PCT)     1.1 ng/mL
questions.solution:
This 24-day-old boy has a fever without an obvious source. Lab work shows leukocytosis, abnormal inflammatory markers,and a normal urinalysis. The current recommendation for patients who are 22-28 days old with a fever and abnormal inflammatory markers is to perform a lumbar puncture to obtain cerebrospinal (CSF) studies and to start empiric antibiotics.        

The initial work-up for infants 0-60 days old who present with a fever includes obtaining a complete blood count (CBC), inflammatory markers such as c-reactive protein (CRP) and procalcitonin (PCT), blood cultures, and urinalysis.        

Infants less than 21 days old also need a urine culture and lumbar puncture for CSF studies. If the infant is at increased risk for herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, such as when there is a maternal history of genital HSV lesions or the infant presents with seizures or vesicles, they should also be tested for HSV.        

Additional evaluation of infants 22-60 days old with fever depends on the results of the urinalysis and inflammatory markers. If inflammatory markers are abnormal, CSF studies (and a urine culture if the urinalysis was abnormal) should be obtained in infants 22-28 days old and considered in infants 29-60 days old. If inflammatory markers are normal but the urinalysis is abnormal, a urine culture should be obtained. If both the inflammatory markers and urinalysis are normal, CSF studies should be considered in infants 22-28 days old but are not necessary in infants 29-60 days old.        

The initial evaluation for infants with fevers is performed to diagnose bacteremia, urinary tract infections, and meningitis/encephalitis. Depending on the infant’s symptoms, additional evaluation with viral panels, chest x-ray, or stool culture may be obtained.   

Option Analysis

✅ Perform a lumbar puncture:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Obtain a respiratory viral panel:
Incorrect: Febrile infants 22-28 days old with elevated inflammatory markers and no obvious source of infection should undergo a lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid analysis and culture. Once this is completed and the patient is started on parenteral empiric antibiotics, a respiratory viral panel can be obtained if clinically appropriate. 
❌ Obtain a stool culture:
Incorrect: Febrile infants 22-28 days old with elevated inflammatory markers require a lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid analysis and culture. After this is completed and the patient is started on parenteral empiric antibiotics, a stool culture should be obtained if clinically appropriate. 
❌ Perform a drug screen:
Incorrect: Although this patient appears fussy and lethargic, the fever makes an infection more likely. The next step in evaluating a febrile infant between 22-28 days old with elevated inflammatory markers is to perform a lumbar puncture. 
❌ Obtain a chest x-ray:
Incorrect: Febrile infants 22-60 days old with elevated inflammatory markers, require a lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid analysis and culture. After this is completed and the patient is started on parenteral empiric antibiotics, a chest x-ray should be obtained if clinically appropriate.

questions.text:
A 7-month-old girl presents to the emergency department with severe diarrhea, vomiting, and decreased urine output for 2 days. The patient refuses to feed from the bottle or breast. There is no swelling, or shortness of breath. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 201/min, respirations are 30/min, blood pressure is 69/36 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is irritable with a high-pitched cry and sunken eyes. Mucous membranes are dry and capillary refill is 4 seconds. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are normal. There is generalized hypertonia in all extremities with brisk reflexes. Lab results are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? 

 Laboratory value     Result     
 Sodium     151 mEq/L    
 Potassium      4.5 mEq/L    
 Chloride     104 mEq/L    
 PH     7.21    
 PCO2     40 mmHg    
 Bicarbonate     16 mEq/L    
 BUN     25 mg/dL    
 Creatinine      0.9 mg/dL

choices.text: Observe and measure sodium level in 1 hour

questions.solution:
This patient with gastroenteritis presents with irritability and a high-pitched cry. Physical exam reveals signs of dehydration secondary to gastrointestinal loss leading to hypernatremia.

Symptomatic patients with acute hypernatremia and significant hypovolemia should receive emergent fluid resuscitation with isotonic fluids.

Hypernatremia (defined as serum sodium concentration > 145 mEq/L) can be classified as hypovolemic, euvolemic, or hypervolemic hypernatremia. Hypovolemic hypernatremia may result from gastrointestinal loss and reduced fluid intake, as in this case. Symptoms of hypernatremia in infants can include muscle weakness, restlessness, high-pitched cry, insomnia, and lethargy. An acute or severe rise in serum sodium concentration may lead to neurologic complications, such as seizures and coma. Increased serum osmolality causes water to rapidly shift out of cells, causing the brain to shrink, subsequently stretching intracranial blood vessels, and may result in intracranial hemorrhage.

In the setting of acute symptoms secondary to hypernatremia, an ABCDE assessment should be performed. If the patient is unstable, the first step is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. In patients with signs of significant hypovolemia, as in this patient, emergent fluid resuscitation with isotonic fluid is needed to restore intravascular volume and tissue perfusion. Excessive volume resuscitation should be avoided to prevent cerebral edema. Once intravascular volume is restored, or in cases where there is no need for urgent volume expansion, treatment should focus on providing fluid necessary to correct any remaining hypernatremia. Monitoring urine output is essential. Once the patient is stabilized, continuous vital sign monitoring and oxygen as needed are the next steps in treatment.    

Option Analysis

✅ Administer isotonic intravenous fluids:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Measure urine osmolality:
Incorrect: This patient has acute hypovolemic hypernatremia. Urine osmolality should be obtained to determine the etiology of the hypernatremia but not before stabilizing the patient by giving isotonic intravenous fluids.   
❌ Observe and measure sodium level in 1 hour   :
Incorrect: This patient has hypovolemic hypernatremia with manifestations including signs of dehydration, irritability, and high-pitched cry. Observation and rechecking sodium levels are inappropriate, emergency administration of isotonic intravenous fluids is needed. 
❌ Provide urgent hemodialysis  :
Incorrect: This patient with signs of dehydration due to gastrointestinal loss has hypovolemic hypernatremia. Although labs show metabolic acidosis and renal functions on the higher end of the normal range for this age, these levels are secondary to dehydration and are not indicative of acute renal injury. Therefore, urgent hemodialysis is not required in this case. 
❌ Obtain electrocardiogram (ECG) :
Incorrect: This patient has signs of dehydration secondary to gastroenteritis which can be associated with other electrolyte abnormalities including hypokalemia that may lead to arrythmias. In this patient, potassium is within normal range, so ECG is not required.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of difficulty walking. The patient’s parent states that, due to leg pain, the patient has been limping for the past two days, and today he refuses to walk. He has had fever, malaise, and poor oral intake over the past three days. The patient has no significant past medical history and does not take any medication. He is up-to-date on vaccinations. Weight is 62nd percentile and height is 45th percentile. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 75/32 mmHg, pulse is 144/min, respiratory rate is 32/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient is ill-appearing and uncomfortable. Examination of the right leg reveals an effusion of the right knee with overlying erythema and warmth. There is limited passive and active range of motion of the right knee due to pain. Examination of the left leg is normal. There are 2+ dorsalis pedis pulses bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents for assessment of progressively worsening right leg pain, and refusal to bear weight and ambulate. This, along with the associated fever and malaise as well as decreased range of motion of the right knee, with effusion, erythema, and warmth is consistent with septic arthritis. Based on the history, physical examination, and vital signs, the patient is unstable and septic. Therefore, the most important initial step in management is administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics, with coverage of Staphylococcus aureus, which is the most common cause of septic arthritis in children, and Neisseria meningitidis. Vancomycin and cefepime are the appropriate antibiotic choices for pediatric patients with septic arthritis who are hemodynamically unstable. 

The acute management for unstable patients with septic arthritis centers on initial stabilization of airway, breathing, and circulation. Patients should be given intravenous fluids and continuous vital sign monitoring. All unstable patients should receive intravenous empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics, typically with a regimen that includes vancomycin with cefepime or vancomycin with ceftriaxone and Cefazolin, Nafcillin, or Oxacillin. Patients with sepsis who are unstable should be given immediate empiric antibiotics before arthrocentesis is performed, as a delay in antibiotic administration may be life-threatening. In contrast, stable patients should first have an arthrocentesis; and empiric antibiotics should be started while awaiting culture results. Antibiotic coverage for septic arthritis in hemodynamically stable patients depends on the patient’s age and risk factors. Patients should be covered for Staphylococcus aureus but may require additional coverage. For instance, if there is history of penetrating trauma, antibiotics should cover Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and if a patient is sexually active, antibiotics should cover Neisseria gonorrhea.   

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous vancomycin and cefepime:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous cefepime:
Incorrect: This patient likely has septic arthritis and is hemodynamically unstable. Empiric treatment needs to cover for pathogens most likely to cause septic arthritis including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus, and Neisseria meningitidis. The appropriate antibiotic regimen is vancomycin in addition to cefepime. 
❌ Intravenous methylprednisolone:
Incorrect: Methylprednisolone is not indicated in the treatment of septic arthritis. This patient requires empiric antibiotics with vancomycin and cefepime. 
❌ Intravenous clindamycin:
Incorrect: This patient has septic arthritis and is hemodynamically unstable. Empiric treatment needs to cover for pathogens most likely to cause septic arthritis including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus, and Neisseria meningitidis. The appropriate antibiotic regimen is vancomycin and cefepime. Clindamycin would be appropriate if the patient were hemodynamically stable and there was a high rate of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus in the community. 
❌ Intraarticular glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Administration of intraarticular glucocorticoids is not indicated in the treatment of septic arthritis. Administration can be considered for patients with juvenile idiopathic oligoarthritis. This patient has a septic joint and requires empiric intravenous antibiotics with vancomycin and cefepime.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought by his parents to the emergency department for evaluation of right leg pain. The patient had multiple episodes of watery diarrhea and low-grade fevers five days ago, which have fully resolved. However, over the past two days, the patient began complaining of right leg pain, and today he was limping. The patient has no significant past medical history and does not take any medication. Parents deny dysuria or hematuria. He is up-to-date on his vaccinations. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 95/58 mmHg, pulse is 135/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is in no acute distress and is well-appearing. There is limited range of motion at the right hip secondary to pain, but active and passive movement is possible. There is no obvious erythema or warmth over the hip. All other joints are within normal limits. Laboratory results are shown below. Hip ultrasound shows an effusion. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Hemoglobin      12.5 g/dL     
 Leukocyte count      16,100/mm3     
 Platelet count      344,000/mm3     
 C-reactive protein (CRP)      1mg/dL     
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)      15 mm/h
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents for assessment of right leg pain and limping and is found to have limited range of motion of the right hip due to pain. He has had a recent viral illness, which, along with the other clinical features, is suggestive of transient synovitis. Hip effusion is seen on ultrasound. Given that the patient has a white blood cell count over 15,500 and a slightly elevated c-reactive protein, he should have an arthrocentesis on this joint to formally rule out septic arthritis.

Septic arthritis refers to a bacterial infection of the synovium and joint space. Transient synovitis (toxic synovitis) is noninfectious synovial inflammation and can present similarly. Differentiating the two is important since the treatment is different. Transient synovitis is a benign and self-limited illness, whereas septic arthritis requires drainage of the joint and antibiotics to prevent permanent bone, joint damage, and multisystem involvement.

If there is enough suspicion, formal diagnosis of septic arthritis or transient synovitis is confirmed via joint aspiration, with evaluation of synovial fluid cell count with differential, gram stain, and culture. In patients with septic arthritis, synovial fluid analysis will typically reveal bacterial growth, cloudy or purulent fluid, as well as a cell count > 50K WBC/mm3. Patients can also have positive blood cultures. In contrast, patients with transient synovitis will have a negative gram stain and culture, clear or yellow fluid, and a cell count of 5K - 15K WBC/mm3.    

Option Analysis

✅ Perform hip arthrocentesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Order hip x-ray:
Incorrect: An x-ray of the hip may identify fracture, osteomyelitis, or other causes of pain and swelling, but is not the best next step in management. This patient’s history is concerning for transient synovitis, However, there is elevation of laboratory studies warranting further evaluation of arthrocentesis to rule out septic arthritis. 
❌ Order hip magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
Incorrect: An MRI may identify effusions or abnormalities of the bone and soft tissues, but it is not the best next step for this patient. This patient’s history is concerning for transient synovitis, but there is elevation of laboratory studies warranting further evaluation with arthrocentesis to rule out septic arthritis. 
❌ Order Borrelia burgorferi enzyme immunoassay (EIA) :
Incorrect: Lyme arthritis often presents as monoarthritis of the knee with effusion. This patient has an effusion in the hip and a history of recent gastrointestinal illness, making transient synovitis more likely. However, this patient has elevations in laboratory studies, making arthrocentesis the best next step to rule out septic arthritis. 
❌ Obtain urinalysis:
Incorrect: Urinalysis may be indicated if there is concern for reactive arthritis or urinary tract infection causing pelvic discomfort. This patient has an effusion in the hip and no urinary symptoms. This patient’s history is concerning for transient synovitis, but there is elevation of laboratory studies warranting further evaluation with arthrocentesis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the office for evaluation of dark profuse pubic hair and an increase in penile length that has occurred over the past two months. The parents report that he has not had convulsions, visual disturbance, vomiting, headaches, fever, fatigue, or intolerance to cold. Parents report he takes nighttime lavender oil baths to help him sleep. He has no significant past medical history, perinatal history, or family history. He is meeting all appropriate developmental milestones. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/64 mm Hg. Height and weight are at the 60th and 65th percentile, respectively. On genital examination, pubic hair is dark and thick at the base of the penis, stretched penile length is 9 cm, and testicular volume is > 4 mL. There are no testicular masses on palpation. The patient does not have acne, axillary body hair, or café-au-lait spots. Abdomen is soft and non-tender without palpable masses. X-ray of the left hand shows bone age consistent with 9 years of age. Which of the following should be ordered next to help make the diagnosis?

choices.text: Luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle stimulating hormone (FSH), and testosterone levels

questions.solution:
This 5-year-old boy with gonadarche, adrenarche, and advanced bone age on X-ray has precocious puberty. The best next step is to obtain luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and testosterone levels to help differentiate central from peripheral precocious puberty. 

In biological males who present with testicular enlargement > 3 mL before the age of 9 years, axillary hair, or apocrine odor on physical exam and tanner stage II or higher testicular and pubic hair development (gonadarche and adrenarche), bone age and height velocity should be determined. Bone age is determined by X-ray imaging of the left hand and wrist. If bone age is ≥ 2 standard deviations above the child’s chronological age, as in this case, precocious puberty can be diagnosed, and labs should be obtained to determine if the child has central or peripheral precocious puberty.

To help differentiate central from peripheral precocious puberty, LH, FSH, and testosterone levels should be checked. If pubertal levels are noted, central precocious puberty can be diagnosed, and thyroid levels and brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) should be checked to determine the etiology. If prepubertal levels of LH, FSH, and testosterone (low LH and FSH and elevated testosterone) are noted, peripheral precocious puberty can be diagnosed. Exogenous steroid exposure from use of oral contraceptives, testosterone transdermal patches, and (occasionally) tea tree oil and lavender can lead to peripheral precocious puberty. If there is no exogenous exposure to steroids, endogenous causes of peripheral precocious puberty should be considered, such as McCune Albright syndrome, testicular tumors, adrenal tumors, and non-classical congenital adrenal hyperplasia.        

Option Analysis

❌ Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) :
Incorrect: Brain MRI is useful to determine the etiology of central precocious puberty in biological males younger than 9 years with pubertal levels of testosterone, luteinizing hormone (LH), and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) with or without neurological signs. This patient has precocious puberty without neurological signs, so the best initial step for diagnosis is to order LH, FSH, and testosterone levels to help determine if the patient has central or peripheral puberty. 
❌ Human chorionic gonadotrophin (hCG) level :
Incorrect: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (hCG) may be elevated with testicular germ cell tumors. The patient in this case does not have abdominal or testicular masses to indicate testicular germ cell tumor. The best initial step is to order LH and FSH and testosterone levels to help differentiate central from peripheral precocious puberty. 
✅ Luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle stimulating hormone (FSH), and testosterone levels:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Pelvic ultrasound:
Incorrect: Pelvic ultrasound can be used to visualize ovarian and testicular tumors in the pelvis in patients with signs of precocious puberty, rapid progression of symptoms, or abdominal or testicular masses. This patient does not have asymmetrical testicular enlargement or masses on exam, making testicular tumor a less likely cause of precocious puberty in this patient.  
❌ X-ray of the femur :
Incorrect: X-ray of the femur can help confirm the diagnosis of McCune-Albright syndrome (MAS) with findings of expanded bone with a ground glass appearance, indicating polyostotic fibrous dysplasia of bone (PFD). MAS is characterized by precocious puberty but also café-au-lait skin pigmentation and PFD, which are not seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl presents to the primary care office accompanied by her parent because of two weeks of frequent, greasy, foul-smelling diarrhea. Her parent reports she has not been as active as usual and occasionally reports abdominal pain. She has had frequent flatulence but no vomiting. The family vacationed in Vermont, United States last month where the child was swimming in a freshwater lake daily. Nobody else around her has been sick. Past medical history is unremarkable, and she does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 138/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and blood pressure is 94/52 mmHg. On examination, the child appears tired but is alert and oriented. Mucus membranes are dry. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits except for mild tachycardia. The abdomen is soft and non-tender with hyperactive bowel sounds. Microscopic examination of the stool reveals the organism pictured below. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of diarrhea in this patient?  



Image by Eva Nohýnková, Department of Tropical Medicine, 1st Faculty of Medicine, Charles University in Prague and Hospital Bulovka, Czech Republic. Image in paper by Marie Lipoldova, Laboratory of Molecular and Cellular Immunology, Institute of Molecular Genetics, Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic, Prague, Czech Republic. Licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license. Reproduced from WikiCommons
questions.solution:
This child is presenting with classic symptoms of parasitic gastroenteritis, including frequent, greasy, and foul-smelling diarrhea (i.e. steatorrhea); malaise; flatulence; and abdominal cramps. This child likely acquired the infection from accidental water ingestion while swimming in a freshwater lake in the northern United States. The flagellated, pear-shaped protozoa seen on stool microscopy confirms the diagnosis of Giardia duodenalis.        

A thorough history and physical examination can provide key details in the evaluation of diarrhea in children. Acute diarrhea is usually caused by an infectious etiology, either viral (most common), bacterial, or parasitic. Diarrhea caused by a virus is usually watery in nature and without red flags (i.e. blood or mucus in stool, severe abdominal pain or dehydration, and high fevers). It is most often caused by norovirus in countries where rotavirus vaccination is routine. Norovirus is highly contagious and spreads through close contact with infected individuals through a fecal-oral route. Day care centers, schools, healthcare facilities, and cruise ships are known to be associated with outbreaks.        

Bacterial gastroenteritis is often associated with acute bloody diarrhea or other red flags and may be caused by Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, or Escherichia coli. These infections may be associated with foodborne transmission from undercooked or cross-contaminated meat. In addition to food sources, Salmonella is known for transmission from handling reptiles, rodents, and other animals.        

Parasitic gastroenteritis can lead to either acute or chronic diarrhea and is most often caused by Giardia or Cryptosporidium. The diarrhea is usually non-bloody, watery, and it can be associated with steatorrhea. Transmission of parasitic disease primarily occurs through water, either from drinking contaminated water or during recreational activities in a contaminated body of water, such as a stream or lake.  

Option Analysis

✅ Giardia duodenalis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Campylobacter jejuni:
Incorrect: Campylobacter jejuni is a bacterial cause of gastroenteritis. It typically presents with diarrhea, fever, abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody stools. The lack of bloody stools, presence of watery stools, and flatulence as well as the exposure to a freshwater lake makes Giardia duodenalis the more likely cause of this patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Norovirus:
Incorrect: Norovirus can cause watery diarrhea and abdominal pain, often accompanied by vomiting. This patient has evidence of steatorrhea, which is unlikely with norovirus; and the flagellated, pear-shaped protozoa in this patient’s stool sample are diagnostic of Giardia.  
❌ Salmonella typhi:
Incorrect: Salmonella typhi is the bacteria that causes Typhoid fever, an infection characterized by abdominal pain, high fever, rash, headache, and either diarrhea or constipation. While typhoid fever is also spread through contaminated water, it is usually encountered outside of the United States. In addition to the geographic location of infection, this patient’s lack of fever, steatorrhea, and the microscopy findings are more consistent with Giardia duodenalis infection.  
❌ Toxoplasma gondii:
Incorrect: Toxoplasma gondii is a parasite that can cause a wide range of symptoms. Infected patients are often asymptomatic but may have flu-like symptoms, including malaise and body aches. Rarely, it can cause diarrhea when it affects the gastrointestinal system. The presence of greasy stools and flatulence (i.e. steatorrhea), exposure to a freshwater lake, and microscopy findings makes Giardia duodenalis the cause of this patient’s symptoms.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents to the primary care office for diarrhea. She reports episodes of diarrhea most days of the week for the last three months as well as abdominal bloating and occasional crampy abdominal pain. Some weeks, the symptoms are more frequent than other weeks. She has been feeling fatigued the last two weeks. The abdominal symptoms are not clearly related to consumption of milk products. Past medical history is significant only for seasonal allergies. There has been no recent travel, interaction with animals, new medications, or consumption of untreated water or undercooked meat or poultry. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Weight is 107 lb (48.5 kg), which is seven pounds less than at her well check six months ago. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. The abdomen is soft and non-tender, with slight distension. Laboratory studies reveal a hemoglobin of 11.6 g/dL. White count, platelets, and complete metabolic panel are normal. Inflammatory markers, stool culture, and ova & parasite testing are negative. Which of the following is the best next step for making a diagnosis?

choices.text: Tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A level and total immunoglobulin A level
Magnetic resonance enterography (MRE) of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient’s chronic diarrhea in the setting of weight loss, fatigue, and low hemoglobin are concerning for celiac disease. The best initial test in the workup of suspected celiac disease is a tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A level and a total immunoglobulin A level. Confirmatory testing is done with endoscopy and duodenal biopsy.        
The initial approach to forming a differential diagnosis in a pediatric patient with diarrhea is to determine whether the diarrhea is acute (less than two weeks in duration) or chronic (lasting two or more weeks). The presence or absence of red flags will determine the next steps in the workup.        

Children with chronic diarrhea and red flags, such as blood in the stools, weight loss, nighttime symptoms, or fever, should have a complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein level, and stool studies. If blood in stools is one of the red flags, a fecal calprotectin level is necessary to evaluate for inflammatory bowel disease. If elevated, upper endoscopy and colonoscopy should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. When the fecal calprotectin level is normal, further workup with food allergy testing and endoscopy should be considered to determine whether eosinophilic gastroenteritis is present.        

Children with chronic, non-bloody diarrhea and red flags, such as weight loss, should be assessed for steatorrhea. Steatorrhea occurs in pancreatic insufficiency, and a low fecal elastase will help make this diagnosis. Steatorrhea can also occur in celiac disease, parasitic gastroenteritis, and (less frequently) hyperthyroidism. A thorough history will help guide whether tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A levels, stool studies for ova and parasites, and thyroid function tests should be obtained.        

Other causes of chronic diarrhea in children include lactose intolerance, toddler’s diarrhea, and irritable bowel syndrome. These have no associated red flags and can be diagnosed clinically after ruling out all other causes of diarrhea.    

Option Analysis

✅ Tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A level and total immunoglobulin A level:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Trial of a lactose-free diet:
Incorrect: Lactase deficiency is a common cause of chronic diarrhea in pediatric patients and in patients who present with diarrhea after ingesting dairy products. This patient’s abdominal bloating and weight loss, anemia, and chronic symptoms unrelated to consumption of dairy make celiac disease a more likely diagnosis. This can be further evaluated with tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A level. If elevated, the diagnosis of celiac can be confirmed with upper endoscopy. 
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: A colonoscopy can diagnose inflammatory bowel disease. If there is concern for inflammatory bowel disease, a fecal calprotectin is typically obtained before proceeding with a colonoscopy. This patient’s chronic non-bloody diarrhea, abdominal bloating, mild anemia, and weight loss is concerning for celiac disease. The next step in narrowing down a diagnosis is obtaining a tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A level and total immunoglobulin A level. 
❌ Trial of a gluten-free diet:
Incorrect: A trial of a gluten-free diet is not recommended as part of the workup of patients with suspected celiac disease. Antibody testing and endoscopy are more accurate while the patient is actively consuming gluten. Therefore, a gluten-free diet should be avoided until a definitive diagnosis of celiac disease is made.  
❌ Magnetic resonance enterography (MRE) of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: MRE may be indicated as part of the evaluation of pediatric patients with inflammatory bowel disease or celiac disease. However, it is not used to make a diagnosis. This patient’s chronic diarrhea, abdominal bloating, and weight loss in the setting of mild anemia is concerning for celiac disease. The next step in the evaluation is obtaining a tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A level and total immunoglobulin A level. If these indicate celiac disease, then an upper endoscopy can be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 6-week-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of an episode of cyanosis and irregular breathing. The mother reports that she had just placed her son in the crib for a nap when she saw him "turn blue” with irregular breathing. She states that the patient was behaving normally prior to the episode and returned to his usual state right after. No rhythmic or irregular movements were noted. The episode lasted less than 1 minute. He has had no prior fevers, cough, or congestion. The patient was born at term; pregnancy and birth were uncomplicated. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 92/52mmHg, pulse is 118/min, respiratory rate is 36/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination the patient is well-appearing, sitting in mom’s arms in no distress. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat, mucus membranes are moist, cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits, and no rashes or ecchymosis are noted. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with history and physical exam consistent with a brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE). The patient is less than 60 days old and therefore is considered high-risk and requires further evaluation. Patients with high-risk features are more likely to have recurrent events and worse outcomes. Pertussis testing is part of the initial work-up for BRUEs in higher risk patients.

When assessing patients with a BRUE with high-risk features, management includes close monitoring and evaluation with basic screening tests. Infants with upper respiratory symptoms (cough, nasal congestion), patients who are less than 60 days old, and those who were born premature should be evaluated for respiratory infections (e.g. pertussis and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection).

BRUEs are witnessed episodes during infancy that last less than one minute and are characterized by cyanosis or pallor; absent, decreased, or irregular breathing; a marked change in muscle tone; or altered responsiveness; followed by a return to the infant’s baseline state of health. Based on historical features and exam findings, infants who meet the criteria for BRUE can be classified into high and low-risk categories. High-risk features are detailed in the graphic above. A BRUE is diagnosed when no underlying cause for these symptoms can be identified after a thorough history and physical examination and, in the setting of a high-risk BRUE, after initial work-up fails to identify a cause of the BRUE.

Management of patients with BRUEs with low-risk features focuses on educating caregivers. Caregivers should be educated on BRUEs and how they do not put infants at higher risk for sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). If caregivers are not comfortable with cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), they should be provided with the appropriate resources to get trained. Observation, electrocardiogram, and testing for pertussis can be considered but are not usually necessary. Follow-up of these infants with a pediatrician typically occurs 24 hours after discharge. Management of BRUEs with high-risk features includes in-hospital observation and monitoring. This allows a witnessed episode and time for the patient to undergo a basic screening evaluation to help identify a potential precipitating cause. If there is an underlying cause of the BRUE, then the event is no longer considered a BRUE, since it is no longer an unexplained event. If no cause of the BRUE is identified, patients are discharged home after parents are educated and follow-up is scheduled. 

Option Analysis

✅ Pertussis testing:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Discharge with outpatient follow-up:
Incorrect: This patient presents features concerning for a high-risk brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE). Given that this patient is less than 60 days old and is not fully immunized, the best next step in management is to perform basic screening tests including pertussis testing.  
❌ Echocardiogram:
Incorrect: An electrocardiogram is part of the work-up for patients with a high-risk brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE), but an echocardiogram is not recommended unless there are specific exam findings or history concerning for cardiac anomaly. 
❌ Glucose tolerance test :
Incorrect: A blood glucose level is part of the work-up for patients with a high-risk brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE), but glucose tolerance testing is not recommended. 
❌ Electroencephalogram (EEG) :
Incorrect: An EEG is not part of the initial work-up for a high-risk brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE). An EEG should be obtained if there is high clinical suspicion of a seizure. This patient has no red flags that are concerning for a seizure.

questions.text: A previously healthy 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of low-grade fevers, weight loss, and refusal to bear weight on the left leg due to pain. He has consistently been in the 50<sup>th</sup> percentile for weight, but parents have noticed a 5-pound weight loss over the past month. The patient has not had upper respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms. They have not traveled and there is no family history of autoimmune disease. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 91/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears pale. Ecchymosis is seen over the abdomen and extremities. There are multiple non-tender, firm, rubbery matted lymph nodes palpated in the cervical, axillary, and inguinal regions. There is a soft 2/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border. There is hepatosplenomegaly. Movement of the left leg causes pain. Which of the following tests will confirm the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, weight loss, and bone pain and is found to have pallor, ecchymosis, a flow murmur, hepatosplenomegaly, and generalized firm, non-tender lymphadenopathy on physical examination. This history and physical examination are concerning leukemia/ lymphoma, specifically acute lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoblastic lymphoma, which is the most common cancer in children. While the cbc will be abnormal, a bone marrow biopsy should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

Specific testing for lymphadenopathy is dependent on the most likely diagnosis. Kawasaki disease can cause lymphadenopathy, and it is a clinical diagnosis, although incomplete Kawasaki disease can be diagnosed by including results from a complete blood count (CBC), complete metabolic panel (CMP), urinalysis, and inflammatory markers. SLE is diagnosed with positive antinuclear antibody (ANA), anti-double-stranded DNA, and anti-Smith antibodies. Diagnosis of systemic JIA is based on history (e.g., age <16, pain, and stiffness in ≥ 1 joint for ≥ 6 weeks) and consistent laboratory findings.

Primary lymph node infections are typically diagnosed clinically, although occasionally biopsy or serology testing is required. When there is regional lymphadenopathy and concern for a localized infection, the physical examination will typically confirm the diagnosis, such as in the setting of cellulitis, otitis media, and strep pharyngitis. Generalized lymphadenopathy secondary to a systemic infection can be associated with nonspecific history and physical exam findings and may require immunoglobulins or polymerase chain reactions (PCR) to confirm diagnosis.   

Option Analysis

✅ Bone marrow biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Interferon-γ release assay (IGRA):
Incorrect: An IGRA is used to test for tuberculosis. This patient has no history of cough or recent travel to endemic regions, making tuberculosis unlikely. 
❌ Complete blood count (CBC):
Incorrect: Although a CBC will be abnormal in a patient with leukemia, it will not confirm the diagnosis. Leukocytosis, anemia, and thrombocytopenia can be seen in patients with leukemia, and bone marrow biopsy is necessary to make the diagnosis. 
❌ Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) antibody:
Incorrect: HIV would be unusual in a previously healthy 4-year-old child without known risk factors for exposure. This patient’s age, along with the history of fever, weight loss, and the physical exam findings make the diagnosis of leukemia/lymphoma more likely.  
❌ Serologic testing for B. henselae  :
Incorrect: Serologic testing that is positive B. henselae can confirm a diagnosis of cat scratch disease in suspected cases. This patient's history and findings are consistent with leukemia/lymphoma, which requires a bone marrow biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents to the clinic with concerns regarding delayed sexual development. The patient states that his genitals look different from his peers when he changes in gym class, and he is shorter than the rest of his class. There is no history of headaches, visual disturbances, or neurological deficits. His parent reports that when he was growing up, he was short until the age of 17 years when he had a growth spurt associated with the development of pubic hair and a deepened voice. Past medical and surgical history are noncontributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Growth charts show his height consistently at the 3rd percentile since the age of 2 and his weight at the 25th percentile. On physical examination, there is no pubic hair, no gynecomastia, and testicular volume is 3 mL. Luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and testosterone levels are low. Thyroid and prolactin levels are normal. X-ray of the left-hand shows his bone age consistent with 11 years of age. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of delayed sexual development in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with delayed puberty and a family history that is positive for delayed puberty. He has no history of chronic disease or chronic stress, and he has no neurologic signs or symptoms. He is found to have delayed bone age on radiographs. Constitutional delay of growth and puberty (CDGP) is the most probable cause of these findings.

Constitutional delay of growth and puberty (CDGP) is the most common cause of delayed puberty and is considered a normal variant. It is due to a transient functional defect in production of GnRH from the hypothalamus secondary to genetic factors and results in puberty beginning later than the typical age, but puberty then progressing normally afterward. An affected child typically presents in early adolescence, when peers are beginning to develop and have growth spurts, but the patient is not. The patient's height is typically at or below the 3rd percentile for age. Family history of delayed puberty in a parent or the presence of “late bloomers” in the family is positive in 50% of the patients. The physical examination findings may reveal delayed adrenarche and gonadarche but are otherwise unremarkable. Pubertal delay can lead to significant psychosocial distress in teens and their families. Without intervention, final adult height usually reaches or approximates the target height range.

The diagnosis of CDPG starts with taking a focused history including the growth and pubertal trends of the family members. Physical examination should assess testicular volume and Tanner stage. Initial investigations include luteinizing hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, testosterone, estradiol, thyroid studies, prolactin, and radiological imaging for bone age should be ordered. The absence of chronic disease, excessive stress, and neurological signs and symptoms, and the presence of prepubertal levels of gonadotropins and sex hormones with normal thyroid and prolactin levels, delayed bone age, and positive family history can be used to make the diagnosis of CDPG.   

Option Analysis

❌ Central nervous system (CNS) tumor  :
Incorrect: CNS tumors like pituitary adenomas can lead to delayed puberty and patients typically present with headaches, visual disturbances, prepubertal gonadotropins and sex hormones, and delayed bone age. This patient has no history of neurological deficits or symptoms of a CNS tumor. This patient’s personal and family history of delayed puberty is more suggestive of constitutional delay. 
✅ Constitutional delay :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hyperprolactinemia :
Incorrect: Hyperprolactinemia typically caused by pituitary adenoma can lead to delayed puberty, gynecomastia, nipple discharge, and CNS symptoms not noted in this patient. This patient’s personal and family history of delayed puberty is more suggestive of constitutional delay. 
❌ Genetic syndrome :
Incorrect: Genetic syndromes can lead to delayed puberty; Patients with Kleinfelter syndrome tend to be tall in stature and patients with Kalman syndrome often have associated anosmia. This patient’s personal and family history of delayed puberty is more suggestive of constitutional delay. 
❌ Radiation exposure   :
Incorrect: Radiation exposure can lead to delayed puberty secondary to acquired hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. This patient has no history of radiation exposure, making this an unlikely cause of his pubertal delay. This patient’s personal and family history of delayed puberty is more suggestive of constitutional delay.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to swelling around his eyes and in the legs bilaterally. The parents report that he had a viral upper respiratory tract infection one week ago that resolved spontaneously. Past medical and surgical history are non-contributory. Temperature is 37� C (98.6�F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Physical exam is significant for bilateral lower extremity pitting edema up to the knees and edema of the face as shown in the image below. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are normal. Lab results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported license. Reproduced from Wikimedia commons   


Laboratory ValueResults
Serum

 Albumin      2 g/dL    
 Triglycerides      200 mg/dL    
 Cholesterol     250 mg/dL    
 Blood urea nitrogen     17 mg/dL    
 Creatinine      0.5 mg/dL    
 Complement C3     140 mg/dL    
 Complement C4     20 mg/dL     
 Urine     
 Specific gravity     1.018      
 pH     6      
 Protein     4+     
 Glucose     Negative      
 WBCs     1-5 /hpf      
 RBCs     2-5 /hpf      
 Urine protein/creatinine ratio     0.5    
 Casts     None
questions.solution:
The findings of periorbital and peripheral edema, nephrotic-range proteinuria (3+ or 4+), hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia without casts in the urine are consistent with nephrotic syndrome, most likely secondary to minimal change disease.         

Proteinuria can be classified as transient, orthostatic, and persistent. Persistent proteinuria is diagnosed with urine protein-to-creatinine ratio greater than or equal to 0.2 on two separate occasions. Obtaining a urinalysis with microscopy, serum albumin, complement levels, and lipid panel can help distinguish nephrotic (glomerular) or non-nephrotic (tubular) causes of persistent proteinuria. The most important causes of nephrotic/nephritic proteinuria include minimal change disease (MCD), focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, and membranous nephropathy; while the most important causes of non-nephrotic persistent proteinuria include Fanconi syndrome, acute interstitial nephritis, and acute tubular necrosis.        

The most common cause of nephrotic (glomerular) proteinuria seen in children is MCD. Physical exams often reveal periorbital edema and edema in the lower extremities, as noted in this patient. Proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia with normal renal functions and complement levels, and the absence of hypertension and gross hematuria confirms the diagnosis of MCD, especially in patients with no indications for renal biopsy. Indications for a renal biopsy include age of onset less than 1 year or greater than 12 years, markedly elevated serum creatinine, gross hematuria, marked hypertension, and low levels of C3 and C4.    

Option Analysis

❌ Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) :
Incorrect: Patients with ATN typically have a history of volume depletion, receiving nephrotoxic medications such as NSAIDs or aminoglycosides or exposure to radiocontrast material and urinalysis showing proteinuria with muddy brown casts which are not seen in this patient. 
❌ Fanconi syndrome  :
Incorrect: Patients with Fanconi syndrome may present with growth failure, generalized weakness, and laboratory findings of metabolic acidosis, hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, and proteinuria. This patient’s presentation with edema, proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia is more consistent with minimal change disease. 
✅ Minimal change disease :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Orthostatic proteinuria  :
Incorrect: Patients with orthostatic proteinuria are asymptomatic and are diagnosed incidentally with proteinuria found on random void spot urine and normal protein on first-morning void urine. This patient’s presentation with edema, proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia is more consistent with minimal change disease. 
❌ Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) :
Incorrect: Patients with PSGN typically present with edema, hypertension, and cola-colored urine 2-3 weeks after streptococcal infections and urinalysis showing proteinuria, hematuria, and red blood cells casts which are not seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician for a well-child visit. Parents report that he has been doing well and they have no concerns. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 124/min, blood pressure is 88/43 mm Hg, respirations are 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 100%. On physical examination, there is a mildly increased distance between the eyes and downward-slanting palpebral fissures. He has a webbed neck and pectus excavatum. On cardiac examination, there is a 2/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border with radiation to the back. Which of the following tests is recommended to confirm the most likely cardiac condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has phenotypic features consistent with Noonan syndrome, including hypertelorism, downward-slanting palpebral fissures, webbed neck, and pectus excavatum. A systolic murmur that is best heard at the left upper sternal border with radiation to the back is consistent with pulmonary stenosis which can be seen in patients with Noonan syndrome. Diagnosis of pulmonary stenosis is best made via echocardiogram.        

Echocardiograms can be used to diagnose acyanotic congenital heart disease. An echocardiogram is used to assess pulmonary blood flow and identify specific cardiac abnormalities. If the pulmonary blood flow is normal, congenital heart disease is considered obstructive. This includes non-critical coarctation, aortic stenosis, and pulmonary stenosis.        

If there is an increase in pulmonary blood flow, congenital heart diseases with left-to-right shunting should be considered. These include atrial septal defects (ASDs), ventricular septal defects (VSDs), atrial ventricular septal defects (AVSDs, and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). In addition to assessing pulmonary blood flow, an echocardiogram is used to visualize valvular defects, septal defects, narrowing of the aorta, and patent ductus arteriosus, and to diagnose other specific congenital heart defects.        

Even though most patients with congenital heart disease will have an electrocardiogram and chest x-ray performed, these tests are not diagnostic, and echocardiogram is required. If the diagnosis remains uncertain after echocardiogram, additional imaging modalities such as magnetic resonance imaging and computed tomography can be used.   

Option Analysis

✅ Echocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Four extremity blood pressure:
Incorrect: Four extremity blood pressures are used to identify coarctation of the aorta. This patient likely has Noonan syndrome with pulmonary stenosis; four extremity blood pressures will be normal. An echocardiogram is utilized to diagnose pulmonary stenosis. 
❌ Cardiac MRI:
Incorrect: A cardiac MRI can diagnose pulmonary stenosis but is not the first-line recommended test. Echocardiogram is recommended first to confirm the presence of pulmonary stenosis. If echocardiogram is unable to confirm a diagnosis, cardiac MRI may be performed.
