❌ Genetic testing:
Incorrect: This patient likely has Noonan syndrome, which can be diagnosed via genetic testing. An echocardiogram should be performed to diagnose the likely underlying cardiac defect. 
❌ Electrocardiogram:
Incorrect: This patient has a murmur consistent with pulmonary stenosis. An electrocardiogram can be normal in mild pulmonary stenosis, or it may show signs of right axis deviation and ventricular hypertrophy in severe cases. It is not utilized for diagnostic testing for pulmonary stenosis.

questions.text:
A 5-day-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for a weight check. The patient was born at 37.5 weeks gestation by uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The mother did not know she was pregnant until she was 14 weeks gestation, and she did not receive adequate prenatal care. The patient passed meconium on day one of life but has not stooled since. Parents report she is bottle feeding well with good urine output. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient is down 5% from birth weight. Physical examination demonstrates a well-appearing neonate in no acute distress. There is a small tuft of hair above the gluteal cleft as seen in the image below. Abdomen is soft, nontender, nondistended, with normoactive bowel sounds. Rectal examination does not demonstrate evidence of imperforate anus but does show a diminished anal wink reflex. The patient is moving all extremities but has decreased tone in the lower extremities. Which of the following tests should be performed next?
 

Reproduced from: Wikipedia

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This 5-day-old neonate presents with decreased stool output despite good oral intake and urine output. The patient passed meconium within 48 hours of delivery and has evidence of a sacral dimple and tuft of hair concerning for a spinal cord abnormality. When a spinal cord abnormality is suspected, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine should be performed to assess for tethered cord syndrome, myelomeningocele, or spinal cord tumor.

Newborn patients with constipation should be assessed regarding the timing of meconium passage. Newborns with delayed passage of meconium (> 48 hours from delivery) are more likely to suffer from an anatomic obstruction or intestinal obstruction. These patients should be assessed for the presence of an imperforate anus or intestinal obstruction. Patients with an obstruction will demonstrate evidence of dilated loops of bowel on radiographs. Patients with Hirschsprung disease will often have evidence of decreased or absent air in the distal segment of the intestines. Patients with meconium ileus will have evidence of a “bubbly appearance” in the distended intestinal loops.

Newborns that have difficulty stooling after delivery (though not necessarily in the first 48 hours after delivery) should be assessed for possible spinal cord disorder. This may present as a deep sacral dimple, sacral tuft of hair, absent anal wink, or decreased lower extremity reflexes. If there is concern for a spinal cord abnormality, a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine should be obtained to assess for the presence of meningomyelocele, spinal cord tumor, or tethered cord.   

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Abdominal X-ray:
Incorrect: This patient has a sacral tuft of hair, decreased stooling, and decreased tone of the lower extremities concerning for a spinal cord abnormality. A spinal cord abnormality is best evaluated by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine. An abdominal X-ray is unlikely to provide additional, useful diagnostic information. An abdominal X-ray is indicated when there is concern for intestinal obstruction. 
❌ Contrast enema:
Incorrect: This patient has a sacral tuft of hair, decreased stooling, and decreased tone of the lower extremities concerning for a spinal cord abnormality. A spinal cord abnormality is best evaluated by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine. A contrast enema is indicated in newborns when there is concern for meconium ileus or Hirschsprung disease. 
❌ Ultrasound of the spine:
Incorrect: This patient has a sacral tuft of hair, decreased stooling, and decreased tone of the lower extremities concerning for a spinal cord abnormality. Although an ultrasound of the spine is occasionally used when there is concern for a spinal cord abnormality, the sensitivity is suboptimal. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is preferred. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: This patient has a sacral tuft of hair, decreased stooling, and decreased tone of the lower extremities concerning for a spinal cord abnormality. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine would best evaluate this patient’s anatomy, and an MRI of the abdomen and pelvis is unlikely to provide additional useful diagnostic information.

questions.text:
An 8-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for evaluation of a fever and rash. The parents report that the patient developed a rash covering his body and has been increasingly fussy and difficult to console for the past four days. He has had a fever of 38.3°C (101°F). The parents became concerned today because the skin began to slough off. The patient was born full-term and has not had any significant medical issues since birth. Vaccinations are up-to-date. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 90/67mm Hg, pulse is 155/min, respiratory rate is 25/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient is crying in his mother’s arms and is difficult to console. Skin examination reveals moist, erythematous, denuded skin, as well as perioral and perinasal crusting. There is no mucous membrane involvement. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings consistent with Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS), including a characteristic desquamating rash (without mucous membrane involvement), fever, and irritability. Most cases occur before the age of 6 years. Acute management of this condition includes administration of an intravenous antibiotic with appropriate coverage against Staphylococcus species, such as nafcillin or oxacillin.        

SSSS and impetigo are common pediatric skin infections that are most often caused by Staphylococcus aureus. While impetigo usually results from direct bacterial invasion of the skin or minor skin trauma, SSSS is caused by the hematogenous spread of staphylococcal exotoxins from colonized areas to distal sites. Exam findings can be used to distinguish mild staphylococcal infections, such as impetigo, from more severe infections, like SSSS.        

Acute management of each condition differs significantly. Patients with SSSS are much more likely to present with critical illness, superimposed sepsis, and significant fluid loss from desquamated skin and temperature dysregulation. Therefore, these patients require special attention to airway, breathing, and circulation before further management. Once stabilized, patients with SSSS should be admitted to the hospital and receive intravenous fluids and antibiotic therapy targeted at Staphylococcus species. Since most strains of S. aureus produce penicillinase, a penicillinase-resistant antibiotic, such as nafcillin or oxacillin, is preferred. If risk factors are present for methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) or if the local prevalence of MRSA is high, vancomycin should be considered. Additional management includes application of mupirocin to the nares if S. aureus colonization is suspected, as well as pain control and wound management.    

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous nafcillin:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intravenous clindamycin:
Incorrect: Clindamycin has anti-staphylococcal activity but is not recommended as primary treatment for staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS), which is the likely diagnosis in this case, because of high rates of clindamycin resistance in patients with (SSSS).  
❌ Oral clindamycin:
Incorrect: Clindamycin has anti-staphylococcal activity but is not recommended as primary treatment because of high rates of clindamycin resistance in patients with staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS). This patient with SSSS requires admission to the hospital and intravenous antibiotic therapy. 
❌ Intravenous ciprofloxacin:
Incorrect: Ciprofloxacin provides adequate coverage against gram-negative organisms like Pseudomonas; however, it does not provide adequate coverage for Staphylococcus aureus sp which is the most common cause of SSSS. 
❌ Topical mupirocin:
Incorrect: Topical mupirocin is used to treat localized, non-bullous impetigo. This agent can be applied to the nares of patients with staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) to manage colonization with Staphylococcus aureus, but it is not an appropriate treatment without the use of systemic therapy, such as nafcillin or oxacillin.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old boy presents to the immediate care clinic with his parent for evaluation of a rash. The rash has been present for the past week, and the patient has been intermittently “picking at it.” There are similar lesions on the patient's left arm. The patient reports that the rash is itchy. He has no significant past medical history and vaccinations are up-to-date. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg, pulse is 99/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient is well-appearing and in no acute distress. Skin examination demonstrates a facial rash, depicted in the image below, as well as vesicles on an erythematous base over the left forearm. Nikolsky sign is negative. There is no mucous membrane involvement. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 


Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with features consistent with uncomplicated, non-bullous impetigo. This condition typically occurs in warm, humid months, and presents as a vesicular rash on the nares, mouth, face, and extremities. The lesions coalesce to form characteristic “honey crusted lesions.” When vesicles are present, Nikolsky sign is negative. Patients are typically well-appearing without constitutional signs and symptoms, although they may have regional lymphadenopathy.        

Impetigo is a common pediatric skin infection that is most often caused by Staph species. Staph scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) is also seen in pediatric patients and is most often caused by Staphylococcus sp. While impetigo usually results from direct bacterial invasion of the skin or minor skin trauma, SSSS is caused by hematogenous spread of staphylococcal exotoxins from colonized areas to distal sites. Exam findings and historical elements can be used to distinguish between these conditions, as detailed in the chart above.    

Option Analysis

✅ Non-bullous impetigo:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Bullous impetigo:
Incorrect: Infants or neonates with Bullous impetigo typically have a rash in intertriginous areas that are made up of vesicles that enlarge and evolve into flaccid bullae filled with clear, yellow fluid that often turns cloudy. These patients will often have a fever, diarrhea, or other constitutional symptoms.  
❌ Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome:
Incorrect: Patients with Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) are typically young children who present with a characteristic desquamating rash, fever, and irritability. This patient has evidence of a localized rash consistent with impetigo.  
❌ Stevens-Johnson syndrome :
Incorrect: Stevens-Johnson syndrome is a rare disease in the pediatric population. Patients present with constitutional symptoms and a desquamating rash involving the mucous membranes after exposure to an offending agent (e.g., phenytoin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole).  
❌ Herpes simplex virus-1 (HSV-1):
Incorrect: While herpes simplex virus (e.g., cold sores or herpes labialis) and impetigo may both initially present with vesicular lesions, impetigo tends to form “honey crust” lesions following rupture. Moreover, HSV-1 typically occurs on mucous membranes, is painful, and is unlikely to involve the nares or the extremities.

questions.text: An 8-month-old-girl presents to the pediatrician with her parent for evaluation of a rash and fever. The parent reports that the rash has been present for the past 2-3 days and appears to be in “different stages of healing.” He reports associated tactile fevers at home, as well as diarrhea. The patient was born full-term, is otherwise healthy, and does not take any daily medication. Vaccinations are up-to-date, and the patient has not had any recent sick contacts. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 97/54 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 30/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is in the 50th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. She is well-appearing and in no acute distress. Skin examination demonstrates flaccid bullae over the trunk with surrounding areas of ruptured bullae forming thin, brown crusts. Nikolsky sign is negative. There is no mucous membrane involvement. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This infant presents for evaluation of bullous lesions over the trunk with associated constitutional symptoms, consistent with bullous impetigo. Bullous lesions with a surrounding area of coalesced lesions with a thin brown crust and a negative Nikolsky sign are consistent with this condition. Primary treatment for bullous impetigo involves administration of an oral first-generation cephalosporin, dicloxacillin, or amoxicillin-clavulanic acid. Coverage for methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) should be considered if there are high rates of local prevalence.        

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) and impetigo are common pediatric skin infections that are most often caused by Staphylococcus aureus. Exam findings and historical elements can typically be used to distinguish between these diseases. Treatment is tailored to the underlying condition, as detailed in the chart above.        

Option Analysis

✅ Oral cephalexin:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Topical mupirocin:
Incorrect: Topical mupirocin is an appropriate treatment for the nares in patients with bullous impetigo who are suspected of Staphylococcus aureus colonization; however, it is not appropriate as monotherapy for impetigo.  
❌ Intravenous nafcillin:
Incorrect: Intravenous nafcillin is the most appropriate treatment for patients with staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome. This condition presents in neonates or infants with fever, irritability/poor feeding, and a desquamating rash (Nikolsky positive). The patient in this vignette has localized bullae and is well-appearing, making bullous impetigo more likely. 
❌ Topical retapamulin:
Incorrect: Topical retapamulin is an appropriate treatment for patients with uncomplicated, limited, non-bullous impetigo. This patient has bullous impetigo, requiring oral antibiotic therapy.  
❌ Discharge home with dermatology follow-up:
Incorrect: Discharge home with dermatology follow-up is inappropriate. This patient has bullous impetigo and should be treated with oral antibiotics.

questions.text: A newborn boy delivered at 38 weeks gestation is found to be in respiratory distress 4 hours after delivery. The pregnancy and delivery were without complications. APGAR scores were 5 and 7 respectively, at 1 and 5 minutes. Temperature is 36.8�C (98.2�F), heart rate is 210/min, respiratory rate is 60/min, blood pressure is 60/30 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 82% on room air. On physical examination, the skin is gray, cool, and mottled, there is central cyanosis and subcostal retractions are observed. Pulmonary exam is within normal limits. Cardiac examination is significant for a single loud S2 without murmur. There are weak peripheral pulses bilaterally. The newborn is intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation and an umbilical line is inserted for intravenous fluids. Chest X-ray shows cardiomegaly and pulmonary venous congestion. An echocardiogram reveals a hypoplastic left atrium and ventricle. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This newborn is found to have central cyanosis and respiratory distress a few hours after birth. There is tachypnea, weak peripheral pulses, and a single S2 on examination. Chest x-ray shows pulmonary venous congestion and cardiomegaly consistent with hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS). An echocardiogram showing hypoplastic left atrium and ventricle confirms the diagnosis. HLHS is a ductal-dependent lesion, and patients require intravenous prostaglandin (PGE) infusion to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) to provide adequate systemic circulation while awaiting surgery within the first two weeks of life.        

HLHS is a cyanotic congenital heart disease (CHD) where there is severe atresia of the mitral and aortic valves resulting in decreased blood flow from the left atrium into the left ventricle (LV) and from the LV into the aorta, resulting in a hypoplastic LA and LV. If the duct is left to close patients will have signs of poor systemic perfusion including weak pulses, poor urine output, shock, and skin mottling, in addition to signs and symptoms of pulmonary over-circulation like tachypnea and respiratory distress.         

Chest radiographs will show pulmonary vascular congestion and cardiomegaly due to right ventriculomegaly. Echocardiogram will show hypoplastic left atrium and ventricle; mitral valve or aortic root atresia, right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH), and an atrial septal defect (ASD) or patent foramen ovale (PFO).    

Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous antibiotics :
Incorrect: Intravenous antibiotics should be started in neonates with sepsis. This neonate has hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) and requires intravenous prostaglandins (PGE) to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) for adequate systemic circulation.  
✅ Intravenous prostaglandin infusion :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Genetic consultation :
Incorrect: Genetic consultation should be offered to families of neonatal patients with hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) and features of Turner syndrome (e.g., webbed neck, lymphedema, and wide-spaced nipples), however, this patient requires prompt administration of intravenous PGE to keep the PDA open.  
❌ Surgical correction  :
Incorrect: Surgical correction of hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) occurs in multiple stages beginning within the first 2 weeks after birth. This patient with HLHS should be promptly started on intravenous prostaglandin to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) to maintain systemic circulation while awaiting surgery.  
❌ Cardiac catheterization  :
Incorrect: Cardiac catheterization with balloon atrial septostomy can help neonatal patients with transposition of the greater arteries while awaiting surgery. The findings of hypoplastic left atrium and ventricle on echocardiogram are consistent with hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) which requires prompt administration of intravenous prostaglandins to maintain the patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) and adequate systemic circulation.

questions.text:
A 4-month-old girl is brought to the clinic for a well-child visit. Her parents report that her lips turn blue when she is crying vigorously, and they return to normal color once she stops crying. She was delivered at 37 weeks' gestation. The pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated, and the parent and fetus had routine prenatal care. The infant is breastfeeding and at times she takes a long time to feed. All immunizations are up-to-date. Temperature is 36.8�C (98.2�F), heart rate is 170/min, respiratory rate is 45/min, blood pressure is 85/47 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 81% on room air while crying. Physical examination reveals central cyanosis when the infant is crying. Cardiac examination is significant for a grade 3/6 harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard along the left sternal border that radiates to the axillae and back. The rest of the physical examination is within normal limits. Chest x-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?



Reproduced from: Statdx
questions.solution:
This patient who presents at 4 months with episodic cyanosis brought on by crying is found to have a harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur and a boot-shaped heart on chest x-ray. The most likely diagnosis is tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). Cyanotic spells triggered by agitation or illness that resolve spontaneously are suggestive of paroxysmal hypercyanotic attacks, or tet spells. Difficulty feeding and physical examination findings of low oxygen saturation and a harsh high-intensity systolic murmur (radiating to the axillae or back), along with a “boot-shaped” heart seen on the chest x-ray are all consistent with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).         

Patients with TOF most commonly present within the first few months of life with a systolic murmur with or without associated hypercyanotic (Tet) spells and low oxygen saturation. Tet spells can occur when there is increased right ventricular outflow tract obstruction, increased pulmonary vascular resistance, or decreased systemic vascular resistance which promotes increased shunting from the right ventricle to the left ventricle, causing more mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood resulting in severe cyanosis. These spells are often triggered by agitation or illness. They usually resolve by calming the infant, administering oxygen, and placing the infant in the knee-to-chest position, but some may require medication.        

The timing of symptoms in patients with TOF depends on the severity of the right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. TOF has 4 main components; overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect (VSD), pulmonary stenosis, and right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH). Echocardiogram findings of an overriding aorta with VSD, pulmonary stenosis, and RVH confirm the diagnosis of TOF.   

Option Analysis

❌ Hypoplastic left heart syndrome  :
Incorrect: Hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) is a ductal-dependent lesion that results in central cyanosis and respiratory distress within a few hours after birth. With Cardiomegaly seen on chest x-ray. This patient’s age, episodes of cyanosis with crying, difficulty feeding, harsh systolic murmur, and chest x-ray finding of a “boot-shaped” heart are consistent with tetralogy of Fallot.  
✅ Tetralogy of Fallot:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Transposition of the great arteries  :
Incorrect: Patients with transposition of the great arteries develop symptoms within the first 12 hours of life. They present with tachypnea, a loud single S2, and a chest X-ray with the pathognomonic "egg on a string" appearance. This patient’s age, episodes of cyanosis with crying, difficulty feeding, harsh systolic murmur, and chest x-ray finding of a “boot-shaped” heart are consistent with tetralogy of Fallot. 
❌ Tricuspid atresia  :
Incorrect: Patients with Tricuspid atresia present shortly after birth with severe cyanosis, a single S2, and chest X-ray that demonstrates decreased pulmonary blood flow and cardiomegaly. This patient’s age, cyanotic spells, difficulty feeding, harsh systolic murmur, and chest x-ray finding of a “boot-shaped” heart are consistent with tetralogy of Fallot. 
❌ Total anomalous pulmonary venous return  :
Incorrect: Patients with total anomalous pulmonary venous return present with profound respiratory distress. They do not have a murmur on cardiac examination, and chest X-ray shows a characteristic "snowman" appearance. This patient’s age, episodes of cyanosis with crying, difficulty feeding, harsh systolic murmur, and chest x-ray finding of a “boot-shaped” heart are consistent with tetralogy of Fallot.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department accompanied by his parents for evaluation of five days of fever and fatigue. Parents report the patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Vaccinations are up-to-date and the patient has received all appropriate pediatric well-child care. Temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), blood pressure is 91/46 mmHg, pulse is 155/min, respiratory rate is 26/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient appears uncomfortable but is alert. Physical exam is significant for a diffuse maculopapular rash, bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis, cracked lips, a swollen and red tongue, erythematous and enlarged tonsils, and swelling of the hands and feet bilaterally. There is a 2/6 systolic murmur heard best at left sternal border. Capillary refill is less than 2 seconds. Blood work and throat culture are obtained and pending. An echocardiogram is ordered, and intravenous fluids are started. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Await echocardiogram findings and lab results before starting treatment

questions.solution:
This patient fulfills the diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease (KD) as evidenced by the presence of fever for five days and the presence of at least four of the diagnostic clinical features. Initial treatment of Kawasaki disease is intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) and high-dose aspirin.       

Acute management of patients with KD involves prompt recognition of the condition based on diagnostic criteria, followed by an assessment of stability. Stabilization of the airway, breathing, and circulation is prioritized. Patients should receive supplemental oxygen and intravenous fluids if clinically indicated.       

Kawasaki disease shock syndrome (KDSS) is defined as sustained systolic hypotension (i.e. decrease in blood pressure greater than 20 percent from baseline) or clinical signs of poor perfusion (e.g. delayed capillary refill). It can easily be confused with sepsis. It is a potentially life-threatening complication of KD and requires prompt diagnosis. Treatment involves fluid administration, vasopressor therapy, IVIG, and aspirin. Patients with KDSS are at higher risk for KD that is refractory to IVIG.   

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG):
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: This patient has Kawasaki disease and initial treatment is intravenous immunoglobulin and high-dose aspirin. Antibiotics are not indicated. Although Kawasaki disease and group A Streptococcus present similarly, this patient’s nonexudative conjunctivitis and swelling of the hands and feet make Kawasaki disease more likely. 
❌ Intravenous hydrocortisone:
Incorrect: This patient has Kawasaki disease, and initial treatment is intravenous immunoglobulin and high-dose aspirin. Intravenous hydrocortisone can be used to treat refractory shock in patients with Kawasaki disease shock; however, this patient is not hypotensive and does not have signs of poor perfusion.  
❌ Await echocardiogram findings and lab results before starting treatment:
Incorrect: This patient has Kawasaki disease, and initial treatment is intravenous immunoglobulin and high-dose aspirin. While an echocardiogram is indicated in the workup and management of Kawasaki’s disease, it should not delay treatment. 
❌ Epinephrine drip:
Incorrect: This patient has Kawasaki disease, and initial treatment is intravenous immunoglobulin and high-dose aspirin. An epinephrine drip is indicated in the setting of shock that does not improve with fluid resuscitation. Although patients can have Kawasaki disease shock syndrome, this patient is not hypotensive and does not have signs of poor perfusion.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presents to the emergency department accompanied by her parents for evaluation of seven days of fever. They saw the pediatrician last week who diagnosed the patient with an upper respiratory virus with associated viral conjunctivitis. Since that time, the patient developed a diffuse, red rash and a red tongue. She has been meeting appropriate developmental milestones and vaccinations are up to date. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), blood pressure is 94/55 mmHg, pulse is 142/min, respiratory rate is 30/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals a strawberry red tongue and a diffuse maculopapular rash. Bilateral non-exudative conjunctivitis and erythematous cracked lips are also noted. The patient is otherwise well-appearing and in no respiratory distress. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is 78 mm/hr and c-reactive protein (CRP) is 6 mg/dL. An echocardiogram shows a small coronary artery aneurysm. Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is started. Which of the following additional treatments is indicated at this time?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical findings, lab work, and echocardiogram findings consistent with incomplete Kawasaki disease (KD). When patients meet diagnostic criteria for classic or incomplete KD, treatment includes high-dose intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) and high-dose aspirin.         

Treatment of classic and incomplete KD is the same: high-dose aspirin and IVIG are given. Cardiology should be consulted on all cases of KD. Following initial treatment, patients with KD require surveillance monitoring with repeat echocardiography. Frequency of echocardiograms and treatment duration with aspirin depends on the severity of illness determined by the presence of coronary complications. A second dose of IVIG is administered if the patient is still febrile ≥ 36 hours after the initial treatment with IVIG.   

Option Analysis

✅ High-dose aspirin :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Clopidogrel:
Incorrect: This patient has Kawasaki disease (KD) and should be started on high-dose aspirin in addition to IVIG. Clopidogrel is an anti-platelet agent that would only be indicated if the patient is intolerant to aspirin or in the setting of medium or large coronary arteries, in which case it would be given along with aspirin. 
❌ Prednisolone:
Incorrect: This patient has Kawasaki disease (KD). Prednisolone and glucocorticoids in general are not indicated in the management of patients with KD. Although prednisolone can be administered when there is suspicion of IVIG resistance, high-dose aspirin is started on all patients with KD immediately after diagnosis. 
❌ Plasmapheresis:
Incorrect: This patient has Kawasaki disease (KD) and should be started on high-dose aspirin. Plasmapheresis is not indicated in the acute management of patients with KD.  
❌ Second dose of IVIG:
Incorrect: This patient has Kawasaki disease (KD) and should be started on high-dose aspirin. A second dose of IVIG is indicated if the patient still has a fever ≥ 36 hours after the first dose of IVIG.

questions.text:
Six hours ago, a newborn girl was delivered via uncomplicated vaginal delivery at 37 weeks of estimated gestation age. She is cyanotic and is having difficulty feeding in the newborn nursery. The pregnancy was uncomplicated, and the mother had regular prenatal care. The rupture of membrane was six hours prior to delivery, group B streptococcus (GBS) was negative, and amniotic fluid was clear. APGAR scores were 6 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F) and stable, pulse is 210/min, respirations are 55/min, blood pressure is 63/39 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 85% at the right hand and 86% at the left foot. Physical exam shows no dysmorphic features but reveals cyanotic mucous membranes and extremities. There is mild nasal flaring, and intercostal retractions are seen. Cardiac exam reveals a single loud second heart sound and harsh systolic ejection murmur at the left sternal border. On pulmonary exam, air entry is equal bilaterally and normal breath sounds are heard throughout. The abdomen is soft without hepatosplenomegaly. Pulses are equal and symmetrical bilaterally. Chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the best next step for confirming the diagnosis?
 

Statdx
questions.solution:
This newborn with central cyanosis and physical exam findings of low oxygen saturation, a harsh systolic ejection murmur at the left sternal border, and a single loud S2 along with a chest X-ray showing “boot-shaped" heart and SpO2 of less than 90% in the right hand and left foot likely has Tetralogy of Fallot. An echocardiogram should be performed to help confirm the diagnosis.

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a critical congenital heart disease that presents with findings secondary to decreased pulmonary blood flow. Patients typically develop cyanosis and shortness of breath shortly after birth or in the first few months of life, depending on the severity. TOF has 4 components: overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect (VSD), pulmonary stenosis, and right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH). History may reveal cardiac defects on prenatal ultrasound. Physical exam may show central cyanosis, a harsh systolic ejection murmur on left sternal border, and low oxygen saturation as are seen in this patient.  

Newborns with central cyanosis should be evaluated for cardiac and non-cardiac causes. To help differentiate the etiology of central cyanosis, pulse oximetry for pre- and post-ductal saturations should be checked to determine if congenital heart disease is likely. Pulse oximetry measurements on the right-hand measure pre-ductal saturation, and pulse oximetry measurements on either foot measure post-ductal saturation.  

Criteria for echocardiogram to rule out cyanotic congenital heart disease includes SpO2 less than 90% in the right hand and foot, SpO2 less than 95% in right hand and foot on three separate occasions, or a difference of 3% or higher between the pre- and post-ductal oxygen saturations on three separate occasions. If pre-ductal saturations are significantly higher than post-ductal saturations, this means that de-oxygenated blood is being shunted from the pulmonary artery to the aorta through an open ductus arteriosus. This is called differential cyanosis. If any of these criteria are met, echocardiogram is necessary to evaluate the patient for critical congenital heart disease. If echocardiogram is normal or criteria are not met, consider other etiologies of cyanosis, such as pulmonary causes, upper airway obstruction, respiratory depression, neonatal sepsis, or hemorrhagic shock.    

Option Analysis

❌ Complete blood count :
Incorrect: Complete blood count (CBC) is useful for determining neonatal sepsis and hemorrhagic shock; both may cause central cyanosis in newborns. This patient's physical and radiological findings suggest a cyanotic congenital heart disease, and an echocardiogram should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Blood culture:
Incorrect: Blood culture can help confirm the diagnosis of neonatal sepsis in patients with fever and risk factors for neonatal sepsis. This patient's physical and radiological findings suggest a cyanotic congenital heart disease, and an echocardiogram should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. 
✅ Echocardiogram  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Head ultrasound  :
Incorrect: Head ultrasound should be obtained in newborns with decreased respiratory effort, history of maternal opioid use, birth trauma, and hypotonia to rule out intracranial hemorrhage. This patient's physical and radiological findings suggest a cyanotic congenital heart disease, and an echocardiogram should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.  
❌ Nasopharyngoscopy :
Incorrect: Nasopharyngoscopy is helpful for diagnosing upper airway obstruction, such as choanal atresia, vocal cord paralysis, and vascular malformations, as the cause of cyanosis with stridor or stertor in the newborn. These findings are not noted in this patient, making upper airway obstruction unlikely.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with his parents for evaluation of two days of fever and abdominal pain. He describes the pain as sharp in the upper abdomen with radiation to the back. The pain worsens after eating and lying flat and improves with sitting up and leaning forward. The patient reports nausea and has had three episodes of non-bloody, nonbilious emesis. The patient has been passing well-formed stools daily. He was diagnosed with coxsackie virus earlier in the week after his brother who is in daycare, was diagnosed with it. Weight is 67th percentile and height is 60th percentile. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 128/min, blood pressure is 104/61 mm Hg, respirations are 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable. There are scattered erythematous papules on the hands and the feet bilaterally, and in the peri oral area. Cardiopulmonary examinations are normal. The abdomen is soft and slightly distended with hypoactive bowel sounds. There is epigastric tenderness to palpation but no rebound, guarding, or hepatosplenomegaly, and no right lower quadrant or suprapubic tenderness. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. Which of the following should be performed next to make a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with a fever, vomiting, and epigastric abdominal pain that radiates to the back and is worsened with eating. He also has signs and symptoms of recent systemic illness (i.e., coxsackie infection) which can increase the risk for pancreatitis. Pancreatitis is the most likely diagnosis and serum amylase, and lipase levels should be checked next to evaluate for acute pancreatitis.        

The initial step in evaluating pediatric patients who have acute abdominal pain is to rule out a surgical abdomen. Next, the patient's stooling pattern should be assessed. Infectious gastroenteritis often presents as an increase in stooling frequency whereas constipation will present as a decrease in stooling frequency. If the patient's stooling pattern is normal, they should be asked about signs and symptoms consistent with a urinary tract infection or urolithiasis including dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, suprapubic pain and tenderness and costovertebral angle tenderness.        

The location of abdominal pain and tenderness can also give a clue to the underlying etiology. If there are no urinary symptoms, the next step is to assess for postprandial symptoms. If the abdominal pain worsens after eating, the patient may have pancreatitis or cholecystitis. Pancreatitis typically presents with epigastric pain while cholecystitis typically causes pain in the right upper quadrant. If the pain improves after eating, then peptic ulcer disease is more likely. Other causes of abdominal pain like pelvic pain from an ovarian cyst or pain from anterior cutaneous nerve entrapment are not affected by eating.   

Option Analysis

✅ Serum amylase and lipase:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Stool culture:
Incorrect: A stool culture is used to diagnose bacterial gastroenteritis. The focal location of this patient’s abdominal pain in the epigastric area with radiation to the back, postprandial worsening of pain and lack of diarrhea, makes gastroenteritis less likely. A serum amylase and lipase level should be obtained to evaluate for pancreatitis. 
❌ Abdominal radiograph:
Incorrect: Abdominal radiographs can be used to evaluate for various causes of abdominal pain such as urolithiasis and constipation. The focal location of this patient’s abdominal pain in the epigastric area with radiation to the back, postprandial worsening, and improvement with leaning forward makes pancreatitis likely. A serum amylase and lipase level should be obtained to evaluate for pancreatitis. 
❌ Urine culture:
Incorrect: A urine culture is used to diagnose urinary tract infections. This patient has no urinary signs or symptoms of findings on exam. The focal location of this patient’s abdominal pain in the epigastric area with radiation to the back and postprandial worsening, and improvement of symptoms with leaning forward, makes pancreatitis likely. A serum amylase and lipase level should be obtained to evaluate for pancreatitis. 
❌ Exploratory laparotomy:
Incorrect: An exploratory laparotomy may be necessary in the setting of an acute surgical abdomen. This patient does not have rebound tenderness, guarding or abdominal rigidity and he has stable vital signs. A serum amylase and lipase level should be obtained to evaluate for pancreatitis.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old boy in status epilepticus is brought to the emergency room by ambulance. Intravenous (IV) access was obtained by the paramedics, and he was given two doses of IV lorazepam but continues to seize. His parents state he has not had any fevers, upper respiratory infections, trauma, or potential overdose. He was born at 39 weeks of gestation, and the pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. He has been growing well but has gross motor delays for which he is getting physical therapy. The parents report that he is otherwise healthy. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 165/min, respirations are 42/min, blood pressure is 85/48 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is in status epilepticus with tonic-clonic movements. There is noticeable frontal bossing and bowing of the legs. Additional physical examination is difficult to perform. The patient is placed on continuous monitoring, and he is provided supplemental oxygen. Results of lab work are shown below. Which of the following should be administered to this patient to treat the underlying cause of the seizures? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Complete blood count    
 Hemoglobin    12 g/dL   
 Hematocrit    40 %   
 Leukocyte count    14,300 /mm3   
 Platelet count    317,000/mm3   
 Serum chemistry         
 Sodium     142 mEq/L   
 Potassium     4.6 mEq/L   
 Glucose    78 mg/dL   
 Calcium    6.8 mg/dL   
 Toxicology    
 Urine toxicology     Negative    
 Serum toxicology     Negative
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department in status epilepticus. The additional history of gross motor delay, physical examination findings of bowing of legs and frontal bossing, and lab findings of hypocalcemia are consistent with a severe presentation of rickets. The initial treatment for severe hypocalcemia is intravenous calcium. Intravenous magnesium is also often given since hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia can present simultaneously.        

The initial step in management of hypocalcemia is to perform airway, breathing, circulation, disability, and exposure (ABCDE) assessment to ensure the patient is stable. Hypocalcemia can lead to severe presentations such as seizures, stridor secondary to laryngospasm, and prolonged QT interval on electrocardiogram. If the patient is unstable, securing the airway, ensuring adequate breathing, and stabilizing circulation are priorities. Patients may require intravenous access, continuous vital sign monitoring, and supplemental oxygen.        

In severe cases of hypocalcemia (≤ 7.5 mg/dL) or hypocalcemia with severe presentations (e.g., seizure), intravenous calcium, and intravenous magnesium, should be administered. If the serum potassium is low, it should also be repleted. Intravenous calcium continues until the patient is stable and able to tolerate and absorb oral supplements. If the calcium is ≥ 7.5 mg/dL, the patient has mild or no symptoms, and can tolerate and absorb oral supplements, then oral calcium and vitamin D supplementation is appropriate treatment.   

Option Analysis

✅  Intravenous calcium and magnesium:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Oral calcium and vitamin D:
Incorrect: This patient has severe hypocalcemia causing seizures. Oral calcium replacement is not appropriate in the acute setting and this patient requires intravenous calcium. Following stabilization of severe hypocalcemia, transition to oral calcium and vitamin D supplementation for management of likely underlying rickets would be appropriate. 
❌ Oral calcium and magnesium :
Incorrect: This patient has severe hypocalcemia causing seizures. Hypomagnesemia is a common cause of hypocalcemia, so it would be appropriate to administer both due to this patient’s severe presentation. However, oral replacement is inappropriate, and this patient requires intravenous calcium and magnesium. 
❌ Intravenous calcium and vitamin D:
Incorrect: This patient has severe hypocalcemia causing seizures. In the acute setting, treatment is intravenous calcium, and intravenous magnesium. Vitamin D does not have a role in the acute stabilization of a patient with severe hypocalcemia. 
❌ Intravenous calcium and potassium :
Incorrect: This patient has severe hypocalcemia causing seizures and requires intravenous replacement of calcium. However, this patient’s potassium level is within normal limits, so potassium replacement is unnecessary.

questions.text:
A 72-hour-old female neonate born at 39 weeks is brought to the emergency department for yellowing skin, lethargy, and poor feeding. This is the mother’s second delivery, and she was born via spontaneous vaginal delivery at home after an uncomplicated pregnancy. The parents prefer holistic medicine and refused all recommended shots during the pregnancy. The mother’s blood type is AB, Rhesus (Rh) negative. The neonate has breastfed since birth and passed black-colored stools within 24 hours of delivery. Over the last 24 hours, she has been lethargic and not latching on well. There have only been two minimally wet diapers in the last 24 hours. She has not experienced vomiting, diarrhea, bloody stools, or seizures. Temperature is 37° C (98.6° F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 35/min, blood pressure is 69/36 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination is significant for a sleepy but arousable neonate with a high-pitched cry. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. Lips are slightly dry. Scleral icterus, generalized jaundice, and cephalohematoma are present. No dysmorphic features are appreciated. Cardiopulmonary exam is normal. There is mild hypotonia. Labs are shown below. Access is obtained and phototherapy is initiated. Which of the following is the best next step in management?    
 Laboratory value     Results     
 Total bilirubin     31 mg/dL    
 Conjugated bilirubin      1 mg/dL    
 Reticulocyte count      8%    
 Neonates blood type     AB, Rh positive    
 Direct antiglobulin test (DAT)     Positive
questions.solution:
This newborn patient presents with jaundice, lethargy, and poor feeding after a home birth. The parent’s blood type is AB, Rhesus (Rh) negative and Rho(D) Immune Globulin (Rhogam) was not given during the pregnancy. Lab evaluation confirms this patient has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia secondary to Rh incompatibility. The bilirubin level and clinical findings of lethargy, hypotonia, and high-pitched cry are characteristic of acute bilirubin encephalopathy (ABE). Urgent exchange transfusion is necessary.        

Jaundice is a yellowish discoloration of the skin and sclerae caused by hyperbilirubinemia. While jaundice is a common physiologic phenomenon in newborns, it is considered pathologic if it progresses rapidly, begins within the first day of life, is extremely high, persists beyond two weeks of age, or is associated with cholestasis.        

In infants with jaundice, if there is ABO/Rh incompatibility, laboratory evidence of hemolysis, and a positive direct antiglobulin test (DAT), then alloimmune hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN) can be diagnosed. Patients with alloimmune HDN can present with severe hemolysis, resulting in anemia and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Unconjugated bilirubin is lipid-soluble and can cross the blood-brain barrier and thus can lead to acute bilirubin encephalopathy (ABE). This life-threatening condition manifests as lethargy, hypotonia, and a high-pitched cry, and if left untreated can lead to opisthotonos, seizures, permanent neurologic damage, or death. Chronic bilirubin encephalopathy is also known as kernicterus.         

In patients with severe jaundice and signs of ABE, as seen in this case, an urgent exchange transfusion is needed to decrease bilirubin levels and reverse ABE. Exchange transfusion is required for newborns with signs of ABE, serum bilirubin at or above the hour-specific exchange transfusion threshold, or a bilirubin/albumin ratio at or above the exchange. transfusion threshold.    

Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) :
Incorrect: While IVIG is sometimes given to treat alloimmune hemolytic disease, this infant has signs of acute bilirubin encephalopathy (ABE) (i.e., lethargy, hypotonia, high-pitched cry) and requires urgent exchange transfusion. 
❌ Blood transfusion  :
Incorrect: A blood transfusion can be given to patients with hemolysis and severe anemia. Although this infant is likely anemic, she has signs of acute bilirubin encephalopathy (ABE) (i.e., lethargy, hypotonia, high-pitched cry), and an urgent exchange transfusion is the best next step in treatment. 
✅ Exchange transfusion :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous antibiotics  :
Incorrect: Intravenous antibiotics should be started in patients with hyperbilirubinemia secondary to neonatal sepsis. These patients typically present with temperature instability, respiratory distress, and feeding difficulties. However, this patient has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia secondary to Rhesus (Rh) incompatibility with signs of acute bilirubin encephalopathy (ABE) (i.e., lethargy, hypotonia, high-pitched cry), and urgent exchange transfusion is necessary. 
❌ Pediatric surgery consultation :
Incorrect: Surgery consultation is required for patients with biliary atresia which commonly causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia in infants. This patient has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia secondary to Rhesus (Rh) incompatibility with signs of acute bilirubin encephalopathy (ABE) (e.g., lethargy, hypotonia, high-pitched cry), and urgent exchange transfusion is required.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old girl presents to the emergency department for evaluation of fever, rash, and irritability. The rash started as generalized redness and progressively worsened. For the past few days, she has been refusing to eat and has decreased urinary output. There is no history of travel or exposure to sick contacts. Birth, family, and surgical histories are non-contributory. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 180/min, respirations are 32/min, blood pressure is 70/36 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination, there are bullae on the body and findings on both hands as pictured below. The skin over the bullae peels off easily with gentle pressure. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable except for tachycardia. Abdominal exam is normal. Labs are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?


 Reproduced from Wikipedia . Licensed under CC BY 4.0        

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Serum chemistries           
 Hemoglobin      14 g/dL     
 Hematocrit      41 %     
 Leukocyte count      17,100 /mm3     
 Platelet count      460,000/mm3     
 Neutrophils, segmented      70%     
 Lymphocytes      24%
questions.solution:
This infant with fever and a rash with bullae, desquamation of the skin, and positive Nikolsky sign has staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS). The patient is unstable with hypotension and tachycardia and requires emergent administration of intravenous fluids.    

SSSS is caused by Staphylococcus aureus producing exfoliative toxins which result in fever, erythema, and destruction of proteins in the skin. Lesions may be severe with partial-thickness burns, leading to high insensible losses due to capillary leakage and a damaged skin barrier. This can cause dehydration and shock, as seen in this case.        

Patients presenting with SSSS are typically neonates, infants, or young children with the sudden onset of symptoms including irritability, fatigue, and poor feeding. Physical examination demonstrates generalized erythroderma that evolves into diffuse, flaccid bullae. The bullae rupture, leaving areas of moist, erythematous, denuded skin. Other findings include perioral and perinasal crusting and desquamation, with sparing of the mucosa, and positive Nikolsky sign (i.e., applying pressure to bullae causes the upper skin layer to pull away from the underlying layers revealing a raw red base). A skin biopsy or culture of the lesional sites can confirm the diagnosis of SSSS; however, a diagnosis can be made based on history and physical exam findings alone.        

In children like this one with suspected bacterial infection who present with fever and rash, an Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure (ABCDE) assessment should be performed initially. If the patient is unstable, the first step is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. For unstable patients with signs of dehydration and shock including tachycardia and hypotension, emergent administration of intravenous fluids is needed to maintain systemic circulation. Continuous vital sign monitoring should be established, and oxygen should be provided as needed. Once the patient is stabilized, treatment should focus on treating the underlying bacterial infection with intravenous antibiotics.    

Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous nafcillin :
Incorrect: While intravenous nafcillin is ultimately the treatment of choice for staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (this patient's diagnosis), this patient is unstable with hypotension and tachycardia; therefore, the priority is emergent administration of intravenous fluids.  
✅ Intravenous fluids :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blood cultures:
Incorrect: While blood cultures can sometimes help diagnose the etiology of shock, they are typically negative in children with staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome like this one. Priority should be given to stabilizing any patient who is in shock.  
❌ Skin biopsy  :
Incorrect: Skin biopsy can help confirm the diagnosis of staphylococcal scaled skin syndrome. However, obtaining a skin biopsy is not a priority for this patient who is in shock. Intravenous fluids should be given to help stabilize the patient. 
❌ Intravenous dopamine infusion  :
Incorrect: Intravenous dopamine infusion is used for patients with shock refractory to fluid resuscitation, but intravenous fluids must be given first.

questions.text:
A 13-month-old girl presents to the emergency department in respiratory distress. The parents report that she was eating a carrot when she started coughing and then developed difficulty breathing. Parents report no fever or vomiting. Past medical and surgical histories are non-contributory. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 65/min, blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 70% on room air. On exam, severe work of breathing is noted with intercostal retractions and tracheal tugging. On pulmonary exam, wheezing and decreased air entry is heard over the right lower lung. Heart sounds are normal. The exam is otherwise unremarkable. Blood gas is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?  
 
 Laboratory value     Results    
 pH     7.29    
 PaO2     58 mmHg    
 PaCO2     60 mmHg    
 Serum bicarbonate      24 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This infant presents with coughing and respiratory failure that developed during witnessed ingestion of a carrot. The most likely diagnosis is foreign body aspiration. Physical exam reveals tachypnea, unilateral wheezing, and decreased air entry with decreased oxygen saturation. Lab work confirms hypoxemic and hypercapnic respiratory failure requiring endotracheal intubation for stabilization. When a pediatric patient presents with respiratory failure, an ABCDE assessment should be performed, and steps should be taken to immediately stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation, including intubation and mechanical ventilation.

Respiratory failure occurs when the respiratory system cannot adequately oxygenate the blood and/or remove carbon dioxide from it. It is a life-threatening condition requiring rapid recognition and management. Underlying causes of respiratory failure include pulmonary or airway disease, conditions affecting the chest wall, muscles of respiration, and central or peripheral chemoreceptors. Conditions that involve the bronchi (status asthmaticus, bronchiolitis, and foreign body) or those affecting the parenchyma (pneumonia, aspiration, cystic fibrosis, and ciliary dysmotility) result in airway obstruction and parenchymal loss, leading to V/Q mismatch, impaired gas exchange and respiratory failure.

Option Analysis

❌ Albuterol  :
Incorrect: Albuterol is appropriate for patients with reactive airway disease and respiratory failure. This patient is unstable with findings consistent with respiratory failure secondary to foreign body aspiration. Endotracheal intubation is the best next step in treatment.
❌ Bronchoscopy  :
Incorrect: Bronchoscopy can aid in diagnosing and treating patients with airway anomalies and foreign body aspirations who present with stridor, wheezing, or atelectasis. However, for this patient who is unstable and in respiratory distress, endotracheal intubation is the priority prior to bronchoscopy.
❌ Computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest :
Incorrect: CT chest can provide a definitive diagnosis for a variety of cardiopulmonary conditions; however, it is not an appropriate first step in this unstable patient. The findings in this patient are consistent with respiratory failure secondary to foreign body aspiration, and endotracheal intubation is the priority.
✅ Endotracheal intubation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Naloxone  :
Incorrect: Naloxone is appropriate for patients with respiratory failure secondary to opioid overdose. This patient is unstable with findings of respiratory failure secondary to foreign body aspiration.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to developmental concerns. He uses fewer words than his siblings at the same age, and non-family members find it difficult to understand him when he speaks. Vocabulary includes less than 50 words, and he does not know the names of colors or body parts. The child plays appropriately and makes good eye contact. Parents report he can catch a ball, walk down the stairs alone and can draw a square. He can dress himself. He was born 39 weeks after an uncomplicated pregnancy. However, at 10 days of life, he was admitted to the intensive care unit for a fever and was treated with amoxicillin and gentamycin for three weeks.  Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, no dysmorphic facial features are noted.  He does not look at objects or people named by the examiner. The bilateral ear canals and tympanic membranes are normal. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are normal. A hearing test reveals bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Which of the following of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 4-year-old child has delays in speech and language secondary to hearing loss with normal motor, cognitive, and social milestones.  At 4 years old, a child should be able to define five words, name four colors, and all speech should be understood by strangers. Children with hearing loss should be referred to audiology for further evaluation.

Speech and language delay is defined as children falling behind recognized milestones for age. There are multiple causes of speech delay, which can be classified into neurologic, otologic and psychologic. Neurologic factors that may cause speech delay include TORCH intrauterine infections (toxoplasmosis, rubella, cytomegalovirus, and herpes simplex), maternal drug exposure, prematurity, hypoxia, birth trauma, neonatal jaundice, meningitis, head trauma, and seizures. Otologic causes may include recurrent otitis media, and exposure to ototoxic drugs, such as gentamycin in this patient. Family history of hearing loss and speech delay indicate metabolic or recessive inherited conditions. Autism spectrum disorders are associated with speech and language delay, impaired social interactions, and repetitive behaviors.

Patients with speech and language delay should be evaluated with a focus on birth history, family history and developmental milestones. Physical examination should include behavioral assessment, neurological and otoscopic evaluations. Isolated speech and language delay is diagnosed when a child exhibits a significant delay in speech development, but maintains normal comprehension, intelligence, and social-emotional skills. To help differentiate the causes of speech delay without other developmental delays, a hearing test should initially be performed. If hearing loss is diagnosed, the next step is referral to audiology for further evaluation and implementation of interventional programs.

Option Analysis

❌ Follow up in one month:
Incorrect: This patient has language and speech delay associated with hearing loss and follow up in one month will delay necessary diagnostic evaluation and timely intervention.
❌ Order brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) :
Incorrect: While brain MRI can diagnose causes of hearing loss such as cerebral palsy or meningitis, it should not be the first step in the evaluation of this patient. Given the patient’s isolated speech and language delay secondary to hearing loss, referral to audiology is the most appropriate next step.
❌ Refer to genetics  :
Incorrect: Children with global developmental delay, dysmorphic features, or a positive family history of genetic disorders should be referred to genetics for further evaluation. As these features are not present in this patient, genetic referral is not indicated.
✅ Refer to audiology:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Recommend hearing aids:
Incorrect: Hearing aids may be beneficial for patients with speech and language delays secondary to hearing loss. However, an initial audiology evaluation is necessary to determine the extent of hearing loss and to identify appropriate interventions, including hearing aids, if necessary.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department along with his parents for evaluation of severe chest pain and shortness of breath after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. The patient has no pain in the extremities and has not lost consciousness. Past medical and surgical histories are non-contributory. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.67°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 45/min, blood pressure is 95/59 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 89% on room air. On physical exam, the patient appears alert and oriented but is only able to speak in 2-word sentences due to shortness of breath. There is generalized subcutaneous emphysema. Capillary refill is five seconds, and mucous membranes are moist. The skin is cool to touch. Breath sounds are absent over the left chest, and the trachea is deviated to the right. Cardiac exam reveals normal heart sounds and no murmurs. The abdomen is soft and nontender. No head or extremity injuries are noted, and the neurological exam is normal. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 10-year-old patient presents after a motor vehicle collision with chest pain and shortness of breath and is found to have tachypnea, tachycardia, subcutaneous emphysema, unilateral absent breath sounds, and tracheal deviation. A clinical diagnosis of a tension pneumothorax causing obstructive shock can be made. A tension pneumothorax leads to obstructive shock due to obstruction of blood flow. Emergent life-saving treatment with needle decompression is necessary.       

For patients presenting with shock, a focused history and physical examination should be performed. The patient’s skin temperature, capillary refill, and peripheral pulses can help differentiate warm shock from cold shock. Patients with hypovolemic, obstructive or cardiogenic shock present with cold and clammy skin, delayed capillary refill, diminished peripheral pulses, and a narrow pulse pressure, indicating cold shock. Besides tension pneumothorax, other types of obstructive shock include pulmonary embolism, cardiac tamponade, and congenital left ventricle outflow tract obstruction.        

A tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening condition resulting in obstructive shock. Patients with a tension pneumothorax may report chest or shoulder pain and severe shortness of breath. Physical examination can reveal unilateral decreased or absent breath sounds and contralateral hyper-expansion of the chest and/or tracheal deviation. A chest X-ray showing a visceral pleural line with absent distal lung markings and tracheal deviation or mediastinal shift to the contralateral side confirms the diagnosis. The diagnosis can be made clinically, and emergent treatment with needle decompression followed by chest tube placement should not be delayed while awaiting imaging results.   

Option Analysis

❌ Blood culture  :
Incorrect: Blood culture is commonly used to confirm a diagnosis (and guide management) of septic shock secondary to bacteremia. This patient’s presentation is consistent with a tension pneumothorax, which is a clinical diagnosis that can be made in this patient with respiratory distress, lack of air entry in the left lung, and tracheal deviation to the right following a motor vehicle collision. 
✅ Needle decompression  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Complete blood count  :
Incorrect: A complete blood count is useful in evaluating for hemorrhagic shock due to blood loss. However, this patient has a tension pneumothorax and associated obstructive shock, which should be emergently treated with needle decompression.  
❌ Electrocardiogram  :
Incorrect: Electrocardiogram is commonly used to confirm the diagnosis of supraventricular tachycardia, which can manifest as cardiogenic shock. However, this patient’s presentation is consistent with a tension pneumothorax, which should be immediately treated with needle decompression. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the brain  :
Incorrect: A CT of the brain can determine the etiology of neurogenic shock secondary to head trauma. However, this patient has no abnormal neurological findings. Instead, a diagnosis of tension pneumothorax can be made in this patient with respiratory distress, lack of air entry in the left lung, and tracheal deviation to the right following a motor vehicle collision.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician to establish care after being adopted. The adoptive parents are not aware of significant past medical history or family history. Routine immunizations are up to date. The patient has no symptoms at this time. Height is 8<sup>th</sup> percentile, weight is less than 3<sup>rd</sup> percentile, and body-mass-index (BMI) is less than 3<sup>rd</sup> percentile. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 90/52 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears proportional with normal upper-to-lower body segment ratios. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. Bloodwork is obtained. Complete blood count, complete metabolic panel, inflammatory markers, tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A, and growth hormone levels are normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of short stature in this patient?
questions.solution:
This 5-year-old patient presents to establish care after being adopted and is found to have short stature with a BMI below the 5th percentile. There is no known past medical history or family history. The patient has no symptoms at this time, and laboratory studies are normal. The most likely cause of this patient’s short stature is malnutrition or decreased caloric intake.

The initial evaluation of short stature requires a thorough history, physical examination, and evaluation of the growth chart. Important aspects of the history include birth history, dietary history, parental heights (in order to calculate mid-parental height), and family history of “later bloomers” or growth issues. The review of symptoms should be broad and assess for systemic symptoms and should especially highlight gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea). Physical examination should evaluate for dysmorphic features, pallor, murmur, goiter, skin findings, and lymphadenopathy.

One of the most important aspects of the physical examination in patients being assessed for short stature is an accurate height and weight measurement. Under age two, measurements should be plotted on a World Health Organization (WHO) growth chart. After age two, measurements should be plotted on a Centers for Disease Control (CDC) growth chart. There are special growth charts for specific situations, such as the Fenton growth chart for premature infants and growth charts specific to patients with Down syndrome and Noonan syndrome. Normal growth expectations are listed in the chart below. Heights that warrant further investigation are heights that don’t hit expected growth velocity, have crossed two major percentile lines, are more than two standard deviations from the mean, or are more than two inches from mid-parental height.
 

Option Analysis

✅ History of malnutrition:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of skeletal dysplasia:
Incorrect: Skeletal dysplasia typically presents with disproportionate skeletal growth. This patient is proportional with short stature and a decreased weight-for-length ratio. A decreased weight-for-length ratio in the setting of normal labs is concerning for a history of malnutrition.
❌ History of prematurity:
Incorrect: Infants with prematurity have usually caught up growth-wise to their peers by two years of age. It would be uncommon for a 5-year-old to still have short stature and poor growth secondary to prematurity. A decreased weight-for-length ratio in the setting of normal labs is concerning for a history of malnutrition.
❌ Presence of a goiter:
Incorrect: Hypothyroidism can cause short stature, but the weight-for-length ratio is typically normal or increased. In addition, this patient has no symptoms that are concerning for hypothyroidism, such as fatigue, constipation, or cold intolerance. This patient has a decreased weight-for-length ratio in the setting of normal labs, which is concerning for a history of malnutrition.
❌ History of chronic abdominal pain:
Incorrect: Chronic abdominal pain due to celiac disease or other chronic illnesses, such as inflammatory bowel disease, can cause short stature with a decreased weight-for-length ratio. However, there would likely be lab abnormalities, whereas this patient’s labs are normal. A decreased weight-for-length ratio in the setting of normal labs is concerning for history of malnutrition.

questions.text:
A 3-day-old newborn female in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) is being evaluated for hypotonia and decreased spontaneous movements. She was born at 28 weeks' gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery for preterm labor and required immediate resuscitation and intubation. There was no history of maternal fever, and maternal labs are within normal limits. There has been no fever, vomiting, or bloody stools. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F) and stable, pulse is 168/min, respirations are 38/min, blood pressure is 52/28 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 98%. On physical exam, the patient is intubated, hypotonic and has decreased spontaneous movements. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. Heart sounds are normal, and there is no murmur. Lungs are clear with equal air entry bilaterally. Abdominal exam is unremarkable. Nasogastric tube and umbilical lines are in place. The newborn is tolerating appropriate volumes of nasogastric and parenteral nutrition. Labs are shown below. Which of the following findings would confirm the most likely diagnosis?
 
 Laboratory value     Results     
 Hemoglobin      12 g/dL    
 Hematocrit      36%    
 White blood cells     8,000 /mm3    
 Platelets      130,000/mm3    
 Sodium      136 mEq/L    
 Potassium      4.8 mEq/L    
 PH     7.35    
 PCO2     39 mmHg    
 Bicarbonate (HCO3)     22 mEq/L

choices.text: Portal venous gas on abdominal radiograph
Blood in the germinal matrix on cranial ultrasound

questions.solution:
This preterm neonate was born at 28 weeks’ gestation and is hypotonic with decreased spontaneous movements several days after delivery. In the setting of prematurity and mechanical ventilation, these findings are consistent with intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH). Blood in the germinal matrix on cranial ultrasound would confirm the diagnosis of intraventricular hemorrhage.

Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) can occur in premature and exceptionally low birth weight infants due to blood vessel fragility and instability of cerebral blood flow within the highly vascular germinal matrix of premature infants’ brains. Other risk factors for IVH besides prematurity include cardiopulmonary resuscitation, mechanical ventilation, and neonatal transport. Intraventricular hemorrhages can have severe complications, including posthemorrhagic ventricular dilatation and hydrocephalus.

Most infants with IVH are asymptomatic. Although uncommon, neonates with severe intracranial bleeding may present with rapid-onset apnea, seizures, flaccid weakness, decreased alertness, and a bulging fontanelle. IVH is diagnosed with cranial ultrasound, which is routinely performed between 7 and 14 days of life for all infants born before 30 weeks of gestation. The severity of the germinal matrix and intraventricular hemorrhage is based on the location and extent of the bleed, the presence of ventricular dilatation, and extension into the periventricular white matter. Management should focus on stabilizing the patient, maintaining circulation, treating seizures, and correcting any apparent coagulation abnormalities

Option Analysis

❌ Portal venous gas on abdominal radiograph:
Incorrect: Portal venous gas on abdominal radiograph confirms necrotizing enterocolitis. Patients typically present with feeding intolerance and abdominal distention, which this patient does not have. This premature infant with hypotonia and decreased spontaneous movements most likely has an intraventricular hemorrhage (IHV). Cranial ultrasound showing blood in the germinal matrix will confirm the diagnosis of IVH.
✅ Blood in the germinal matrix on cranial ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Low blood glucose:
Incorrect: Premature infants are at risk for hypoglycemia, which often presents as jitteriness, irritability, tachypnea, and pallor. This patient is receiving nasogastric and parental nutrition, and electrolytes are appropriate for age, making hypoglycemia unlikely. Intraventricular hemorrhage is the most probable cause of hypotonia and decreased spontaneous movements in this patient.
❌ Abnormal electroencephalogram (EEG) :
Incorrect: The most likely underlying cause of the patient’s symptoms (hypotonia and decreased spontaneous movements) is an intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), which can be confirmed with the finding of blood in the germinal matrix on cranial ultrasound. IVH is not diagnosed with an EEG.
❌ Positive blood culture:
Incorrect: Positive blood culture would confirm neonatal sepsis, which typically presents with temperature instability, tachycardia, and hypotension. Given this patient’s clinical findings and normal white blood cell count, intraventricular hemorrhage is the most likely diagnosis, and cranial ultrasound showing blood in the germinal matrix would confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 10-day-old newborn male delivered at 30 weeks’ gestation is in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) and being evaluated for feeding intolerance. He was noted to have increased gastric residuals and two episodes of bilious emesis with nasogastric feeds of expressed breast milk. The nurse reports blood in the diaper and multiple episodes of apnea. The pregnancy was complicated by pre-eclampsia, and the patient was delivered vaginally at 30 weeks for severe pre-eclampsia. Aside from pre-eclampsia, the patient’s biological mother was otherwise healthy throughout the pregnancy. Temperature is 36.5° C (97.7°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 45/min, blood pressure is 48/28 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. On examination, the abdomen is distended with decreased bowel sounds. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. Labs are obtained, and results are pending. Which of the following tests should be ordered next?
questions.solution:
Reproduced from: Statdx
This newborn was born prematurely and is now presenting with feeding intolerance with increased gastric residuals and bilious emesis after nasogastric feeds. There is blood in the stool, and the newborn is experiencing episodes of apnea and bradycardia. The abdomen is distended, and there are decreased bowel sounds. These findings are consistent with necrotizing enterocolitis, and an abdominal radiograph can be used to confirm the diagnosis.

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a life-threatening condition that can occur in premature infants. It can lead to intestinal necrosis and perforation. Risk factors for NEC include prematurity and low birth weight. Patients with NEC typically present with feeding intolerance, bloody stools, and abdominal distension with enteral feeds. Additionally, some infants with NEC might have apneic events. On the physical exam, there may be hemodynamic instability, such as hypotension and bradycardia. Abdominal exams typically reveal distension, tenderness, and decreased or absent bowel sounds. Abdominal wall erythema may be seen, and crepitus may be palpated from free air in the abdominal cavity if intestinal perforation has occurred.

Diagnostic workup for NEC includes obtaining a complete blood count (CBC), complete metabolic panel (CMP), blood culture and an abdominal radiograph. CBC may show thrombocytopenia or neutropenia. CMP may reveal electrolyte derangements like hyponatremia or metabolic acidosis, and blood culture might be positive for infectious organisms. Dilated loops of bowel and pneumatosis intestinalis (visible gas within the necrotic intestinal wall) are pathognomonic findings for NEC on abdominal radiograph (see image above). Later complications and findings include portal venous gas (gas that has escaped into the hepatic portal vein) and pneumoperitoneum (free air within the abdominal cavity). A large amount of free air can be identified by the “football” sign on radiographs.

Option Analysis

✅ Abdominal radiograph:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cranial ultrasound:
Incorrect: Cranial ultrasound can be used to diagnose intraventricular hemorrhage, which can present silently or cause an altered level of consciousness and hypotonia. This patient’s emesis and hematochezia are more consistent with necrotizing enterocolitis, and an abdominal radiograph can confirm the diagnosis.
❌ Endoscopy  :
